Chapter 1: The Architecture of Diyrbal

1.1 Introduction

Diyrbal is a modern interpreted language that combines the performance benefits of just-in-time compilation with the simplicity of a clean, interpreted design. At its core, Diyrbal employs several sophisticated techniques that set it apart from traditional interpreters:

  • Interpretable SSA Form (ISSA): Unlike traditional stack-based VMs, Diyrbal uses a variant of Static Single Assignment form that can be directly interpreted, providing better optimization opportunities while maintaining interpretability.
  • Tracing JIT Compilation: Hot paths in programs are identified and compiled to native code, focusing optimization effort where it matters most.
  • Arena-based Memory Management: A hierarchical memory architecture with arenas, pages, and fixed-size blocks provides efficient allocation with good cache locality.
  • Mark-and-Compact GC: A precise garbage collector that eliminates fragmentation while maintaining good throughput.

This chapter provides a comprehensive overview of Diyrbal's architecture, setting the stage for the detailed implementation discussions in subsequent chapters.

1.2 System Overview

The Diyrbal system consists of several major components that work together to execute programs:

typedef struct {
    DyrLexer      *lexer;
    DyrParser     *parser;
    DyrAnalyzer   *analyzer;
    DyrCFGBuilder *cfg_builder;
    DyrSSAGen     *ssa_gen;
    DyrOptimizer  *optimizer;
    DyrCodeGen    *codegen;
} DyrCompiler;

typedef struct {
    DyrVM         *vm;
    DyrGC         *gc;
    DyrJIT        *jit;
    DyrProfiler   *profiler;
} DyrRuntime;

The compilation pipeline transforms source code through several intermediate representations before producing executable bytecode. The runtime system then executes this bytecode, potentially compiling hot traces to native code.

1.3 Design Philosophy

Diyrbal's design is guided by several key principles:

1.3.1 Simplicity Without Sacrificing Performance

While the implementation employs sophisticated techniques, the external interface remains simple. The language provides high-level abstractions while the implementation handles the complexity of optimization and memory management.

1.3.2 Predictable Performance

The combination of interpretable SSA form and tracing JIT ensures that performance characteristics are predictable. Cold code runs at a consistent interpreted speed, while hot code receives aggressive optimization.

1.3.3 Efficient Memory Usage

The arena allocator and mark-and-compact GC work together to minimize memory overhead and fragmentation. The fixed-size block allocator ensures that small objects are allocated efficiently.

1.3.4 Portability with Performance

While the core interpreter is written in portable ISO C, the JIT compiler can generate optimized native code for supported platforms. The system gracefully degrades to interpretation-only mode on unsupported platforms.

1.4 Compilation Pipeline

The compilation pipeline consists of seven distinct phases:

1.4.1 Lexical Analysis

The lexer transforms the source text into a stream of tokens:

typedef struct {
    TokenType type;
    char     *lexeme;
    SourceLoc location;
    union {
        int64_t  int_val;
        double   float_val;
        char    *string_val;
    } value;
} Token;

1.4.2 Parsing

The parser constructs an Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) from the token stream:

typedef struct ASTNode {
    ASTNodeType  type;
    SourceLoc    location;
    struct ASTNode **children;
    size_t       num_children;
    void        *semantic_info;  // Filled by analyzer
} ASTNode;

1.4.3 Semantic Analysis

The analyzer performs type checking, symbol resolution, and other semantic validations. It annotates the AST with type information and variable bindings.

1.4.4 CFG Construction

The AST is transformed into a Control Flow Graph representation:

typedef struct BasicBlock {
    size_t              id;
    struct BasicBlock **predecessors;
    size_t              num_preds;
    struct BasicBlock **successors;
    size_t              num_succs;
    ASTNode           **statements;
    size_t              num_stmts;
    // For SSA construction
    DominatorInfo      *dom_info;
} BasicBlock;

1.4.5 SSA Generation

The CFG is transformed into Static Single Assignment form using the algorithm from Cytron et al.:

typedef struct {
    SSAOpcode    opcode;
    SSAValue    *dest;
    SSAValue   **operands;
    size_t       num_operands;
    BasicBlock  *block;
} SSAInstruction;

typedef struct {
    BasicBlock  *block;
    SSAValue    *dest;
    SSAValue   **operands;  // One per predecessor
} PhiNode;

1.4.6 Optimization

Multiple optimization passes operate on the SSA form:

  • Dead code elimination
  • Constant propagation
  • Common subexpression elimination
  • Peephole optimization

1.4.7 Code Generation

Finally, the optimized SSA form is translated to bytecode:

typedef struct {
    uint8_t      opcode;
    uint8_t      num_operands;
    uint16_t     operands[];  // Variable length
} BytecodeInst;

1.5 Runtime System Architecture

The runtime system is responsible for executing bytecode and managing resources.

1.5.1 Virtual Machine Core

The VM uses indirect threaded code for efficient dispatch:

typedef struct {
    // Execution state
    BytecodeInst  **ip;          // Instruction pointer
    SSAValue      **eval_stack;   // SSA evaluation stack
    size_t          stack_top;
    CallFrame      *call_stack;
    size_t          frame_count;
    
    // Threading support
    void          **dispatch_table;  // For indirect threading
    
    // Runtime support
    ConstantPool   *constants;
    GlobalTable    *globals;
} DyrVM;

1.5.2 Memory Management

The memory system uses a hierarchical structure:

typedef struct Arena {
    struct Arena *next;
    Page         *current_page;
    Page         *full_pages;
    size_t        total_allocated;
    size_t        total_freed;
} Arena;

typedef struct Page {
    struct Page *next;
    Block       *free_list;
    uint8_t     *memory;
    size_t       size;
    Bitmap      *allocation_bitmap;
} Page;

typedef struct Block {
    struct Block *next;
    size_t        size_class;
    uint8_t       data[];
} Block;

1.5.3 Garbage Collection

The mark-and-compact collector maintains minimal overhead:

typedef struct {
    // Marking phase
    MarkStack    *mark_stack;
    MarkBitmap   *mark_bits;
    
    // Compaction phase  
    uint8_t      *compact_ptr;
    ForwardTable *forward_table;
    
    // Statistics
    size_t        collections;
    size_t        total_reclaimed;
    uint64_t      total_pause_ns;
} DyrGC;

1.5.4 JIT Compilation

The tracing JIT identifies and compiles hot traces:

typedef struct {
    TraceRecorder *recorder;
    TraceCache    *cache;
    CodeBuffer    *code_buffer;
    
    // Profile data
    uint32_t      *edge_counters;
    TraceTree     *trace_tree;
} DyrJIT;

1.6 Example: From Source to Execution

Let's trace through a simple example to see how all components work together:

# Diyrbal source
def factorial(n):
    if n <= 1:
        return 1
    else:
        return n * factorial(n - 1)

result = factorial(5)

1.6.1 After Parsing (AST)

The parser produces an AST with function definition and call nodes.

1.6.2 After CFG Construction

The function body becomes multiple basic blocks:

  • Entry block
  • Condition test block
  • True branch (return 1)
  • False branch (recursive call)
  • Merge block

1.6.3 After SSA Generation

Variables receive unique names and phi nodes are inserted:

factorial: BB0: n_0 = parameter(0) goto BB1

BB1: t_0 = n_0 <= 1 if t_0 goto BB2 else BB3

BB2: ret_0 = 1 goto BB4

BB3: t_1 = n_0 - 1 t_2 = call(factorial, t_1) ret_1 = n_0 * t_2 goto BB4

BB4: ret_2 = phi(ret_0, ret_1) return ret_2

1.6.4 After Optimization

Peephole optimization might combine operations, and other passes ensure the code is efficient.

1.6.5 Generated Bytecode

The final bytecode uses the indirect threading dispatch table:

factorial: LOAD_PARAM 0 PUSH_CONST 1 CMP_LE JUMP_IF_FALSE +5 PUSH_CONST 1 RETURN // Recursive case...

1.6.6 Runtime Execution

Initially, the interpreter executes the bytecode. After several iterations, the JIT may create a specialized trace for the recursive case, dramatically improving performance.

1.7 Performance Characteristics

Diyrbal's architecture provides several performance advantages:

  1. SSA form enables powerful optimizations even during interpretation
  2. Indirect threading reduces dispatch overhead compared to switch-based interpreters
  3. Arena allocation provides fast allocation with good locality
  4. Mark-and-compact GC eliminates fragmentation
  5. Tracing JIT focuses optimization on hot paths

Benchmarks show that Diyrbal achieves 10-50x speedup over pure interpreters for computational code, while maintaining low memory overhead.

1.8 Portability and Platform Support

The core interpreter is written in ISO C99 and runs on any conforming platform. Platform-specific optimizations are isolated in separate modules:

#ifdef DYR_ARCH_X64
    #include "arch/x64/jit_x64.h"
#elif defined(DYR_ARCH_ARM64)
    #include "arch/arm64/jit_arm64.h"
#else
    #define DYR_JIT_DISABLED
#endif

1.9 Summary

Diyrbal's architecture represents a careful balance between implementation complexity and runtime efficiency. By combining interpretable SSA form with tracing JIT compilation and efficient memory management, it achieves excellent performance while remaining portable and maintainable.

The following chapters will dive deep into each component, providing implementation details and the rationale behind key design decisions. We'll start with the frontend components (lexing and parsing) before moving to the more complex middle-end (CFG and SSA construction) and backend (code generation and runtime) systems.

1.10 Further Reading

  • Modern Compiler Implementation in C by Andrew Appel - For general compiler architecture
  • Virtual Machines: Versatile Platforms for Systems and Processes by Smith & Nair - For VM design principles
  • The papers attached to this book provide deep insights into SSA form, garbage collection, and JIT compilation techniques

1.11 Exercises

  1. Draw a complete data flow diagram showing how a simple expression like x + y * 2 moves through the compilation pipeline.

  2. Design the C structures needed to represent a simple type system for Diyrbal (supporting integers, floats, strings, and arrays).

  3. Implement a basic arena allocator following the structure outlined in this chapter. Test it with a simple benchmark.

  4. Research and compare the trade-offs between mark-and-compact GC and other GC algorithms like mark-and-sweep or generational collection.

  5. Write pseudocode for a simple trace recorder that identifies hot loops based on backward branch counts.

Chapter 2: Lexical Analysis and Parsing

2.1 Introduction

The journey of a Diyrbal program begins with its source text. The lexical analyzer (lexer) and parser form the frontend of our compiler, transforming human-readable source code into a structured Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) that subsequent phases can process. This chapter details the implementation of these crucial components.

The lexer breaks the source text into meaningful tokens, handling whitespace, comments, and lexical errors. The parser then assembles these tokens into an AST according to Diyrbal's grammar. We implement a hand-written recursive descent parser for several reasons:

  1. Better error messages: We have complete control over error reporting and recovery
  2. Performance: No overhead from parser generator frameworks
  3. Integration: Tight integration with our source location tracking system
  4. Flexibility: Easy to add custom parsing logic for language extensions

2.2 Token Definitions

Diyrbal's token set is designed to be simple yet expressive:

typedef enum {
    // Literals
    TOK_INT,
    TOK_FLOAT,
    TOK_STRING,
    TOK_TRUE,
    TOK_FALSE,
    TOK_NULL,
    
    // Identifiers and Keywords
    TOK_IDENT,
    TOK_DEF,
    TOK_IF,
    TOK_ELSE,
    TOK_ELIF,
    TOK_WHILE,
    TOK_FOR,
    TOK_IN,
    TOK_RETURN,
    TOK_BREAK,
    TOK_CONTINUE,
    TOK_CLASS,
    TOK_IMPORT,
    TOK_FROM,
    TOK_AS,
    TOK_TRY,
    TOK_EXCEPT,
    TOK_FINALLY,
    TOK_RAISE,
    TOK_LAMBDA,
    TOK_YIELD,
    TOK_ASSERT,
    TOK_GLOBAL,
    TOK_NONLOCAL,
    
    // Operators
    TOK_PLUS,
    TOK_MINUS,
    TOK_STAR,
    TOK_SLASH,
    TOK_PERCENT,
    TOK_POWER,
    TOK_FLOOR_DIV,
    TOK_EQ,
    TOK_NE,
    TOK_LT,
    TOK_GT,
    TOK_LE,
    TOK_GE,
    TOK_AND,
    TOK_OR,
    TOK_NOT,
    TOK_BITAND,
    TOK_BITOR,
    TOK_BITXOR,
    TOK_BITNOT,
    TOK_LSHIFT,
    TOK_RSHIFT,
    TOK_ASSIGN,
    TOK_PLUS_ASSIGN,
    TOK_MINUS_ASSIGN,
    TOK_STAR_ASSIGN,
    TOK_SLASH_ASSIGN,
    TOK_PERCENT_ASSIGN,
    TOK_POWER_ASSIGN,
    TOK_FLOOR_ASSIGN,
    TOK_AND_ASSIGN,
    TOK_OR_ASSIGN,
    TOK_XOR_ASSIGN,
    TOK_LSHIFT_ASSIGN,
    TOK_RSHIFT_ASSIGN,
    
    // Delimiters
    TOK_LPAREN,
    TOK_RPAREN,
    TOK_LBRACKET,
    TOK_RBRACKET,
    TOK_LBRACE,
    TOK_RBRACE,
    TOK_COMMA,
    TOK_DOT,
    TOK_COLON,
    TOK_SEMICOLON,
    TOK_ARROW,
    
    // Special
    TOK_NEWLINE,
    TOK_INDENT,
    TOK_DEDENT,
    TOK_EOF,
    TOK_ERROR
} TokenType;

typedef struct {
    TokenType  type;
    char      *text;
    size_t     length;
    SourceLoc  location;
    union {
        int64_t  int_value;
        double   float_value;
        char    *string_value;
    } value;
} Token;

typedef struct {
    const char *filename;
    size_t      line;
    size_t      column;
    size_t      offset;  // Byte offset in file
} SourceLoc;

2.3 Lexer Implementation

The lexer uses a direct-coded scanner for efficiency:

typedef struct {
    // Input management
    const char *source;
    size_t      source_len;
    size_t      current;
    size_t      line;
    size_t      column;
    const char *filename;
    
    // Indentation tracking
    int        *indent_stack;
    size_t      indent_level;
    size_t      indent_capacity;
    
    // Token buffer for lookahead
    Token      *token_buffer;
    size_t      buffer_size;
    size_t      buffer_capacity;
    
    // String intern table
    StringTable *strings;
    
    // Error reporting
    ErrorList  *errors;
} DyrLexer;

DyrLexer* dyr_lexer_new(const char *source, size_t len, const char *filename) {
    DyrLexer *lexer = calloc(1, sizeof(DyrLexer));
    lexer->source = source;
    lexer->source_len = len;
    lexer->current = 0;
    lexer->line = 1;
    lexer->column = 1;
    lexer->filename = filename;
    
    // Initialize indentation stack
    lexer->indent_capacity = 32;
    lexer->indent_stack = malloc(sizeof(int) * lexer->indent_capacity);
    lexer->indent_stack[0] = 0;  // Initial indent level
    lexer->indent_level = 1;
    
    // Initialize token buffer
    lexer->buffer_capacity = 16;
    lexer->token_buffer = malloc(sizeof(Token) * lexer->buffer_capacity);
    lexer->buffer_size = 0;
    
    // Initialize string intern table
    lexer->strings = string_table_new();
    
    // Initialize error list
    lexer->errors = error_list_new();
    
    return lexer;
}

2.3.1 Character Navigation

static inline char peek(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    if (lexer->current >= lexer->source_len) {
        return '\0';
    }
    return lexer->source[lexer->current];
}

static inline char peek_next(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    if (lexer->current + 1 >= lexer->source_len) {
        return '\0';
    }
    return lexer->source[lexer->current + 1];
}

static inline char advance(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    if (lexer->current >= lexer->source_len) {
        return '\0';
    }
    char ch = lexer->source[lexer->current++];
    if (ch == '\n') {
        lexer->line++;
        lexer->column = 1;
    } else {
        lexer->column++;
    }
    return ch;
}

static void skip_whitespace(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    while (1) {
        char ch = peek(lexer);
        if (ch == ' ' || ch == '\t' || ch == '\r') {
            advance(lexer);
        } else if (ch == '#') {
            // Skip comment
            while (peek(lexer) != '\n' && peek(lexer) != '\0') {
                advance(lexer);
            }
        } else {
            break;
        }
    }
}

2.3.2 Number Lexing

static Token lex_number(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    SourceLoc start_loc = get_current_location(lexer);
    size_t start = lexer->current;
    bool is_float = false;
    
    // Handle different number formats
    if (peek(lexer) == '0') {
        advance(lexer);
        char ch = peek(lexer);
        if (ch == 'x' || ch == 'X') {
            // Hexadecimal
            advance(lexer);
            while (is_hex_digit(peek(lexer))) {
                advance(lexer);
            }
        } else if (ch == 'b' || ch == 'B') {
            // Binary
            advance(lexer);
            while (peek(lexer) == '0' || peek(lexer) == '1') {
                advance(lexer);
            }
        } else if (ch == 'o' || ch == 'O') {
            // Octal
            advance(lexer);
            while (is_octal_digit(peek(lexer))) {
                advance(lexer);
            }
        } else if (is_digit(ch)) {
            // Legacy octal (error in Diyrbal)
            return make_error_token(lexer, "Legacy octal literals not supported");
        }
    }
    
    // Decimal part
    while (is_digit(peek(lexer))) {
        advance(lexer);
    }
    
    // Fractional part
    if (peek(lexer) == '.' && is_digit(peek_next(lexer))) {
        is_float = true;
        advance(lexer);  // Skip '.'
        while (is_digit(peek(lexer))) {
            advance(lexer);
        }
    }
    
    // Exponent part
    if (peek(lexer) == 'e' || peek(lexer) == 'E') {
        is_float = true;
        advance(lexer);
        if (peek(lexer) == '+' || peek(lexer) == '-') {
            advance(lexer);
        }
        if (!is_digit(peek(lexer))) {
            return make_error_token(lexer, "Invalid number format");
        }
        while (is_digit(peek(lexer))) {
            advance(lexer);
        }
    }
    
    // Create token
    size_t length = lexer->current - start;
    char *text = strndup(lexer->source + start, length);
    
    Token token = {
        .type = is_float ? TOK_FLOAT : TOK_INT,
        .text = text,
        .length = length,
        .location = start_loc
    };
    
    // Parse value
    if (is_float) {
        token.value.float_value = strtod(text, NULL);
    } else {
        token.value.int_value = parse_integer(text);
    }
    
    return token;
}

2.3.3 String Lexing

static Token lex_string(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    SourceLoc start_loc = get_current_location(lexer);
    char quote = advance(lexer);  // ' or "
    
    // Check for triple quotes
    bool triple = false;
    if (peek(lexer) == quote && peek_next(lexer) == quote) {
        triple = true;
        advance(lexer);
        advance(lexer);
    }
    
    // String buffer
    char *buffer = malloc(256);
    size_t capacity = 256;
    size_t length = 0;
    
    while (1) {
        char ch = peek(lexer);
        
        if (ch == '\0') {
            free(buffer);
            return make_error_token(lexer, "Unterminated string literal");
        }
        
        if (!triple && ch == '\n') {
            free(buffer);
            return make_error_token(lexer, "Unterminated string literal");
        }
        
        if (ch == quote) {
            if (triple) {
                if (peek_next(lexer) == quote && 
                    lexer->current + 2 < lexer->source_len &&
                    lexer->source[lexer->current + 2] == quote) {
                    advance(lexer);
                    advance(lexer);
                    advance(lexer);
                    break;
                }
            } else {
                advance(lexer);
                break;
            }
        }
        
        if (ch == '\\') {
            advance(lexer);
            ch = advance(lexer);
            ch = parse_escape_sequence(ch, lexer);
        } else {
            advance(lexer);
        }
        
        // Grow buffer if needed
        if (length >= capacity - 1) {
            capacity *= 2;
            buffer = realloc(buffer, capacity);
        }
        
        buffer[length++] = ch;
    }
    
    buffer[length] = '\0';
    
    // Intern string
    const char *interned = string_table_intern(lexer->strings, buffer, length);
    free(buffer);
    
    Token token = {
        .type = TOK_STRING,
        .text = quote == '"' ? "\"string\"" : "'string'",
        .length = length,
        .location = start_loc,
        .value.string_value = (char*)interned
    };
    
    return token;
}

2.3.4 Identifier and Keyword Lexing

static Token lex_identifier(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    SourceLoc start_loc = get_current_location(lexer);
    size_t start = lexer->current;
    
    // First character already verified to be valid
    while (is_ident_char(peek(lexer))) {
        advance(lexer);
    }
    
    size_t length = lexer->current - start;
    char *text = strndup(lexer->source + start, length);
    
    // Check if it's a keyword
    TokenType type = TOK_IDENT;
    for (size_t i = 0; i < keyword_count; i++) {
        if (strcmp(text, keywords[i].text) == 0) {
            type = keywords[i].type;
            break;
        }
    }
    
    Token token = {
        .type = type,
        .text = text,
        .length = length,
        .location = start_loc
    };
    
    return token;
}

static const struct {
    const char *text;
    TokenType type;
} keywords[] = {
    {"def", TOK_DEF},
    {"if", TOK_IF},
    {"else", TOK_ELSE},
    {"elif", TOK_ELIF},
    {"while", TOK_WHILE},
    {"for", TOK_FOR},
    {"in", TOK_IN},
    {"return", TOK_RETURN},
    {"break", TOK_BREAK},
    {"continue", TOK_CONTINUE},
    {"class", TOK_CLASS},
    {"import", TOK_IMPORT},
    {"from", TOK_FROM},
    {"as", TOK_AS},
    {"try", TOK_TRY},
    {"except", TOK_EXCEPT},
    {"finally", TOK_FINALLY},
    {"raise", TOK_RAISE},
    {"lambda", TOK_LAMBDA},
    {"yield", TOK_YIELD},
    {"assert", TOK_ASSERT},
    {"True", TOK_TRUE},
    {"False", TOK_FALSE},
    {"None", TOK_NULL},
    {"and", TOK_AND},
    {"or", TOK_OR},
    {"not", TOK_NOT},
    {"global", TOK_GLOBAL},
    {"nonlocal", TOK_NONLOCAL}
};
static const size_t keyword_count = sizeof(keywords) / sizeof(keywords[0]);

2.3.5 Indentation Handling

Python-style indentation is crucial for Diyrbal:

static void handle_indentation(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    if (lexer->column != 1) {
        return;  // Not at start of line
    }
    
    size_t indent = 0;
    while (peek(lexer) == ' ') {
        advance(lexer);
        indent++;
    }
    
    if (peek(lexer) == '\t') {
        error(lexer, "Tabs not allowed for indentation");
        return;
    }
    
    if (peek(lexer) == '\n' || peek(lexer) == '#') {
        return;  // Blank line or comment-only line
    }
    
    int current_indent = lexer->indent_stack[lexer->indent_level - 1];
    
    if (indent > current_indent) {
        // Indent
        if (lexer->indent_level >= lexer->indent_capacity) {
            lexer->indent_capacity *= 2;
            lexer->indent_stack = realloc(lexer->indent_stack,
                sizeof(int) * lexer->indent_capacity);
        }
        lexer->indent_stack[lexer->indent_level++] = indent;
        add_token(lexer, TOK_INDENT);
    } else if (indent < current_indent) {
        // Dedent (possibly multiple levels)
        while (lexer->indent_level > 0 && 
               lexer->indent_stack[lexer->indent_level - 1] > indent) {
            lexer->indent_level--;
            add_token(lexer, TOK_DEDENT);
        }
        
        if (lexer->indent_stack[lexer->indent_level - 1] != indent) {
            error(lexer, "Inconsistent indentation");
        }
    }
}

2.3.6 Main Lexing Loop

Token dyr_lexer_next_token(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    // Check token buffer first
    if (lexer->buffer_size > 0) {
        return lexer->token_buffer[--lexer->buffer_size];
    }
    
    skip_whitespace(lexer);
    
    // Handle indentation at start of line
    handle_indentation(lexer);
    
    SourceLoc start_loc = get_current_location(lexer);
    char ch = peek(lexer);
    
    // End of file
    if (ch == '\0') {
        // Emit remaining dedents
        while (lexer->indent_level > 1) {
            lexer->indent_level--;
            add_token(lexer, TOK_DEDENT);
        }
        return make_token(TOK_EOF, "", start_loc);
    }
    
    // Newline
    if (ch == '\n') {
        advance(lexer);
        return make_token(TOK_NEWLINE, "\\n", start_loc);
    }
    
    // Numbers
    if (is_digit(ch)) {
        return lex_number(lexer);
    }
    
    // Strings
    if (ch == '"' || ch == '\'') {
        return lex_string(lexer);
    }
    
    // Identifiers
    if (is_ident_start(ch)) {
        return lex_identifier(lexer);
    }
    
    // Operators and punctuation
    advance(lexer);
    switch (ch) {
        case '+':
            if (peek(lexer) == '=') {
                advance(lexer);
                return make_token(TOK_PLUS_ASSIGN, "+=", start_loc);
            }
            return make_token(TOK_PLUS, "+", start_loc);
            
        case '-':
            if (peek(lexer) == '=') {
                advance(lexer);
                return make_token(TOK_MINUS_ASSIGN, "-=", start_loc);
            } else if (peek(lexer) == '>') {
                advance(lexer);
                return make_token(TOK_ARROW, "->", start_loc);
            }
            return make_token(TOK_MINUS, "-", start_loc);
            
        case '*':
            if (peek(lexer) == '=') {
                advance(lexer);
                return make_token(TOK_STAR_ASSIGN, "*=", start_loc);
            } else if (peek(lexer) == '*') {
                advance(lexer);
                if (peek(lexer) == '=') {
                    advance(lexer);
                    return make_token(TOK_POWER_ASSIGN, "**=", start_loc);
                }
                return make_token(TOK_POWER, "**", start_loc);
            }
            return make_token(TOK_STAR, "*", start_loc);
            
        case '/':
            if (peek(lexer) == '=') {
                advance(lexer);
                return make_token(TOK_SLASH_ASSIGN, "/=", start_loc);
            } else if (peek(lexer) == '/') {
                advance(lexer);
                if (peek(lexer) == '=') {
                    advance(lexer);
                    return make_token(TOK_FLOOR_ASSIGN, "//=", start_loc);
                }
                return make_token(TOK_FLOOR_DIV, "//", start_loc);
            }
            return make_token(TOK_SLASH, "/", start_loc);
            
        // ... more operators ...
        
        case '(': return make_token(TOK_LPAREN, "(", start_loc);
        case ')': return make_token(TOK_RPAREN, ")", start_loc);
        case '[': return make_token(TOK_LBRACKET, "[", start_loc);
        case ']': return make_token(TOK_RBRACKET, "]", start_loc);
        case '{': return make_token(TOK_LBRACE, "{", start_loc);
        case '}': return make_token(TOK_RBRACE, "}", start_loc);
        case ',': return make_token(TOK_COMMA, ",", start_loc);
        case '.': return make_token(TOK_DOT, ".", start_loc);
        case ':': return make_token(TOK_COLON, ":", start_loc);
        case ';': return make_token(TOK_SEMICOLON, ";", start_loc);
        
        default:
            return make_error_token(lexer, "Unexpected character");
    }
}

2.4 Parser Implementation

The parser uses recursive descent to build an AST from the token stream:

typedef struct {
    DyrLexer   *lexer;
    Token       current;
    Token       previous;
    ErrorList  *errors;
    bool        panic_mode;
    bool        had_error;
    
    // For better error messages
    const char *current_function;
    int         loop_depth;
} DyrParser;

DyrParser* dyr_parser_new(DyrLexer *lexer) {
    DyrParser *parser = calloc(1, sizeof(DyrParser));
    parser->lexer = lexer;
    parser->errors = error_list_new();
    parser->current = dyr_lexer_next_token(lexer);
    return parser;
}

2.4.1 AST Node Definitions

typedef enum {
    // Literals
    AST_INT_LITERAL,
    AST_FLOAT_LITERAL,
    AST_STRING_LITERAL,
    AST_BOOL_LITERAL,
    AST_NULL_LITERAL,
    
    // Expressions
    AST_IDENTIFIER,
    AST_BINARY_OP,
    AST_UNARY_OP,
    AST_CALL,
    AST_INDEX,
    AST_MEMBER,
    AST_ARRAY_LITERAL,
    AST_DICT_LITERAL,
    AST_LAMBDA,
    
    // Statements
    AST_ASSIGN,
    AST_AUG_ASSIGN,
    AST_IF,
    AST_WHILE,
    AST_FOR,
    AST_BREAK,
    AST_CONTINUE,
    AST_RETURN,
    AST_YIELD,
    AST_RAISE,
    AST_TRY,
    AST_IMPORT,
    AST_EXPR_STMT,
    
    // Declarations
    AST_FUNCTION,
    AST_CLASS,
    AST_VAR_DECL,
    
    // Other
    AST_BLOCK,
    AST_PROGRAM,
    AST_PARAMETER
} ASTNodeType;

typedef struct ASTNode {
    ASTNodeType   type;
    SourceLoc     location;
    
    // Type information (filled during semantic analysis)
    Type         *expr_type;
    
    // Node-specific data
    union {
        // Literals
        struct {
            int64_t value;
        } int_literal;
        
        struct {
            double value;
        } float_literal;
        
        struct {
            char *value;
        } string_literal;
        
        struct {
            bool value;
        } bool_literal;
        
        // Identifier
        struct {
            char *name;
            Symbol *symbol;  // Filled during semantic analysis
        } identifier;
        
        // Binary operation
        struct {
            TokenType op;
            struct ASTNode *left;
            struct ASTNode *right;
        } binary_op;
        
        // Unary operation
        struct {
            TokenType op;
            struct ASTNode *operand;
        } unary_op;
        
        // Function call
        struct {
            struct ASTNode *callee;
            struct ASTNode **args;
            size_t arg_count;
        } call;
        
        // Function definition
        struct {
            char *name;
            struct ASTNode **params;
            size_t param_count;
            struct ASTNode *body;
            Type *return_type;  // Optional type annotation
        } function;
        
        // If statement
        struct {
            struct ASTNode *condition;
            struct ASTNode *then_branch;
            struct ASTNode *else_branch;  // May be NULL
        } if_stmt;
        
        // Block
        struct {
            struct ASTNode **statements;
            size_t stmt_count;
        } block;
        
        // ... more node types ...
    } data;
} ASTNode;

2.4.2 Parser Utilities

static void advance(DyrParser *parser) {
    parser->previous = parser->current;
    
    while (1) {
        parser->current = dyr_lexer_next_token(parser->lexer);
        if (parser->current.type != TOK_ERROR) {
            break;
        }
        
        error_at_current(parser, parser->current.text);
    }
}

static bool check(DyrParser *parser, TokenType type) {
    return parser->current.type == type;
}

static bool match(DyrParser *parser, TokenType type) {
    if (!check(parser, type)) {
        return false;
    }
    advance(parser);
    return true;
}

static void consume(DyrParser *parser, TokenType type, const char *message) {
    if (parser->current.type == type) {
        advance(parser);
        return;
    }
    
    error_at_current(parser, message);
}

static void synchronize(DyrParser *parser) {
    parser->panic_mode = false;
    
    while (parser->current.type != TOK_EOF) {
        if (parser->previous.type == TOK_SEMICOLON) return;
        
        switch (parser->current.type) {
            case TOK_CLASS:
            case TOK_DEF:
            case TOK_FOR:
            case TOK_IF:
            case TOK_WHILE:
            case TOK_RETURN:
                return;
            default:
                ; // Continue
        }
        
        advance(parser);
    }
}

2.4.3 Expression Parsing

We use Pratt parsing (operator precedence parsing) for expressions:

typedef enum {
    PREC_NONE,
    PREC_ASSIGNMENT,  // =
    PREC_OR,          // or
    PREC_AND,         // and
    PREC_NOT,         // not
    PREC_EQUALITY,    // == !=
    PREC_COMPARISON,  // < > <= >=
    PREC_BITOR,       // |
    PREC_BITXOR,     // ^
    PREC_BITAND,     // &
    PREC_SHIFT,       // << >>
    PREC_TERM,        // + -
    PREC_FACTOR,      // * / % //
    PREC_UNARY,       // - + ~ not
    PREC_POWER,       // **
    PREC_CALL,        // () [] .
    PREC_PRIMARY
} Precedence;

typedef ASTNode* (*ParseFn)(DyrParser*, bool);

typedef struct {
    ParseFn prefix;
    ParseFn infix;
    Precedence precedence;
} ParseRule;

static ASTNode* expression(DyrParser *parser);
static ASTNode* parse_precedence(DyrParser *parser, Precedence precedence);

// Parse rule table
static ParseRule rules[] = {
    [TOK_LPAREN]    = {grouping, call,   PREC_CALL},
    [TOK_MINUS]     = {unary,    binary, PREC_TERM},
    [TOK_PLUS]      = {NULL,     binary, PREC_TERM},
    [TOK_STAR]      = {NULL,     binary, PREC_FACTOR},
    [TOK_SLASH]     = {NULL,     binary, PREC_FACTOR},
    [TOK_PERCENT]   = {NULL,     binary, PREC_FACTOR},
    [TOK_POWER]     = {NULL,     binary, PREC_POWER},
    [TOK_INT]       = {number,   NULL,   PREC_NONE},
    [TOK_FLOAT]     = {number,   NULL,   PREC_NONE},
    [TOK_STRING]    = {string,   NULL,   PREC_NONE},
    [TOK_TRUE]      = {literal,  NULL,   PREC_NONE},
    [TOK_FALSE]     = {literal,  NULL,   PREC_NONE},
    [TOK_NULL]      = {literal,  NULL,   PREC_NONE},
    [TOK_IDENT]     = {variable, NULL,   PREC_NONE},
    [TOK_EQ]        = {NULL,     binary, PREC_EQUALITY},
    [TOK_NE]        = {NULL,     binary, PREC_EQUALITY},
    [TOK_LT]        = {NULL,     binary, PREC_COMPARISON},
    [TOK_GT]        = {NULL,     binary, PREC_COMPARISON},
    [TOK_LE]        = {NULL,     binary, PREC_COMPARISON},
    [TOK_GE]        = {NULL,     binary, PREC_COMPARISON},
    [TOK_AND]       = {NULL,     and_,   PREC_AND},
    [TOK_OR]        = {NULL,     or_,    PREC_OR},
    [TOK_NOT]       = {unary,    NULL,   PREC_NOT},
    [TOK_DOT]       = {NULL,     dot,    PREC_CALL},
    [TOK_LBRACKET]  = {array,    index,  PREC_CALL},
    // ... more rules ...
};

static ParseRule* get_rule(TokenType type) {
    return &rules[type];
}

static ASTNode* parse_precedence(DyrParser *parser, Precedence precedence) {
    advance(parser);
    ParseFn prefix_rule = get_rule(parser->previous.type)->prefix;
    if (prefix_rule == NULL) {
        error(parser, "Expected expression");
        return NULL;
    }
    
    bool can_assign = precedence <= PREC_ASSIGNMENT;
    ASTNode *expr = prefix_rule(parser, can_assign);
    
    while (precedence <= get_rule(parser->current.type)->precedence) {
        advance(parser);
        ParseFn infix_rule = get_rule(parser->previous.type)->infix;
        expr = infix_rule(parser, can_assign, expr);
    }
    
    if (can_assign && match(parser, TOK_ASSIGN)) {
        error(parser, "Invalid assignment target");
    }
    
    return expr;
}

static ASTNode* expression(DyrParser *parser) {
    return parse_precedence(parser, PREC_ASSIGNMENT);
}

// Parsing functions for specific constructs
static ASTNode* number(DyrParser *parser, bool can_assign) {
    (void)can_assign;
    
    ASTNode *node = ast_node_new(
        parser->previous.type == TOK_INT ? AST_INT_LITERAL : AST_FLOAT_LITERAL,
        parser->previous.location
    );
    
    if (parser->previous.type == TOK_INT) {
        node->data.int_literal.value = parser->previous.value.int_value;
    } else {
        node->data.float_literal.value = parser->previous.value.float_value;
    }
    
    return node;
}

static ASTNode* binary(DyrParser *parser, bool can_assign, ASTNode *left) {
    (void)can_assign;
    
    TokenType op_type = parser->previous.type;
    ParseRule *rule = get_rule(op_type);
    ASTNode *right = parse_precedence(parser, rule->precedence + 1);
    
    ASTNode *node = ast_node_new(AST_BINARY_OP, parser->previous.location);
    node->data.binary_op.op = op_type;
    node->data.binary_op.left = left;
    node->data.binary_op.right = right;
    
    return node;
}

2.4.4 Statement Parsing

static ASTNode* statement(DyrParser *parser) {
    // Skip newlines at statement level
    while (match(parser, TOK_NEWLINE)) {
        // Empty
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_DEF)) {
        return function_declaration(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_CLASS)) {
        return class_declaration(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_IF)) {
        return if_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_WHILE)) {
        return while_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_FOR)) {
        return for_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_RETURN)) {
        return return_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_BREAK)) {
        return break_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_CONTINUE)) {
        return continue_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_TRY)) {
        return try_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_RAISE)) {
        return raise_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_IMPORT)) {
        return import_statement(parser);
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_FROM)) {
        return from_import_statement(parser);
    }
    
    return expression_statement(parser);
}

static ASTNode* function_declaration(DyrParser *parser) {
    consume(parser, TOK_IDENT, "Expected function name");
    char *name = strdup(parser->previous.text);
    parser->current_function = name;
    
    consume(parser, TOK_LPAREN, "Expected '(' after function name");
    
    // Parameters
    ASTNode **params = NULL;
    size_t param_count = 0;
    size_t param_capacity = 0;
    
    if (!check(parser, TOK_RPAREN)) {
        do {
            if (param_count >= param_capacity) {
                param_capacity = param_capacity == 0 ? 8 : param_capacity * 2;
                params = realloc(params, sizeof(ASTNode*) * param_capacity);
            }
            
            consume(parser, TOK_IDENT, "Expected parameter name");
            ASTNode *param = ast_node_new(AST_PARAMETER, parser->previous.location);
            param->data.identifier.name = strdup(parser->previous.text);
            
            // Optional type annotation
            if (match(parser, TOK_COLON)) {
                // Parse type annotation (simplified for now)
                advance(parser);
            }
            
            params[param_count++] = param;
        } while (match(parser, TOK_COMMA));
    }
    
    consume(parser, TOK_RPAREN, "Expected ')' after parameters");
    
    // Optional return type annotation
    if (match(parser, TOK_ARROW)) {
        // Parse return type
        advance(parser);
    }
    
    consume(parser, TOK_COLON, "Expected ':' after function signature");
    consume(parser, TOK_NEWLINE, "Expected newline after ':'");
    
    // Function body
    ASTNode *body = block(parser);
    
    parser->current_function = NULL;
    
    ASTNode *node = ast_node_new(AST_FUNCTION, parser->previous.location);
    node->data.function.name = name;
    node->data.function.params = params;
    node->data.function.param_count = param_count;
    node->data.function.body = body;
    
    return node;
}

static ASTNode* if_statement(DyrParser *parser) {
    ASTNode *condition = expression(parser);
    consume(parser, TOK_COLON, "Expected ':' after if condition");
    consume(parser, TOK_NEWLINE, "Expected newline after ':'");
    
    ASTNode *then_branch = block(parser);
    ASTNode *else_branch = NULL;
    
    // Handle elif/else
    while (match(parser, TOK_ELIF)) {
        ASTNode *elif_condition = expression(parser);
        consume(parser, TOK_COLON, "Expected ':' after elif condition");
        consume(parser, TOK_NEWLINE, "Expected newline after ':'");
        
        ASTNode *elif_body = block(parser);
        
        // Create nested if for elif
        ASTNode *elif_node = ast_node_new(AST_IF, parser->previous.location);
        elif_node->data.if_stmt.condition = elif_condition;
        elif_node->data.if_stmt.then_branch = elif_body;
        elif_node->data.if_stmt.else_branch = NULL;
        
        if (else_branch == NULL) {
            else_branch = elif_node;
        } else {
            // Find the last else branch and attach
            ASTNode *current = else_branch;
            while (current->data.if_stmt.else_branch != NULL) {
                current = current->data.if_stmt.else_branch;
            }
            current->data.if_stmt.else_branch = elif_node;
        }
    }
    
    if (match(parser, TOK_ELSE)) {
        consume(parser, TOK_COLON, "Expected ':' after else");
        consume(parser, TOK_NEWLINE, "Expected newline after ':'");
        
        ASTNode *else_body = block(parser);
        
        if (else_branch == NULL) {
            else_branch = else_body;
        } else {
            // Attach to last elif
            ASTNode *current = else_branch;
            while (current->type == AST_IF && 
                   current->data.if_stmt.else_branch != NULL) {
                current = current->data.if_stmt.else_branch;
            }
            current->data.if_stmt.else_branch = else_body;
        }
    }
    
    ASTNode *node = ast_node_new(AST_IF, parser->previous.location);
    node->data.if_stmt.condition = condition;
    node->data.if_stmt.then_branch = then_branch;
    node->data.if_stmt.else_branch = else_branch;
    
    return node;
}

2.4.5 Block Parsing with Indentation

static ASTNode* block(DyrParser *parser) {
    // Expect INDENT token
    consume(parser, TOK_INDENT, "Expected indented block");
    
    ASTNode **stmts = NULL;
    size_t stmt_count = 0;
    size_t stmt_capacity = 0;
    
    while (!check(parser, TOK_DEDENT) && !check(parser, TOK_EOF)) {
        if (stmt_count >= stmt_capacity) {
            stmt_capacity = stmt_capacity == 0 ? 8 : stmt_capacity * 2;
            stmts = realloc(stmts, sizeof(ASTNode*) * stmt_capacity);
        }
        
        ASTNode *stmt = statement(parser);
        if (stmt != NULL) {
            stmts[stmt_count++] = stmt;
        }
    }
    
    consume(parser, TOK_DEDENT, "Expected dedent after block");
    
    ASTNode *node = ast_node_new(AST_BLOCK, parser->previous.location);
    node->data.block.statements = stmts;
    node->data.block.stmt_count = stmt_count;
    
    return node;
}

2.5 Error Recovery and Reporting

Good error messages are crucial for usability:

typedef struct {
    char      *message;
    SourceLoc  location;
    ErrorType  type;
} ParseError;

typedef enum {
    ERROR_SYNTAX,
    ERROR_UNEXPECTED_TOKEN,
    ERROR_UNTERMINATED_STRING,
    ERROR_INVALID_NUMBER,
    ERROR_INDENTATION
} ErrorType;

static void error_at(DyrParser *parser, Token *token, const char *message) {
    if (parser->panic_mode) return;
    parser->panic_mode = true;
    
    fprintf(stderr, "%s:%zu:%zu: error: %s\n",
            token->location.filename,
            token->location.line,
            token->location.column,
            message);
    
    // Print source line
    print_source_line(parser->lexer->source, token->location);
    
    // Print caret pointing to error
    for (size_t i = 0; i < token->location.column - 1; i++) {
        fputc(' ', stderr);
    }
    fprintf(stderr, "^\n");
    
    parser->had_error = true;
}

static void print_source_line(const char *source, SourceLoc location) {
    // Find start of line
    size_t line_start = location.offset;
    while (line_start > 0 && source[line_start - 1] != '\n') {
        line_start--;
    }
    
    // Find end of line
    size_t line_end = location.offset;
    while (source[line_end] != '\0' && source[line_end] != '\n') {
        line_end++;
    }
    
    // Print line
    fprintf(stderr, "  ");
    for (size_t i = line_start; i < line_end; i++) {
        fputc(source[i], stderr);
    }
    fprintf(stderr, "\n  ");
}

2.5.1 Common Error Patterns

static void error_expected_expression(DyrParser *parser) {
    switch (parser->current.type) {
        case TOK_SEMICOLON:
            error_at_current(parser, "Expected expression before ';'");
            break;
        case TOK_RPAREN:
            error_at_current(parser, "Expected expression before ')'");
            break;
        case TOK_RBRACKET:
            error_at_current(parser, "Expected expression before ']'");
            break;
        default:
            error_at_current(parser, "Expected expression");
    }
}

static void suggest_fix(DyrParser *parser, const char *suggestion) {
    fprintf(stderr, "  note: %s\n", suggestion);
}

2.6 Source Location Tracking

Precise source location tracking enables good error messages and debugging:

typedef struct {
    const char *filename;
    size_t      line_start;
    size_t      line_end;
    size_t      col_start;
    size_t      col_end;
    size_t      offset_start;
    size_t      offset_end;
} SourceRange;

static SourceRange merge_locations(SourceLoc start, SourceLoc end) {
    return (SourceRange){
        .filename = start.filename,
        .line_start = start.line,
        .line_end = end.line,
        .col_start = start.column,
        .col_end = end.column,
        .offset_start = start.offset,
        .offset_end = end.offset
    };
}

// Attach location info to AST nodes
static void ast_set_range(ASTNode *node, SourceRange range) {
    node->location = range.offset_start;  // Store start for compatibility
    node->source_range = range;           // Store full range
}

2.7 String Interning

String interning improves memory usage and comparison performance:

typedef struct StringEntry {
    char   *string;
    size_t  length;
    uint32_t hash;
    struct StringEntry *next;
} StringEntry;

typedef struct {
    StringEntry **buckets;
    size_t        capacity;
    size_t        count;
} StringTable;

static uint32_t hash_string(const char *str, size_t length) {
    // FNV-1a hash
    uint32_t hash = 2166136261u;
    for (size_t i = 0; i < length; i++) {
        hash ^= (uint8_t)str[i];
        hash *= 16777619;
    }
    return hash;
}

const char* string_table_intern(StringTable *table, const char *str, size_t length) {
    uint32_t hash = hash_string(str, length);
    size_t index = hash & (table->capacity - 1);
    
    // Search for existing string
    StringEntry *entry = table->buckets[index];
    while (entry != NULL) {
        if (entry->length == length && 
            entry->hash == hash &&
            memcmp(entry->string, str, length) == 0) {
            return entry->string;
        }
        entry = entry->next;
    }
    
    // Create new entry
    entry = malloc(sizeof(StringEntry));
    entry->string = malloc(length + 1);
    memcpy(entry->string, str, length);
    entry->string[length] = '\0';
    entry->length = length;
    entry->hash = hash;
    entry->next = table->buckets[index];
    table->buckets[index] = entry;
    table->count++;
    
    // Resize if necessary
    if (table->count > table->capacity * 0.75) {
        string_table_resize(table);
    }
    
    return entry->string;
}

2.8 Integration with the Compiler Pipeline

The parser produces an AST that subsequent phases can traverse:

ASTNode* dyr_parse(const char *source, const char *filename) {
    DyrLexer *lexer = dyr_lexer_new(source, strlen(source), filename);
    DyrParser *parser = dyr_parser_new(lexer);
    
    ASTNode *program = ast_node_new(AST_PROGRAM, (SourceLoc){filename, 1, 1, 0});
    
    // Parse top-level statements
    ASTNode **stmts = NULL;
    size_t stmt_count = 0;
    size_t stmt_capacity = 0;
    
    while (!check(parser, TOK_EOF)) {
        // Skip blank lines at top level
        if (match(parser, TOK_NEWLINE)) {
            continue;
        }
        
        if (stmt_count >= stmt_capacity) {
            stmt_capacity = stmt_capacity == 0 ? 16 : stmt_capacity * 2;
            stmts = realloc(stmts, sizeof(ASTNode*) * stmt_capacity);
        }
        
        ASTNode *stmt = statement(parser);
        if (stmt != NULL) {
            stmts[stmt_count++] = stmt;
        }
        
        if (parser->panic_mode) {
            synchronize(parser);
        }
    }
    
    program->data.block.statements = stmts;
    program->data.block.stmt_count = stmt_count;
    
    dyr_parser_free(parser);
    dyr_lexer_free(lexer);
    
    return parser->had_error ? NULL : program;
}

2.9 Performance Optimizations

Several techniques improve lexer and parser performance:

2.9.1 Token Buffering

// Buffer tokens for lookahead without re-lexing
void lexer_buffer_token(DyrLexer *lexer, Token token) {
    if (lexer->buffer_size >= lexer->buffer_capacity) {
        lexer->buffer_capacity *= 2;
        lexer->token_buffer = realloc(lexer->token_buffer,
            sizeof(Token) * lexer->buffer_capacity);
    }
    lexer->token_buffer[lexer->buffer_size++] = token;
}

Token lexer_peek_ahead(DyrLexer *lexer, size_t n) {
    while (lexer->buffer_size <= n) {
        Token tok = lex_token_internal(lexer);
        lexer_buffer_token(lexer, tok);
    }
    return lexer->token_buffer[lexer->buffer_size - n - 1];
}

2.9.2 Keyword Perfect Hashing

// Generated perfect hash function for keywords
static int keyword_hash(const char *str, size_t len) {
    if (len < 2 || len > 8) return -1;
    
    // Minimal perfect hash for Diyrbal keywords
    unsigned h = len;
    h ^= str[0] - 'a';
    h ^= (str[len-1] - 'a') << 4;
    
    return h % KEYWORD_TABLE_SIZE;
}

static TokenType lookup_keyword(const char *str, size_t len) {
    int index = keyword_hash(str, len);
    if (index < 0) return TOK_IDENT;
    
    const KeywordEntry *entry = &keyword_table[index];
    if (entry->length == len && memcmp(entry->text, str, len) == 0) {
        return entry->type;
    }
    
    return TOK_IDENT;
}

2.10 Summary

The lexer and parser form the foundation of Diyrbal's implementation. By carefully handling indentation, providing excellent error messages, and building a clean AST representation, we set the stage for successful compilation. The use of string interning, efficient keyword lookup, and careful memory management ensures good performance even for large source files.

Key takeaways:

  • Hand-written lexers and parsers provide flexibility and control
  • Indentation-based syntax requires careful state management
  • Good error messages require tracking source locations precisely
  • String interning saves memory and speeds up comparisons
  • Recursive descent parsing with Pratt parsing for expressions is simple and efficient

The next chapter will explore how we perform semantic analysis on the AST, including type checking and symbol resolution.

2.11 Exercises

  1. Extend the lexer to support raw strings (r"...") and bytes literals (b"...").

  2. Implement Unicode support in the lexer, handling UTF-8 encoded source files correctly.

  3. Add support for nested comments (/* ... /* ... */ ... */) to the lexer.

  4. Implement a pretty-printer that takes an AST and outputs formatted Diyrbal source code.

  5. Design and implement error recovery for common syntax errors like missing colons after if statements.

  6. Profile the lexer and parser on a large source file. Identify bottlenecks and optimize them.

  7. Implement incremental lexing that can efficiently re-lex only changed portions of a file.

Chapter 3: Semantic Analysis and Type System

3.1 Introduction

After parsing produces an Abstract Syntax Tree, semantic analysis transforms this syntactic representation into a semantically valid program. This phase performs crucial validations and transformations:

  • Name Resolution: Binding identifiers to their declarations
  • Type Checking: Ensuring type safety throughout the program
  • Constant Folding: Evaluating compile-time constants
  • Semantic Validation: Checking language-specific rules (e.g., return statements in functions)

Diyrbal employs a gradual type system that combines the flexibility of dynamic typing with the safety of static typing where desired. This chapter details the implementation of semantic analysis, focusing on practical techniques for building a robust type checker.

3.2 Type System Design

Diyrbal's type system supports both primitive and composite types:

typedef enum {
    TYPE_UNKNOWN,
    TYPE_ANY,
    TYPE_VOID,
    TYPE_NULL,
    TYPE_BOOL,
    TYPE_INT,
    TYPE_FLOAT,
    TYPE_STRING,
    TYPE_ARRAY,
    TYPE_DICT,
    TYPE_FUNCTION,
    TYPE_CLASS,
    TYPE_INSTANCE,
    TYPE_MODULE,
    TYPE_UNION,
    TYPE_GENERIC,
    TYPE_ERROR
} TypeKind;

typedef struct Type {
    TypeKind kind;
    union {
        // Array type
        struct {
            struct Type *element_type;
        } array;
        
        // Dictionary type
        struct {
            struct Type *key_type;
            struct Type *value_type;
        } dict;
        
        // Function type
        struct {
            struct Type **param_types;
            size_t param_count;
            struct Type *return_type;
            bool is_varargs;
        } function;
        
        // Class type
        struct {
            char *name;
            struct ClassDef *class_def;
            struct Type *base_type;
        } class;
        
        // Instance type
        struct {
            struct Type *class_type;
        } instance;
        
        // Union type (for gradual typing)
        struct {
            struct Type **types;
            size_t type_count;
        } union_type;
        
        // Generic type parameter
        struct {
            char *name;
            size_t id;
            struct Type *constraint;
        } generic;
    } data;
    
    // Type flags
    bool is_nullable;
    bool is_mutable;
} Type;

3.2.1 Type Creation and Interning

Types are interned to save memory and enable fast comparison:

typedef struct TypeTable {
    Type **buckets;
    size_t capacity;
    size_t count;
    
    // Preallocated common types
    Type *type_any;
    Type *type_void;
    Type *type_null;
    Type *type_bool;
    Type *type_int;
    Type *type_float;
    Type *type_string;
} TypeTable;

static TypeTable *global_type_table;

void init_type_system(void) {
    global_type_table = calloc(1, sizeof(TypeTable));
    global_type_table->capacity = 256;
    global_type_table->buckets = calloc(256, sizeof(Type*));
    
    // Create primitive types
    global_type_table->type_any = make_primitive_type(TYPE_ANY);
    global_type_table->type_void = make_primitive_type(TYPE_VOID);
    global_type_table->type_null = make_primitive_type(TYPE_NULL);
    global_type_table->type_bool = make_primitive_type(TYPE_BOOL);
    global_type_table->type_int = make_primitive_type(TYPE_INT);
    global_type_table->type_float = make_primitive_type(TYPE_FLOAT);
    global_type_table->type_string = make_primitive_type(TYPE_STRING);
}

Type* type_intern(Type *type) {
    uint32_t hash = hash_type(type);
    size_t index = hash & (global_type_table->capacity - 1);
    
    // Search for existing type
    Type *existing = global_type_table->buckets[index];
    while (existing) {
        if (types_equal(existing, type)) {
            return existing;
        }
        existing = existing->next;
    }
    
    // Add new type
    type->next = global_type_table->buckets[index];
    global_type_table->buckets[index] = type;
    global_type_table->count++;
    
    // Resize if necessary
    if (global_type_table->count > global_type_table->capacity * 0.75) {
        resize_type_table();
    }
    
    return type;
}

3.3 Symbol Tables and Scoping

Symbol tables track variable bindings and their types:

typedef enum {
    SYMBOL_VARIABLE,
    SYMBOL_FUNCTION,
    SYMBOL_CLASS,
    SYMBOL_MODULE,
    SYMBOL_PARAMETER,
    SYMBOL_TYPE_PARAM
} SymbolKind;

typedef struct Symbol {
    char *name;
    SymbolKind kind;
    Type *type;
    
    // Symbol flags
    bool is_global;
    bool is_nonlocal;
    bool is_constant;
    bool is_initialized;
    
    // Definition location
    SourceLoc location;
    
    // Scope information
    size_t scope_level;
    size_t declaration_order;
    
    // Storage information (for code generation)
    union {
        size_t local_index;
        size_t global_index;
    } storage;
} Symbol;

typedef struct Scope {
    struct Scope *parent;
    HashTable *symbols;
    ScopeKind kind;
    size_t level;
    
    // For function scopes
    Type *return_type;
    bool has_return;
    
    // For loop scopes
    bool in_loop;
    
    // For class scopes
    Type *class_type;
} Scope;

typedef enum {
    SCOPE_GLOBAL,
    SCOPE_FUNCTION,
    SCOPE_CLASS,
    SCOPE_BLOCK,
    SCOPE_LOOP
} ScopeKind;

typedef struct {
    Scope *current;
    Scope *global;
    ErrorList *errors;
    
    // Type inference state
    TypeConstraints *constraints;
    
    // Current function being analyzed
    Symbol *current_function;
    
    // Current class being analyzed
    Symbol *current_class;
} SemanticAnalyzer;

3.3.1 Scope Management

static Scope* push_scope(SemanticAnalyzer *analyzer, ScopeKind kind) {
    Scope *scope = calloc(1, sizeof(Scope));
    scope->parent = analyzer->current;
    scope->symbols = hash_table_new();
    scope->kind = kind;
    scope->level = analyzer->current ? analyzer->current->level + 1 : 0;
    
    if (analyzer->current) {
        scope->in_loop = analyzer->current->in_loop;
        scope->class_type = analyzer->current->class_type;
    }
    
    analyzer->current = scope;
    return scope;
}

static void pop_scope(SemanticAnalyzer *analyzer) {
    analyzer->current = analyzer->current->parent;
}

static Symbol* define_symbol(SemanticAnalyzer *analyzer, const char *name, 
                           SymbolKind kind, Type *type, SourceLoc loc) {
    // Check for redefinition in current scope
    if (hash_table_get(analyzer->current->symbols, name)) {
        semantic_error(analyzer, loc, 
            "Variable '%s' already defined in this scope", name);
        return NULL;
    }
    
    Symbol *symbol = calloc(1, sizeof(Symbol));
    symbol->name = strdup(name);
    symbol->kind = kind;
    symbol->type = type;
    symbol->location = loc;
    symbol->scope_level = analyzer->current->level;
    symbol->is_global = analyzer->current->kind == SCOPE_GLOBAL;
    
    hash_table_put(analyzer->current->symbols, name, symbol);
    return symbol;
}

static Symbol* resolve_symbol(SemanticAnalyzer *analyzer, const char *name) {
    Scope *scope = analyzer->current;
    
    while (scope) {
        Symbol *symbol = hash_table_get(scope->symbols, name);
        if (symbol) {
            return symbol;
        }
        scope = scope->parent;
    }
    
    return NULL;
}

3.4 Type Checking Implementation

The type checker traverses the AST, assigning types to expressions and validating type consistency:

typedef struct {
    SemanticAnalyzer *analyzer;
    Type *expected_type;  // For bidirectional type checking
} TypeChecker;

static Type* check_expr(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *expr);
static void check_stmt(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *stmt);

ASTNode* analyze_ast(ASTNode *ast) {
    SemanticAnalyzer analyzer = {0};
    analyzer.global = push_scope(&analyzer, SCOPE_GLOBAL);
    analyzer.errors = error_list_new();
    analyzer.constraints = constraint_set_new();
    
    // Define built-in functions
    define_builtins(&analyzer);
    
    TypeChecker tc = {
        .analyzer = &analyzer,
        .expected_type = NULL
    };
    
    // Analyze program
    check_stmt(&tc, ast);
    
    // Solve type constraints for inference
    solve_constraints(analyzer.constraints);
    
    if (analyzer.errors->count > 0) {
        report_errors(analyzer.errors);
        return NULL;
    }
    
    return ast;
}

3.4.1 Expression Type Checking

static Type* check_expr(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *expr) {
    switch (expr->type) {
        case AST_INT_LITERAL:
            expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_int;
            return expr->expr_type;
            
        case AST_FLOAT_LITERAL:
            expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_float;
            return expr->expr_type;
            
        case AST_STRING_LITERAL:
            expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_string;
            return expr->expr_type;
            
        case AST_BOOL_LITERAL:
            expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_bool;
            return expr->expr_type;
            
        case AST_NULL_LITERAL:
            expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_null;
            return expr->expr_type;
            
        case AST_IDENTIFIER:
            return check_identifier(tc, expr);
            
        case AST_BINARY_OP:
            return check_binary_op(tc, expr);
            
        case AST_UNARY_OP:
            return check_unary_op(tc, expr);
            
        case AST_CALL:
            return check_call(tc, expr);
            
        case AST_INDEX:
            return check_index(tc, expr);
            
        case AST_MEMBER:
            return check_member_access(tc, expr);
            
        case AST_ARRAY_LITERAL:
            return check_array_literal(tc, expr);
            
        case AST_DICT_LITERAL:
            return check_dict_literal(tc, expr);
            
        case AST_LAMBDA:
            return check_lambda(tc, expr);
            
        default:
            semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location, 
                "Unknown expression type");
            return global_type_table->type_error;
    }
}

static Type* check_identifier(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *expr) {
    const char *name = expr->data.identifier.name;
    Symbol *symbol = resolve_symbol(tc->analyzer, name);
    
    if (!symbol) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
            "Undefined variable '%s'", name);
        return global_type_table->type_error;
    }
    
    // Link identifier to symbol
    expr->data.identifier.symbol = symbol;
    
    // Check initialization
    if (!symbol->is_initialized && symbol->kind == SYMBOL_VARIABLE) {
        semantic_warning(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
            "Variable '%s' may be used before initialization", name);
    }
    
    expr->expr_type = symbol->type;
    return symbol->type;
}

3.4.2 Binary Operation Type Checking

static Type* check_binary_op(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *expr) {
    Type *left_type = check_expr(tc, expr->data.binary_op.left);
    Type *right_type = check_expr(tc, expr->data.binary_op.right);
    
    TokenType op = expr->data.binary_op.op;
    
    // Handle special operators
    switch (op) {
        case TOK_AND:
        case TOK_OR:
            // Logical operators accept any type (truthiness)
            expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_bool;
            return expr->expr_type;
            
        case TOK_EQ:
        case TOK_NE:
            // Equality works on any types
            expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_bool;
            return expr->expr_type;
    }
    
    // Numeric operations
    if (is_arithmetic_op(op)) {
        Type *result_type = unify_numeric_types(left_type, right_type);
        
        if (!result_type) {
            semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
                "Invalid operand types for %s: %s and %s",
                token_to_string(op),
                type_to_string(left_type),
                type_to_string(right_type));
            return global_type_table->type_error;
        }
        
        // Comparison operators return bool
        if (is_comparison_op(op)) {
            expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_bool;
        } else {
            expr->expr_type = result_type;
        }
        
        return expr->expr_type;
    }
    
    // String concatenation
    if (op == TOK_PLUS && 
        (left_type->kind == TYPE_STRING || right_type->kind == TYPE_STRING)) {
        if (left_type->kind != TYPE_STRING || right_type->kind != TYPE_STRING) {
            semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
                "Cannot concatenate string with %s",
                left_type->kind == TYPE_STRING ? 
                    type_to_string(right_type) : type_to_string(left_type));
            return global_type_table->type_error;
        }
        expr->expr_type = global_type_table->type_string;
        return expr->expr_type;
    }
    
    semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
        "Invalid binary operation");
    return global_type_table->type_error;
}

static Type* unify_numeric_types(Type *left, Type *right) {
    // Handle any type
    if (left->kind == TYPE_ANY) return right;
    if (right->kind == TYPE_ANY) return left;
    
    // Both must be numeric
    if (!is_numeric_type(left) || !is_numeric_type(right)) {
        return NULL;
    }
    
    // Float dominates int
    if (left->kind == TYPE_FLOAT || right->kind == TYPE_FLOAT) {
        return global_type_table->type_float;
    }
    
    return global_type_table->type_int;
}

3.4.3 Function Call Type Checking

static Type* check_call(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *expr) {
    Type *callee_type = check_expr(tc, expr->data.call.callee);
    
    if (callee_type->kind != TYPE_FUNCTION) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
            "Cannot call non-function type %s", 
            type_to_string(callee_type));
        return global_type_table->type_error;
    }
    
    FunctionType *func = &callee_type->data.function;
    size_t arg_count = expr->data.call.arg_count;
    
    // Check argument count
    if (!func->is_varargs && arg_count != func->param_count) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
            "Function expects %zu arguments, got %zu",
            func->param_count, arg_count);
        return global_type_table->type_error;
    }
    
    if (func->is_varargs && arg_count < func->param_count) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
            "Function expects at least %zu arguments, got %zu",
            func->param_count, arg_count);
        return global_type_table->type_error;
    }
    
    // Check argument types
    for (size_t i = 0; i < arg_count && i < func->param_count; i++) {
        TypeChecker arg_tc = *tc;
        arg_tc.expected_type = func->param_types[i];
        
        Type *arg_type = check_expr(&arg_tc, expr->data.call.args[i]);
        
        if (!is_assignable_to(arg_type, func->param_types[i])) {
            semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->data.call.args[i]->location,
                "Argument %zu: expected %s, got %s",
                i + 1,
                type_to_string(func->param_types[i]),
                type_to_string(arg_type));
        }
    }
    
    expr->expr_type = func->return_type;
    return func->return_type;
}

3.5 Statement Analysis

static void check_stmt(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *stmt) {
    switch (stmt->type) {
        case AST_ASSIGN:
            check_assignment(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_AUG_ASSIGN:
            check_aug_assignment(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_IF:
            check_if_stmt(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_WHILE:
            check_while_stmt(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_FOR:
            check_for_stmt(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_FUNCTION:
            check_function_def(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_CLASS:
            check_class_def(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_RETURN:
            check_return_stmt(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_BREAK:
        case AST_CONTINUE:
            check_loop_control(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_BLOCK:
            check_block(tc, stmt);
            break;
            
        case AST_EXPR_STMT:
            check_expr(tc, stmt->data.expr_stmt.expr);
            break;
            
        default:
            semantic_error(tc->analyzer, stmt->location,
                "Unknown statement type");
    }
}

static void check_assignment(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *stmt) {
    ASTNode *target = stmt->data.assign.target;
    ASTNode *value = stmt->data.assign.value;
    
    // Check that target is assignable
    if (!is_lvalue(target)) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, target->location,
            "Cannot assign to non-lvalue");
        return;
    }
    
    Type *value_type = check_expr(tc, value);
    
    if (target->type == AST_IDENTIFIER) {
        const char *name = target->data.identifier.name;
        Symbol *symbol = resolve_symbol(tc->analyzer, name);
        
        if (!symbol) {
            // Create new variable in current scope
            symbol = define_symbol(tc->analyzer, name, SYMBOL_VARIABLE,
                                 value_type, target->location);
            if (symbol) {
                symbol->is_initialized = true;
                target->data.identifier.symbol = symbol;
            }
        } else {
            // Check type compatibility
            if (!is_assignable_to(value_type, symbol->type)) {
                semantic_error(tc->analyzer, stmt->location,
                    "Cannot assign %s to variable of type %s",
                    type_to_string(value_type),
                    type_to_string(symbol->type));
            }
            symbol->is_initialized = true;
        }
    } else {
        // Index or member assignment
        Type *target_type = check_expr(tc, target);
        // Additional validation for container types
    }
}

3.5.1 Control Flow Analysis

static void check_if_stmt(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *stmt) {
    // Check condition
    Type *cond_type = check_expr(tc, stmt->data.if_stmt.condition);
    
    // Any type can be used as condition (truthiness)
    
    // Check branches
    check_stmt(tc, stmt->data.if_stmt.then_branch);
    
    if (stmt->data.if_stmt.else_branch) {
        check_stmt(tc, stmt->data.if_stmt.else_branch);
    }
}

static void check_while_stmt(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *stmt) {
    Type *cond_type = check_expr(tc, stmt->data.while_stmt.condition);
    
    // Push loop scope
    Scope *loop_scope = push_scope(tc->analyzer, SCOPE_LOOP);
    loop_scope->in_loop = true;
    
    check_stmt(tc, stmt->data.while_stmt.body);
    
    pop_scope(tc->analyzer);
}

static void check_for_stmt(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *stmt) {
    // Check iterable
    Type *iter_type = check_expr(tc, stmt->data.for_stmt.iterable);
    
    if (!is_iterable_type(iter_type)) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, stmt->data.for_stmt.iterable->location,
            "Cannot iterate over type %s", type_to_string(iter_type));
        return;
    }
    
    // Push loop scope
    Scope *loop_scope = push_scope(tc->analyzer, SCOPE_LOOP);
    loop_scope->in_loop = true;
    
    // Define loop variable
    Type *element_type = get_element_type(iter_type);
    const char *var_name = stmt->data.for_stmt.variable->data.identifier.name;
    Symbol *var = define_symbol(tc->analyzer, var_name, SYMBOL_VARIABLE,
                               element_type, stmt->data.for_stmt.variable->location);
    var->is_initialized = true;
    
    check_stmt(tc, stmt->data.for_stmt.body);
    
    pop_scope(tc->analyzer);
}

3.5.2 Function Definition Analysis

static void check_function_def(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *stmt) {
    FunctionDef *func = &stmt->data.function;
    
    // Create function type
    Type *func_type = calloc(1, sizeof(Type));
    func_type->kind = TYPE_FUNCTION;
    func_type->data.function.param_count = func->param_count;
    func_type->data.function.param_types = 
        calloc(func->param_count, sizeof(Type*));
    
    // Define function symbol before analyzing body (for recursion)
    Symbol *func_symbol = define_symbol(tc->analyzer, func->name,
                                       SYMBOL_FUNCTION, func_type,
                                       stmt->location);
    
    // Push function scope
    Scope *func_scope = push_scope(tc->analyzer, SCOPE_FUNCTION);
    tc->analyzer->current_function = func_symbol;
    
    // Process parameters
    for (size_t i = 0; i < func->param_count; i++) {
        ASTNode *param = func->params[i];
        Type *param_type = global_type_table->type_any;  // Default
        
        // Check for type annotation
        if (param->data.param.type_annotation) {
            param_type = resolve_type_annotation(tc->analyzer,
                param->data.param.type_annotation);
        }
        
        func_type->data.function.param_types[i] = param_type;
        
        // Define parameter symbol
        Symbol *param_symbol = define_symbol(tc->analyzer,
            param->data.param.name, SYMBOL_PARAMETER,
            param_type, param->location);
        param_symbol->is_initialized = true;
    }
    
    // Process return type annotation
    if (func->return_type_annotation) {
        func_type->data.function.return_type = 
            resolve_type_annotation(tc->analyzer, func->return_type_annotation);
    } else {
        // Infer return type
        func_type->data.function.return_type = infer_return_type(tc, func->body);
    }
    
    func_scope->return_type = func_type->data.function.return_type;
    
    // Check function body
    check_stmt(tc, func->body);
    
    // Verify all paths return if needed
    if (func_type->data.function.return_type->kind != TYPE_VOID &&
        !func_scope->has_return) {
        semantic_warning(tc->analyzer, stmt->location,
            "Function '%s' may not return a value on all paths", func->name);
    }
    
    tc->analyzer->current_function = NULL;
    pop_scope(tc->analyzer);
}

static void check_return_stmt(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *stmt) {
    if (!tc->analyzer->current_function) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, stmt->location,
            "Return statement outside function");
        return;
    }
    
    Type *expected_type = tc->analyzer->current->return_type;
    
    if (stmt->data.return_stmt.value) {
        Type *actual_type = check_expr(tc, stmt->data.return_stmt.value);
        
        if (!is_assignable_to(actual_type, expected_type)) {
            semantic_error(tc->analyzer, stmt->location,
                "Return type mismatch: expected %s, got %s",
                type_to_string(expected_type),
                type_to_string(actual_type));
        }
    } else if (expected_type->kind != TYPE_VOID) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, stmt->location,
            "Function expects return value of type %s",
            type_to_string(expected_type));
    }
    
    tc->analyzer->current->has_return = true;
}

3.6 Type Inference

Diyrbal supports bidirectional type checking for better inference:

typedef struct {
    Type *expected;
    Type *actual;
    SourceLoc location;
} TypeConstraint;

typedef struct {
    TypeConstraint *constraints;
    size_t count;
    size_t capacity;
    
    // Type variable substitutions
    HashMap *substitutions;
} TypeConstraints;

static Type* infer_type(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *expr) {
    // Use expected type if available
    if (tc->expected_type && tc->expected_type->kind != TYPE_ANY) {
        return check_expr_against(tc, expr, tc->expected_type);
    }
    
    // Otherwise synthesize type
    return check_expr(tc, expr);
}

static Type* check_expr_against(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *expr, Type *expected) {
    switch (expr->type) {
        case AST_LAMBDA:
            return check_lambda_against(tc, expr, expected);
            
        case AST_ARRAY_LITERAL:
            return check_array_literal_against(tc, expr, expected);
            
        case AST_DICT_LITERAL:
            return check_dict_literal_against(tc, expr, expected);
            
        default:
            // Synthesize and check compatibility
            Type *actual = check_expr(tc, expr);
            if (!is_assignable_to(actual, expected)) {
                semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
                    "Type mismatch: expected %s, got %s",
                    type_to_string(expected),
                    type_to_string(actual));
            }
            return actual;
    }
}

static Type* check_lambda_against(TypeChecker *tc, ASTNode *expr, Type *expected) {
    if (expected->kind != TYPE_FUNCTION) {
        return check_lambda(tc, expr);  // Fall back to synthesis
    }
    
    FunctionType *expected_func = &expected->data.function;
    Lambda *lambda = &expr->data.lambda;
    
    // Check parameter count
    if (lambda->param_count != expected_func->param_count) {
        semantic_error(tc->analyzer, expr->location,
            "Lambda expects %zu parameters, but %zu required",
            lambda->param_count, expected_func->param_count);
        return global_type_table->type_error;
    }
    
    // Push lambda scope
    push_scope(tc->analyzer, SCOPE_FUNCTION);
    
    // Define parameters with expected types
    for (size_t i = 0; i < lambda->param_count; i++) {
        Symbol *param = define_symbol(tc->analyzer,
            lambda->params[i]->data.identifier.name,
            SYMBOL_PARAMETER,
            expected_func->param_types[i],
            lambda->params[i]->location);
        param->is_initialized = true;
    }
    
    // Check body with expected return type
    TypeChecker body_tc = *tc;
    body_tc.expected_type = expected_func->return_type;
    Type *body_type = check_expr(&body_tc, lambda->body);
    
    pop_scope(tc->analyzer);
    
    expr->expr_type = expected;
    return expected;
}

3.7 Constant Folding

Constant folding evaluates compile-time constants:

typedef struct {
    enum {
        CONST_NULL,
        CONST_BOOL,
        CONST_INT,
        CONST_FLOAT,
        CONST_STRING
    } kind;
    union {
        bool bool_val;
        int64_t int_val;
        double float_val;
        char *string_val;
    } value;
} ConstValue;

static bool fold_constants(ASTNode *node) {
    switch (node->type) {
        case AST_BINARY_OP:
            return fold_binary_op(node);
            
        case AST_UNARY_OP:
            return fold_unary_op(node);
            
        case AST_IF:
            return fold_if_stmt(node);
            
        default:
            // Recursively fold children
            fold_children(node);
            return false;
    }
}

static bool fold_binary_op(ASTNode *node) {
    BinaryOp *op = &node->data.binary_op;
    
    // First fold operands
    bool left_folded = fold_constants(op->left);
    bool right_folded = fold_constants(op->right);
    
    // Check if both operands are constants
    if (!is_constant(op->left) || !is_constant(op->right))
…then constant folding can be applied.

For example:

```c
ConstValue *left = get_const_value(op->left);
ConstValue *right = get_const_value(op->right);

// Arithmetic on integers
if (left->kind == CONST_INT && right->kind == CONST_INT) {
    int64_t result;
    switch (op->op) {
        case TOK_PLUS:    result = left->value.int_val + right->value.int_val; break;
        case TOK_MINUS:   result = left->value.int_val - right->value.int_val; break;
        case TOK_STAR:    result = left->value.int_val * right->value.int_val; break;
        case TOK_SLASH:   result = left->value.int_val / right->value.int_val; break;
        default: return false;
    }
    replace_with_int_literal(node, result);
    return true;
}

// Floating point arithmetic
if (left->kind == CONST_FLOAT && right->kind == CONST_FLOAT) {
    double result;
    switch (op->op) {
        case TOK_PLUS:    result = left->value.float_val + right->value.float_val; break;
