        case TOK_MINUS:   result = left->value.float_val - right->value.float_val; break;
        case TOK_STAR:    result = left->value.float_val * right->value.float_val; break;
        case TOK_SLASH:   result = left->value.float_val / right->value.float_val; break;
        default: return false;
    }
    replace_with_float_literal(node, result);
    return true;
}

// Boolean simplifications
if (left->kind == CONST_BOOL && right->kind == CONST_BOOL) {
    bool result;
    switch (op->op) {
        case TOK_AND: result = left->value.bool_val && right->value.bool_val; break;
        case TOK_OR:  result = left->value.bool_val || right->value.bool_val; break;
        default: return false;
    }
    replace_with_bool_literal(node, result);
    return true;
}

return false;

This can drastically simplify ASTs before code generation by removing dead computations.

Similarly for folding if statements:

static bool fold_if_stmt(ASTNode *node) {
    IfStmt *ifstmt = &node->data.if_stmt;
    if (!fold_constants(ifstmt->condition))
        return false;

    if (is_constant(ifstmt->condition)) {
        ConstValue *cond = get_const_value(ifstmt->condition);
        if (cond->kind == CONST_BOOL) {
            // Replace with taken branch
            ASTNode *taken = cond->value.bool_val ? ifstmt->then_branch
                                                  : ifstmt->else_branch;
            if (taken) {
                *node = *taken; // structural replace
                return true;
            }
        }
    }
    return false;
}

3.8 Integration

The semantic analysis stage binds together name resolution, type checking, and optimization:

  1. Initialize the global scope and type table.
  2. Walk the AST, defining symbols and checking expressions/statements.
  3. Accumulate any type constraints for later inference.
  4. Fold constants wherever possible to simplify the AST.
  5. Report errors and warnings with precise source locations.

High-level driver:

ASTNode *dyr_semantic_analyze(ASTNode *ast) {
    SemanticAnalyzer analyzer = {0};
    analyzer.global = push_scope(&analyzer, SCOPE_GLOBAL);
    init_type_system();
    define_builtins(&analyzer);

    TypeChecker tc = {.analyzer = &analyzer};
    check_stmt(&tc, ast);

    fold_constants(ast);
    solve_constraints(analyzer.constraints);

    if (has_errors(&analyzer))
        return NULL;

    return ast; // now type-annotated and optimized
}

3.9 Conclusion

This chapter established the core of Diyrbal’s semantic analysis and type system:

  • Gradual type system to balance flexibility and safety.
  • Scoped symbol tables to manage variable lifetimes and visibility.
  • Bidirectional type checking for better inference, especially with lambdas.
  • Constant folding for compile-time optimization.
  • Precise error reporting tied to source ranges for developer productivity.

A robust semantic analysis phase ensures that by the time code generation or interpretation begins, the AST represents a well-typed, semantically valid program — setting the stage for Diyrbal’s hybrid interpreter/JIT backend to operate efficiently.

If you like, I can follow this with Chapter 4: Intermediate Representation and SSA Transformation, which would connect directly to this type-checked AST for optimization and execution. Would you like me to proceed with that?

Chapter 4: Control Flow Graph Construction

4.1 Introduction

The Control Flow Graph (CFG) is a fundamental representation that explicitly captures the flow of control through a program. Each node in the CFG represents a basic block—a sequence of instructions with no branches except at the end—and edges represent possible control transfers between blocks. This chapter details the construction of CFGs from Diyrbal's AST, a crucial step before SSA transformation and optimization.

The CFG serves multiple purposes:

  • Optimization Foundation: Many optimizations operate on the CFG structure
  • SSA Construction: Dominance relationships in the CFG guide φ-node placement
  • Analysis Framework: Data-flow analyses traverse the CFG
  • JIT Compilation: The trace-based JIT identifies hot paths through the CFG

4.2 Basic Block Representation

A basic block is a maximal sequence of instructions where:

  • Control enters only at the beginning
  • Control leaves only at the end
  • No internal branches or branch targets
typedef struct BasicBlock {
    size_t id;                    // Unique identifier
    char *label;                  // Optional label for debugging
    
    // Instructions in this block
    Instruction *first;
    Instruction *last;
    size_t instruction_count;
    
    // Control flow edges
    struct BasicBlock **predecessors;
    size_t predecessor_count;
    size_t predecessor_capacity;
    
    struct BasicBlock **successors;
    size_t successor_count;
    size_t successor_capacity;
    
    // Terminator instruction
    enum {
        TERM_NONE,               // Fall through to next block
        TERM_JUMP,               // Unconditional jump
        TERM_BRANCH,             // Conditional branch
        TERM_SWITCH,             // Multi-way branch
        TERM_RETURN,             // Function return
        TERM_THROW               // Exception throw
    } terminator_type;
    
    union {
        struct {
            struct BasicBlock *target;
        } jump;
        
        struct {
            Value *condition;
            struct BasicBlock *true_target;
            struct BasicBlock *false_target;
        } branch;
        
        struct {
            Value *value;
            struct BasicBlock **targets;
            size_t target_count;
            struct BasicBlock *default_target;
        } switch_stmt;
        
        struct {
            Value *value;  // NULL for void return
        } return_stmt;
    } terminator;
    
    // Analysis information
    size_t dom_depth;            // Depth in dominator tree
    struct BasicBlock *idom;     // Immediate dominator
    BitSet *dominators;          // Set of dominators
    BitSet *df;                  // Dominance frontier
    
    // For CFG construction
    bool is_reachable;
    bool is_sealed;              // For SSA construction
    
    // Loop information
    struct Loop *loop;
    bool is_loop_header;
    
    // Profiling data
    uint64_t execution_count;
    double execution_frequency;
} BasicBlock;

typedef struct CFG {
    BasicBlock *entry;
    BasicBlock *exit;
    
    BasicBlock **blocks;
    size_t block_count;
    size_t block_capacity;
    
    // For block allocation
    size_t next_block_id;
    
    // Parent function
    struct Function *function;
    
    // Analysis results  
    bool dominance_computed;
    bool loops_analyzed;
} CFG;

4.3 Instruction Representation

Before building the CFG, we need an intermediate representation for instructions:

typedef enum {
    // Arithmetic
    INST_ADD, INST_SUB, INST_MUL, INST_DIV, INST_MOD,
    INST_NEG, INST_ABS,
    
    // Comparison
    INST_EQ, INST_NE, INST_LT, INST_LE, INST_GT, INST_GE,
    
    // Logical
    INST_AND, INST_OR, INST_NOT,
    
    // Memory
    INST_LOAD, INST_STORE, INST_ALLOCA,
    INST_LOAD_FIELD, INST_STORE_FIELD,
    INST_LOAD_ELEMENT, INST_STORE_ELEMENT,
    
    // Control flow
    INST_JUMP, INST_BRANCH, INST_SWITCH, INST_RETURN,
    INST_CALL, INST_TAIL_CALL,
    
    // Type operations
    INST_CAST, INST_INSTANCEOF,
    
    // Constants
    INST_CONST_INT, INST_CONST_FLOAT, INST_CONST_STRING,
    INST_CONST_BOOL, INST_CONST_NULL,
    
    // SSA operations
    INST_PHI,
    
    // Other
    INST_NOP, INST_UNREACHABLE
} InstructionKind;

typedef struct Value {
    enum {
        VALUE_CONST,
        VALUE_TEMP,
        VALUE_PARAM,
        VALUE_GLOBAL
    } kind;
    
    Type *type;
    
    union {
        // Constants
        struct {
            union {
                int64_t int_val;
                double float_val;
                char *string_val;
                bool bool_val;
            } data;
        } constant;
        
        // Temporaries
        struct {
            size_t id;
            char *name;  // Optional, for debugging
        } temp;
        
        // Parameters
        struct {
            size_t index;
            char *name;
        } param;
        
        // Globals
        struct {
            char *name;
            void *symbol;
        } global;
    } data;
    
    // Def-use chains
    struct Instruction *def;     // Defining instruction
    struct Use *uses;            // List of uses
} Value;

typedef struct Instruction {
    InstructionKind kind;
    Value *result;               // NULL if void
    
    // Operands
    Value **operands;
    size_t operand_count;
    
    // Source location for debugging
    SourceLoc location;
    
    // Links
    struct Instruction *prev;
    struct Instruction *next;
    struct BasicBlock *block;
    
    // Additional data for specific instructions
    union {
        struct {
            Function *target;
            bool is_tail_call;
        } call;
        
        struct {
            size_t incoming_count;
            Value **incoming_values;
            BasicBlock **incoming_blocks;
        } phi;
    } data;
} Instruction;

4.4 CFG Builder

The CFG builder traverses the AST and generates basic blocks:

typedef struct CFGBuilder {
    CFG *cfg;
    BasicBlock *current_block;
    
    // Stack for nested control structures
    struct {
        BasicBlock *continue_target;
        BasicBlock *break_target;
    } *loop_stack;
    size_t loop_depth;
    size_t loop_stack_capacity;
    
    // Temporary allocation
    size_t next_temp_id;
    
    // Error handling
    ErrorList *errors;
} CFGBuilder;

CFG* build_cfg(Function *function) {
    CFGBuilder builder = {0};
    builder.cfg = calloc(1, sizeof(CFG));
    builder.cfg->function = function;
    
    // Create entry block
    builder.cfg->entry = create_block(&builder, "entry");
    builder.current_block = builder.cfg->entry;
    
    // Build CFG from function body
    Value *result = build_stmt(&builder, function->body);
    
    // Ensure all paths end with return
    if (!block_has_terminator(builder.current_block)) {
        if (function->return_type->kind == TYPE_VOID) {
            emit_return(&builder, NULL);
        } else {
            error(&builder, function->body->location,
                  "Function does not return on all paths");
        }
    }
    
    // Create exit block
    builder.cfg->exit = create_block(&builder, "exit");
    connect_returns_to_exit(builder.cfg);
    
    // Clean up unreachable blocks
    remove_unreachable_blocks(builder.cfg);
    
    return builder.cfg;
}

static BasicBlock* create_block(CFGBuilder *builder, const char *label) {
    BasicBlock *block = calloc(1, sizeof(BasicBlock));
    block->id = builder->cfg->next_block_id++;
    block->label = label ? strdup(label) : NULL;
    
    // Add to CFG
    if (builder->cfg->block_count >= builder->cfg->block_capacity) {
        builder->cfg->block_capacity = builder->cfg->block_capacity * 2 + 8;
        builder->cfg->blocks = realloc(builder->cfg->blocks,
            builder->cfg->block_capacity * sizeof(BasicBlock*));
    }
    builder->cfg->blocks[builder->cfg->block_count++] = block;
    
    return block;
}

4.5 Statement Translation

Each statement type is translated into basic blocks and instructions:

static Value* build_stmt(CFGBuilder *builder, ASTNode *stmt) {
    switch (stmt->type) {
        case AST_BLOCK:
            return build_block_stmt(builder, stmt);
            
        case AST_ASSIGN:
            return build_assignment(builder, stmt);
            
        case AST_IF:
            return build_if_stmt(builder, stmt);
            
        case AST_WHILE:
            return build_while_stmt(builder, stmt);
            
        case AST_FOR:
            return build_for_stmt(builder, stmt);
            
        case AST_RETURN:
            return build_return_stmt(builder, stmt);
            
        case AST_BREAK:
            return build_break_stmt(builder, stmt);
            
        case AST_CONTINUE:
            return build_continue_stmt(builder, stmt);
            
        case AST_EXPR_STMT:
            return build_expr(builder, stmt->data.expr_stmt.expr);
            
        default:
            error(builder, stmt->location, "Unknown statement type");
            return NULL;
    }
}

static Value* build_if_stmt(CFGBuilder *builder, ASTNode *stmt) {
    IfStmt *if_stmt = &stmt->data.if_stmt;
    
    // Evaluate condition
    Value *cond = build_expr(builder, if_stmt->condition);
    
    // Create blocks
    BasicBlock *then_block = create_block(builder, "if.then");
    BasicBlock *else_block = if_stmt->else_branch ? 
        create_block(builder, "if.else") : NULL;
    BasicBlock *merge_block = create_block(builder, "if.merge");
    
    // Emit conditional branch
    if (else_block) {
        emit_branch(builder, cond, then_block, else_block);
    } else {
        emit_branch(builder, cond, then_block, merge_block);
    }
    
    // Build then branch
    builder->current_block = then_block;
    build_stmt(builder, if_stmt->then_branch);
    if (!block_has_terminator(builder->current_block)) {
        emit_jump(builder, merge_block);
    }
    
    // Build else branch if present
    if (else_block) {
        builder->current_block = else_block;
        build_stmt(builder, if_stmt->else_branch);
        if (!block_has_terminator(builder->current_block)) {
            emit_jump(builder, merge_block);
        }
    }
    
    // Continue with merge block
    builder->current_block = merge_block;
    return NULL;
}

static Value* build_while_stmt(CFGBuilder *builder, ASTNode *stmt) {
    WhileStmt *while_stmt = &stmt->data.while_stmt;
    
    // Create blocks
    BasicBlock *header = create_block(builder, "while.header");
    BasicBlock *body = create_block(builder, "while.body");
    BasicBlock *exit = create_block(builder, "while.exit");
    
    // Jump to header
    emit_jump(builder, header);
    
    // Build header (condition check)
    builder->current_block = header;
    Value *cond = build_expr(builder, while_stmt->condition);
    emit_branch(builder, cond, body, exit);
    
    // Push loop context
    push_loop_context(builder, header, exit);
    
    // Build body
    builder->current_block = body;
    build_stmt(builder, while_stmt->body);
    if (!block_has_terminator(builder->current_block)) {
        emit_jump(builder, header);
    }
    
    pop_loop_context(builder);
    
    // Continue with exit block
    builder->current_block = exit;
    return NULL;
}

4.6 Expression Translation

Expressions are translated into SSA-style instructions:

static Value* build_expr(CFGBuilder *builder, ASTNode *expr) {
    switch (expr->type) {
        case AST_INT_LITERAL:
            return emit_const_int(builder, expr->data.int_literal.value);
            
        case AST_FLOAT_LITERAL:
            return emit_const_float(builder, expr->data.float_literal.value);
            
        case AST_STRING_LITERAL:
            return emit_const_string(builder, expr->data.string_literal.value);
            
        case AST_BOOL_LITERAL:
            return emit_const_bool(builder, expr->data.bool_literal.value);
            
        case AST_NULL_LITERAL:
            return emit_const_null(builder);
            
        case AST_IDENTIFIER:
            return build_identifier(builder, expr);
            
        case AST_BINARY_OP:
            return build_binary_op(builder, expr);
            
        case AST_UNARY_OP:
            return build_unary_op(builder, expr);
            
        case AST_CALL:
            return build_call(builder, expr);
            
        case AST_INDEX:
            return build_index(builder, expr);
            
        case AST_MEMBER:
            return build_member_access(builder, expr);
            
        default:
            error(builder, expr->location, "Unknown expression type");
            return NULL;
    }
}

static Value* build_binary_op(CFGBuilder *builder, ASTNode *expr) {
    BinaryOp *op = &expr->data.binary_op;
    
    // Short-circuit evaluation for logical operators
    if (op->op == TOK_AND || op->op == TOK_OR) {
        return build_short_circuit(builder, expr);
    }
    
    // Evaluate operands
    Value *left = build_expr(builder, op->left);
    Value *right = build_expr(builder, op->right);
    
    // Emit instruction
    InstructionKind inst_kind;
    switch (op->op) {
        case TOK_PLUS:    inst_kind = INST_ADD; break;
        case TOK_MINUS:   inst_kind = INST_SUB; break;
        case TOK_STAR:    inst_kind = INST_MUL; break;
        case TOK_SLASH:   inst_kind = INST_DIV; break;
        case TOK_PERCENT: inst_kind = INST_MOD; break;
        case TOK_EQ:      inst_kind = INST_EQ; break;
        case TOK_NE:      inst_kind = INST_NE; break;
        case TOK_LT:      inst_kind = INST_LT; break;
        case TOK_LE:      inst_kind = INST_LE; break;
        case TOK_GT:      inst_kind = INST_GT; break;
        case TOK_GE:      inst_kind = INST_GE; break;
        default:
            error(builder, expr->location, "Unknown binary operator");
            return NULL;
    }
    
    return emit_binary(builder, inst_kind, left, right, expr->expr_type);
}

static Value* build_short_circuit(CFGBuilder *builder, ASTNode *expr) {
    BinaryOp *op = &expr->data.binary_op;
    bool is_and = (op->op == TOK_AND);
    
    // Evaluate left operand
    Value *left = build_expr(builder, op->left);
    
    // Create blocks
    BasicBlock *right_block = create_block(builder, is_and ? "and.rhs" : "or.rhs");
    BasicBlock *merge_block = create_block(builder, is_and ? "and.merge" : "or.merge");
    
    // Branch based on left value
    if (is_and) {
        // For AND: if left is false, skip right
        emit_branch(builder, left, right_block, merge_block);
    } else {
        // For OR: if left is true, skip right  
        emit_branch(builder, left, merge_block, right_block);
    }
    
    // Remember incoming value from left block
    BasicBlock *left_block = builder->current_block;
    
    // Evaluate right operand
    builder->current_block = right_block;
    Value *right = build_expr(builder, op->right);
    BasicBlock *right_end_block = builder->current_block;
    emit_jump(builder, merge_block);
    
    // Create phi node in merge block
    builder->current_block = merge_block;
    Value *result = emit_phi(builder, expr->expr_type);
    add_phi_incoming(result, left, left_block);
    add_phi_incoming(result, right, right_end_block);
    
    return result;
}

4.7 Instruction Emission

Helper functions for emitting instructions:

static Value* new_temp(CFGBuilder *builder, Type *type) {
    Value *temp = calloc(1, sizeof(Value));
    temp->kind = VALUE_TEMP;
    temp->type = type;
    temp->data.temp.id = builder->next_temp_id++;
    return temp;
}

static Instruction* emit_instruction(CFGBuilder *builder, InstructionKind kind,
                                   Type *result_type) {
    Instruction *inst = calloc(1, sizeof(Instruction));
    inst->kind = kind;
    inst->block = builder->current_block;
    
    if (result_type && result_type->kind != TYPE_VOID) {
        inst->result = new_temp(builder, result_type);
        inst->result->def = inst;
    }
    
    // Add to block
    if (builder->current_block->last) {
        builder->current_block->last->next = inst;
        inst->prev = builder->current_block->last;
    } else {
        builder->current_block->first = inst;
    }
    builder->current_block->last = inst;
    builder->current_block->instruction_count++;
    
    return inst;
}

static Value* emit_binary(CFGBuilder *builder, InstructionKind kind,
                         Value *left, Value *right, Type *result_type) {
    Instruction *inst = emit_instruction(builder, kind, result_type);
    inst->operand_count = 2;
    inst->operands = calloc(2, sizeof(Value*));
    inst->operands[0] = left;
    inst->operands[1] = right;
    
    add_use(left, inst);
    add_use(right, inst);
    
    return inst->result;
}

static void emit_jump(CFGBuilder *builder, BasicBlock *target) {
    builder->current_block->terminator_type = TERM_JUMP;
    builder->current_block->terminator.jump.target = target;
    
    add_edge(builder->current_block, target);
}

static void emit_branch(CFGBuilder *builder, Value *condition,
                       BasicBlock *true_target, BasicBlock *false_target) {
    builder->current_block->terminator_type = TERM_BRANCH;
    builder->current_block->terminator.branch.condition = condition;
    builder->current_block->terminator.branch.true_target = true_target;
    builder->current_block->terminator.branch.false_target = false_target;
    
    add_use(condition, NULL);  // Terminator use
    add_edge(builder->current_block, true_target);
    add_edge(builder->current_block, false_target);
}

static void emit_return(CFGBuilder *builder, Value *value) {
    builder->current_block->terminator_type = TERM_RETURN;
    builder->current_block->terminator.return_stmt.value = value;
    
    if (value) {
        add_use(value, NULL);  // Terminator use
    }
}

static Value* emit_phi(CFGBuilder *builder, Type *type) {
    Instruction *inst = emit_instruction(builder, INST_PHI, type);
    inst->data.phi.incoming_count = 0;
    inst->data.phi.incoming_values = NULL;
    inst->data.phi.incoming_blocks = NULL;
    return inst->result;
}

static void add_phi_incoming(Value *phi_result, Value *value, BasicBlock *block) {
    Instruction *phi = phi_result->def;
    assert(phi->kind == INST_PHI);
    
    size_t n = phi->data.phi.incoming_count++;
    phi->data.phi.incoming_values = realloc(phi->data.phi.incoming_values,
        phi->data.phi.incoming_count * sizeof(Value*));
    phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks = realloc(phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks,
        phi->data.phi.incoming_count * sizeof(BasicBlock*));
    
    phi->data.phi.incoming_values[n] = value;
    phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks[n] = block;
    
    add_use(value, phi);
}

4.8 Control Flow Edge Management

Managing predecessor/successor relationships:

static void add_edge(BasicBlock *from, BasicBlock *to) {
    // Add to successors
    if (from->successor_count >= from->successor_capacity) {
        from->successor_capacity = from->successor_capacity * 2 + 2;
        from->successors = realloc(from->successors,
            from->successor_capacity * sizeof(BasicBlock*));
    }
    from->successors[from->successor_count++] = to;
    
    // Add to predecessors
    if (to->predecessor_count >= to->predecessor_capacity) {
        to->predecessor_capacity = to->predecessor_capacity * 2 + 2;
        to->predecessors = realloc(to->predecessors,
            to->predecessor_capacity * sizeof(BasicBlock*));
    }
    to->predecessors[to->predecessor_count++] = from;
}

static void remove_edge(BasicBlock *from, BasicBlock *to) {
    // Remove from successors
    for (size_t i = 0; i < from->successor_count; i++) {
        if (from->successors[i] == to) {
            memmove(&from->successors[i], &from->successors[i + 1],
                (from->successor_count - i - 1) * sizeof(BasicBlock*));
            from->successor_count--;
            break;
        }
    }
    
    // Remove from predecessors
    for (size_t i = 0; i < to->predecessor_count; i++) {
        if (to->predecessors[i] == from) {
            memmove(&to->predecessors[i], &to->predecessors[i + 1],
                (to->predecessor_count - i - 1) * sizeof(BasicBlock*));
            to->predecessor_count--;
            break;
        }
    }
}

static bool block_has_terminator(BasicBlock *block) {
    return block->terminator_type != TERM_NONE;
}

4.9 CFG Cleanup

After initial construction, the CFG needs cleanup:

static void remove_unreachable_blocks(CFG *cfg) {
    // Mark reachable blocks
    mark_reachable_blocks(cfg->entry);
    
    // Remove unreachable blocks
    size_t write_idx = 0;
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = cfg->blocks[i];
        if (block->is_reachable) {
            cfg->blocks[write_idx++] = block;
        } else {
            free_block(block);
        }
    }
    cfg->block_count = write_idx;
}

static void mark_reachable_blocks(BasicBlock *block) {
    if (block->is_reachable) return;
    
    block->is_reachable = true;
    
    // Mark successors
    for (size_t i = 0; i < block->successor_count; i++) {
        mark_reachable_blocks(block->successors[i]);
    }
}

static void merge_blocks(BasicBlock *pred, BasicBlock *succ) {
    assert(pred->successor_count == 1);
    assert(succ->predecessor_count == 1);
    
    // Remove jump terminator
    pred->terminator_type = TERM_NONE;
    
    // Move instructions
    if (pred->last) {
        pred->last->next = succ->first;
        if (succ->first) {
            succ->first->prev = pred->last;
        }
    } else {
        pred->first = succ->first;
    }
    pred->last = succ->last;
    pred->instruction_count += succ->instruction_count;
    
    // Update instruction parent blocks
    for (Instruction *inst = succ->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
        inst->block = pred;
    }
    
    // Copy terminator
    pred->terminator_type = succ->terminator_type;
    pred->terminator = succ->terminator;
    
    // Update edges
    for (size_t i = 0; i < succ->successor_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *target = succ->successors[i];
        add_edge(pred, target);
        
        // Update phi nodes
        update_phi_blocks(target, succ, pred);
    }
    
    // Remove old edges
    remove_edge(pred, succ);
    for (size_t i = 0; i < succ->successor_count; i++) {
        remove_edge(succ, succ->successors[i]);
    }
}

static void simplify_cfg(CFG *cfg) {
    bool changed;
    do {
        changed = false;
        
        for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
            BasicBlock *block = cfg->blocks[i];
            
            // Merge blocks with single predecessor/successor
            if (block->terminator_type == TERM_JUMP &&
                block->successor_count == 1 &&
                block->successors[0]->predecessor_count == 1) {
                merge_blocks(block, block->successors[0]);
                changed = true;
            }
            
            // Remove empty blocks
            if (block->instruction_count == 0 &&
                block->terminator_type == TERM_JUMP &&
                block != cfg->entry) {
                bypass_empty_block(block);
                changed = true;
            }
        }
        
        if (changed) {
            remove_unreachable_blocks(cfg);
        }
    } while (changed);
}

4.10 Dominance Analysis

Computing dominance relationships is crucial for SSA construction:

static void compute_dominance(CFG *cfg) {
    size_t n = cfg->block_count;
    
    // Initialize dominance sets
    for (size_t i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        cfg->blocks[i]->dominators = bitset_new(n);
        if (cfg->blocks[i] == cfg->entry) {
            bitset_set(cfg->blocks[i]->dominators, cfg->blocks[i]->id);
        } else {
            bitset_set_all(cfg->blocks[i]->dominators, n);
        }
    }
    
    // Iterate until fixed point
    bool changed;
    do {
        changed = false;
        
        for (size_t i = 0; i < n; i++) {
            BasicBlock *block = cfg->blocks[i];
            if (block == cfg->entry) continue;
            
            // Dom(block) = {block} ∪ (∩ Dom(pred) for pred in predecessors)
            BitSet *new_dom = bitset_new(n);
            bitset_set_all(new_dom, n);
            
            for (size_t j = 0; j < block->predecessor_count; j++) {
                bitset_intersect(new_dom, block->predecessors[j]->dominators);
            }
            bitset_set(new_dom, block->id);
            
            if (!bitset_equal(new_dom, block->dominators)) {
                bitset_free(block->dominators);
                block->dominators = new_dom;
                changed = true;
            } else {
                bitset_free(new_dom);
            }
        }
    } while (changed);
    
    // Compute immediate dominators
    compute_idom(cfg);
    
    // Compute dominance frontiers
    compute_df(cfg);
    
    cfg->dominance_computed = true;
}

static void compute_idom(CFG *cfg) {
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = cfg->blocks[i];
        if (block == cfg->entry) continue;
        
        // Find immediate dominator
        for (size_t j = 0; j < cfg->block_count; j++) {
            BasicBlock *dom = cfg->blocks[j];
            if (dom == block) continue;
            
            if (bitset_test(block->dominators, dom->id)) {
                bool is_idom = true;
                
                // Check if dom dominates all other dominators
                for (size_t k = 0; k < cfg->block_count; k++) {
                    BasicBlock *other = cfg->blocks[k];
                    if (other == block || other == dom) continue;
                    
                    if (bitset_test(block->dominators, other->id) &&
                        !bitset_test(other->dominators, dom->id)) {
                        is_idom = false;
                        break;
                    }
                }
                
                if (is_idom) {
                    block->idom = dom;
                    block->dom_depth = dom->dom_depth + 1;
                    break;
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

static void compute_df(CFG *cfg) {
    // Compute dominance frontiers using Cytron et al. algorithm
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = cfg->blocks[i];
        block->df = bitset_new(cfg->block_count);
    }
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = cfg->blocks[i];
        
        if (block->predecessor_count >= 2) {
            for (size_t j = 0; j < block->predecessor_count; j++) {
                BasicBlock *runner = block->predecessors[j];
                
                while (runner != block->idom) {
                    bitset_set(runner->df, block->id);
                    runner = runner->idom;
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

4.11 Loop Detection

Identifying natural loops for optimization: Here’s the detailed continuation for Chapter 4 based on the style we’ve been using for the Diyrbal Implementation Bible, summarising what you’ve just provided about dominance computation and leading into the next CFG–related stage.

## 4.10 Dominance Analysis

Once the CFG has been simplified, we compute the dominance relationships that drive later SSA φ‑placement and loop analysis.

The procedure is standard:

  1. Dominance Sets – Initialise so that the entry block’s dominator set contains only itself, and all other blocks’ sets initially contain every block. Iteratively refine using:

[ Dom(B) = {B} \cup \bigcap_{P\in Preds(B)} Dom(P) ]

until convergence.

  1. Immediate Dominators (idom) – For each block other than the entry, find the unique dominator that is closest to it in the dominator tree. This is the parent in that tree. We store both the idom and a dom_depth for hierarchical traversals.

  2. Dominance Frontiers (df) – Using the Cytron et al. algorithm, visit each join point (a block with two or more predecessors) and walk backwards along idom links to all strict dominators, adding the join point to their dominance frontier sets. These sets will later be used when inserting φ‑nodes at points where values merge from different paths.

Dominance analysis is marked complete when all sets, parents, and frontiers have been computed and cached within the BasicBlock structures.

Summary of Data Structures Used

  • dominators: bit‑set representing all blocks dominating the current one.
  • idom: pointer to the immediate dominator block.
  • df: bit‑set representing the dominance frontier of the block.

At this stage, the CFG is a fully connected and analysed graph; we have explicit entry/exit, block connectivity, SSA‑style instruction lists inside each block ready for variable renaming, and exact dominance/frontier information. This sets the stage for:

  • Loop detection (natural loop headers can be identified where a successor dominates one of its predecessors),
  • SSA variable renaming and φ‑insertion (using df),
  • Further control‑flow simplifications.

The chapter closes by noting that, with the CFG complete and dominance information in place, the next chapter will focus on loop detection and SSA conversion rules as applied in Diyrbal.

If you like, I can go ahead and draft Chapter 5: Loop Analysis and SSA Conversion in the same level of structural and code‑oriented detail so we keep the continuity of the “Implementation Bible.” Would you like me to proceed with that next?

Chapter 5: SSA Form Generation

5.1 Introduction

Static Single Assignment (SSA) form is a program representation where each variable is assigned exactly once. This property simplifies many analyses and optimizations by making def-use relationships explicit. This chapter details Diyrbal's SSA construction algorithm, which transforms the CFG from Chapter 4 into SSA form.

The key challenges in SSA construction are:

  • Variable Renaming: Each assignment creates a new version of a variable
  • φ-Node Insertion: At control-flow merge points, φ-nodes select the appropriate variable version
  • Minimal SSA: Inserting φ-nodes only where necessary to avoid bloat
  • Memory Operations: Extending SSA to handle loads and stores

5.2 SSA Construction Overview

Diyrbal uses the algorithm from Cytron et al., which consists of two phases:

  1. φ-Node Insertion: Place φ-nodes at dominance frontiers
  2. Variable Renaming: Assign unique names to each definition
typedef struct SSAConstructor {
    CFG *cfg;
    
    // Variable information
    struct {
        char *name;
        Type *type;
        bool is_local;
        
        // Definition sites
        BasicBlock **def_blocks;
        size_t def_count;
        
        // φ-nodes for this variable
        Instruction **phi_nodes;
        size_t phi_count;
    } *variables;
    size_t variable_count;
    
    // Renaming state
    struct {
        Value **stack;
        size_t top;
        size_t capacity;
    } *rename_stacks;
    
    // Statistics
    size_t phi_nodes_inserted;
    size_t variables_renamed;
} SSAConstructor;

void convert_to_ssa(CFG *cfg) {
    SSAConstructor ssa = {0};
    ssa.cfg = cfg;
    
    // Ensure dominance information is computed
    if (!cfg->dominance_computed) {
        compute_dominance(cfg);
    }
    
    // Collect variables
    collect_variables(&ssa);
    
    // Insert φ-nodes
    insert_phi_nodes(&ssa);
    
    // Rename variables
    rename_variables(&ssa);
    
    // Clean up
    cleanup_ssa_constructor(&ssa);
}

5.3 Variable Collection

First, we identify all variables that need SSA form:

static void collect_variables(SSAConstructor *ssa) {
    // Collect function parameters
    Function *func = ssa->cfg->function;
    for (size_t i = 0; i < func->param_count; i++) {
        add_variable(ssa, func->params[i].name, func->params[i].type, false);
    }
    
    // Collect local variables from all blocks
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = ssa->cfg->blocks[i];
        collect_block_variables(ssa, block);
    }
    
    // Initialize rename stacks
    ssa->rename_stacks = calloc(ssa->variable_count, 
                                sizeof(ssa->rename_stacks[0]));
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->variable_count; i++) {
        ssa->rename_stacks[i].capacity = 16;
        ssa->rename_stacks[i].stack = calloc(16, sizeof(Value*));
    }
}

static void collect_block_variables(SSAConstructor *ssa, BasicBlock *block) {
    for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
        switch (inst->kind) {
            case INST_ALLOCA:
                // Local variable declaration
                add_variable(ssa, inst->data.alloca.name, 
                           inst->data.alloca.type, true);
                record_def_site(ssa, inst->data.alloca.name, block);
                break;
                
            case INST_STORE:
                // Assignment to existing variable
                if (inst->operands[1]->kind == VALUE_LOCAL) {
                    record_def_site(ssa, inst->operands[1]->data.local.name, 
                                  block);
                }
                break;
        }
    }
}

static size_t find_variable(SSAConstructor *ssa, const char *name) {
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->variable_count; i++) {
        if (strcmp(ssa->variables[i].name, name) == 0) {
            return i;
        }
    }
    return SIZE_MAX;
}

static void record_def_site(SSAConstructor *ssa, const char *name, 
                          BasicBlock *block) {
    size_t var_idx = find_variable(ssa, name);
    if (var_idx == SIZE_MAX) return;
    
    // Add block to definition sites if not already present
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->variables[var_idx].def_count; i++) {
        if (ssa->variables[var_idx].def_blocks[i] == block) {
            return;
        }
    }
    
    size_t n = ssa->variables[var_idx].def_count++;
    ssa->variables[var_idx].def_blocks = realloc(
        ssa->variables[var_idx].def_blocks,
        ssa->variables[var_idx].def_count * sizeof(BasicBlock*));
    ssa->variables[var_idx].def_blocks[n] = block;
}

5.4 φ-Node Insertion

φ-nodes are inserted at the dominance frontier of definition sites:

static void insert_phi_nodes(SSAConstructor *ssa) {
    for (size_t var = 0; var < ssa->variable_count; var++) {
        if (!ssa->variables[var].is_local) {
            continue;  // Parameters don't need φ-nodes
        }
        
        // Worklist of blocks that define this variable
        BlockSet *worklist = blockset_new(ssa->cfg->block_count);
        BlockSet *has_phi = blockset_new(ssa->cfg->block_count);
        BlockSet *in_worklist = blockset_new(ssa->cfg->block_count);
        
        // Initialize worklist with definition blocks
        for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->variables[var].def_count; i++) {
            BasicBlock *def_block = ssa->variables[var].def_blocks[i];
            blockset_add(worklist, def_block->id);
            blockset_add(in_worklist, def_block->id);
        }
        
        // Process worklist
        while (!blockset_empty(worklist)) {
            BasicBlock *block = blockset_pop(worklist);
            blockset_remove(in_worklist, block->id);
            
            // Insert φ-nodes at dominance frontier
            BitSetIterator it = bitset_iterator(block->df);
            size_t df_block_id;
            while (bitset_next(&it, &df_block_id)) {
                BasicBlock *df_block = ssa->cfg->blocks[df_block_id];
                
                if (!blockset_contains(has_phi, df_block_id)) {
                    insert_phi_for_variable(ssa, var, df_block);
                    blockset_add(has_phi, df_block_id);
                    
                    // φ-node is also a definition
                    if (!blockset_contains(in_worklist, df_block_id)) {
                        blockset_add(worklist, df_block_id);
                        blockset_add(in_worklist, df_block_id);
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        
        blockset_free(worklist);
        blockset_free(has_phi);
        blockset_free(in_worklist);
    }
}

static void insert_phi_for_variable(SSAConstructor *ssa, size_t var_idx,
                                  BasicBlock *block) {
    // Create φ-node
    Instruction *phi = calloc(1, sizeof(Instruction));
    phi->kind = INST_PHI;
    phi->block = block;
    
    // Create result value
    phi->result = calloc(1, sizeof(Value));
    phi->result->kind = VALUE_TEMP;
    phi->result->type = ssa->variables[var_idx].type;
    phi->result->def = phi;
    phi->result->data.temp.name = strdup(ssa->variables[var_idx].name);
    
    // Initialize incoming arrays
    phi->data.phi.incoming_count = block->predecessor_count;
    phi->data.phi.incoming_values = calloc(block->predecessor_count, 
                                          sizeof(Value*));
    phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks = calloc(block->predecessor_count,
                                          sizeof(BasicBlock*));
    
    // Copy predecessor blocks
    for (size_t i = 0; i < block->predecessor_count; i++) {
        phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks[i] = block->predecessors[i];
    }
    
    // Insert at beginning of block
    phi->next = block->first;
    if (block->first) {
        block->first->prev = phi;
    }
    block->first = phi;
    if (!block->last) {
        block->last = phi;
    }
    block->instruction_count++;
    
    // Record φ-node
    size_t n = ssa->variables[var_idx].phi_count++;
    ssa->variables[var_idx].phi_nodes = realloc(
        ssa->variables[var_idx].phi_nodes,
        ssa->variables[var_idx].phi_count * sizeof(Instruction*));
    ssa->variables[var_idx].phi_nodes[n] = phi;
    
    ssa->phi_nodes_inserted++;
}

5.5 Variable Renaming

The renaming phase assigns unique SSA names to each definition:

static void rename_variables(SSAConstructor *ssa) {
    // Initialize parameter values
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->cfg->function->param_count; i++) {
        size_t var_idx = find_variable(ssa, ssa->cfg->function->params[i].name);
        if (var_idx != SIZE_MAX) {
            Value *param_val = create_param_value(ssa, i, 
                ssa->cfg->function->params[i].type);
            push_value(ssa, var_idx, param_val);
        }
    }
    
    // Rename starting from entry block
    rename_block(ssa, ssa->cfg->entry);
}

static void rename_block(SSAConstructor *ssa, BasicBlock *block) {
    // Save stack depths for restoration
    size_t *saved_depths = calloc(ssa->variable_count, sizeof(size_t));
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->variable_count; i++) {
        saved_depths[i] = ssa->rename_stacks[i].top;
    }
    
    // Process φ-nodes
    for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst && inst->kind == INST_PHI; 
         inst = inst->next) {
        // φ-node result pushes new value
        size_t var_idx = find_variable_by_phi(ssa, inst);
        if (var_idx != SIZE_MAX) {
            push_value(ssa, var_idx, inst->result);
        }
    }
    
    // Process other instructions
    for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
        if (inst->kind == INST_PHI) continue;
        
        rename_instruction(ssa, inst);
    }
    
    // Fill in φ-node operands in successors
    for (size_t i = 0; i < block->successor_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *succ = block->successors[i];
        fill_phi_operands(ssa, block, succ);
    }
    
    // Recursively rename dominated blocks
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *child = ssa->cfg->blocks[i];
        if (child->idom == block) {
            rename_block(ssa, child);
        }
    }
    
    // Restore stack depths
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->variable_count; i++) {
        ssa->rename_stacks[i].top = saved_depths[i];
    }
    free(saved_depths);
}

static void rename_instruction(SSAConstructor *ssa, Instruction *inst) {
    // Rename uses
    for (size_t i = 0; i < inst->operand_count; i++) {
        if (inst->operands[i]->kind == VALUE_LOCAL) {
            size_t var_idx = find_variable(ssa, 
                inst->operands[i]->data.local.name);
            if (var_idx != SIZE_MAX) {
                inst->operands[i] = get_current_value(ssa, var_idx);
            }
        }
    }
    
    // Handle definitions
    switch (inst->kind) {
        case INST_ALLOCA:
            // Initial definition of local variable
            {
                size_t var_idx = find_variable(ssa, inst->data.alloca.name);
                if (var_idx != SIZE_MAX) {
                    Value *undef = create_undef_value(ssa->variables[var_idx].type);
                    push_value(ssa, var_idx, undef);
                }
            }
            break;
            
        case INST_STORE:
            // Assignment to variable
            if (inst->operands[1]->kind == VALUE_LOCAL) {
                size_t var_idx = find_variable(ssa, 
                    inst->operands[1]->data.local.name);
                if (var_idx != SIZE_MAX) {
                    push_value(ssa, var_idx, inst->operands[0]);
                }
            }
            break;
            
        case INST_LOAD:
            // Load from variable
            if (inst->operands[0]->kind == VALUE_LOCAL) {
                size_t var_idx = find_variable(ssa, 
                    inst->operands[0]->data.local.name);
                if (var_idx != SIZE_MAX) {
                    Value *current = get_current_value(ssa, var_idx);
                    
                    // Replace load with value
                    replace_instruction_with_value(inst, current);
                    ssa->variables_renamed++;
                }
            }
            break;
    }
}

static void fill_phi_operands(SSAConstructor *ssa, BasicBlock *pred,
                            BasicBlock *succ) {
    for (Instruction *inst = succ->first; inst && inst->kind == INST_PHI;
         inst = inst->next) {
        size_t var_idx = find_variable_by_phi(ssa, inst);
        if (var_idx == SIZE_MAX) continue;
        
        // Find predecessor index
        size_t pred_idx = SIZE_MAX;
        for (size_t i = 0; i < inst->data.phi.incoming_count; i++) {
            if (inst->data.phi.incoming_blocks[i] == pred) {
                pred_idx = i;
                break;
            }
        }
        
        if (pred_idx != SIZE_MAX) {
            inst->data.phi.incoming_values[pred_idx] = 
                get_current_value(ssa, var_idx);
        }
    }
}

static Value* get_current_value(SSAConstructor *ssa, size_t var_idx) {
    if (ssa->rename_stacks[var_idx].top == 0) {
        // No definition yet - create undefined value
        return create_undef_value(ssa->variables[var_idx].type);
    }
    
    return ssa->rename_stacks[var_idx].stack[
        ssa->rename_stacks[var_idx].top - 1];
}

static void push_value(SSAConstructor *ssa, size_t var_idx, Value *value) {
    size_t *top = &ssa->rename_stacks[var_idx].top;
    size_t *cap = &ssa->rename_stacks[var_idx].capacity;
    Value ***stack = &ssa->rename_stacks[var_idx].stack;
    
    if (*top >= *cap) {
        *cap *= 2;
        *stack = realloc(*stack, *cap * sizeof(Value*));
    }
    
    (*stack)[(*top)++] = value;
}

5.6 Memory SSA Extensions

Extending SSA to memory operations requires special handling:

typedef struct MemorySSA {
    // Memory version tracking
    struct {
        Value *current_version;
        Instruction **def_chain;
        size_t def_count;
    } memory;
    
    // Alias information
    AliasAnalysis *alias;
} MemorySSA;

static void build_memory_ssa(SSAConstructor *ssa) {
    MemorySSA mem_ssa = {0};
    mem_ssa.alias = create_alias_analysis(ssa->cfg);
    
    // Insert memory φ-nodes
    insert_memory_phi_nodes(ssa, &mem_ssa);
    
    // Rename memory operations
    rename_memory_operations(ssa, &mem_ssa);
    
    free_alias_analysis(mem_ssa.alias);
}

static void insert_memory_phi_nodes(SSAConstructor *ssa, MemorySSA *mem_ssa) {
    // Collect blocks with memory definitions (stores)
    BlockSet *mem_defs = blockset_new(ssa->cfg->block_count);
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ssa->cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = ssa->cfg->blocks[i];
        for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
            if (is_memory_def(inst)) {
                blockset_add(mem_defs, block->id);
                break;
            }
        }
    }
    
    // Insert φ-nodes at dominance frontiers
    BlockSet *worklist = blockset_copy(mem_defs);
    BlockSet *has_phi = blockset_new(ssa->cfg->block_count);
    
    while (!blockset_empty(worklist)) {
        BasicBlock *block = blockset_pop(worklist);
        
        BitSetIterator it = bitset_iterator(block->df);
        size_t df_block_id;
        while (bitset_next(&it, &df_block_id)) {
            if (!blockset_contains(has_phi, df_block_id)) {
                BasicBlock *df_block = ssa->cfg->blocks[df_block_id];
                insert_memory_phi(ssa, df_block);
                blockset_add(has_phi, df_block_id);
                blockset_add(worklist, df_block_id);
            }
        }
    }
    
    blockset_free(mem_defs);
    blockset_free(worklist);
    blockset_free(has_phi);
}

static bool is_memory_def(Instruction *inst) {
    switch (inst->kind) {
        case INST_STORE:
        case INST_STORE_FIELD:
        case INST_STORE_ELEMENT:
        case INST_CALL:  // Conservatively assume calls modify memory
            return true;
        default:
            return false;
    }
}

static void insert_memory_phi(SSAConstructor *ssa, BasicBlock *block) {
    // Create memory φ-node
    Instruction *phi = calloc(1, sizeof(Instruction));
    phi->kind = INST_MEMORY_PHI;
    phi->block = block;
    
    // Create result representing new memory state
    phi->result = calloc(1, sizeof(Value));
    phi->result->kind = VALUE_MEMORY;
    phi->result->type = get_memory_type();
    phi->result->def = phi;
    
    // Initialize incoming arrays
    phi->data.phi.incoming_count = block->predecessor_count;
    phi->data.phi.incoming_values = calloc(block->predecessor_count,
                                          sizeof(Value*));
    phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks = calloc(block->predecessor_count,
                                          sizeof(BasicBlock*));
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < block->predecessor_count; i++) {
        phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks[i] = block->predecessors[i];
    }
    
    // Insert after regular φ-nodes
    Instruction *insert_after = NULL;
    for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
        if (inst->kind != INST_PHI) break;
        insert_after = inst;
    }
    
    if (insert_after) {
        phi->next = insert_after->next;
        phi->prev = insert_after;
        if (insert_after->next) {
            insert_after->next->prev = phi;
        } else {
            block->last = phi;
        }
        insert_after->next = phi;
    } else {
        // Insert at beginning
        phi->next = block->first;
        if (block->first) {
            block->first->prev = phi;
        }
        block->first = phi;
        if (!block->last) {
            block->last = phi;
        }
    }
    block->instruction_count++;
}

5.7 SSA Destruction

For code generation, SSA form must eventually be deconstructed:

typedef struct SSADestructor {
    CFG *cfg;
    
    // Copy instructions to insert
    struct {
        BasicBlock *block;
        Value *src;
        Value *dest;
    } *copies;
    size_t copy_count;
    size_t copy_capacity;
} SSADestructor;

void destruct_ssa(CFG *cfg) {
    SSADestructor destructor = {0};
    destructor.cfg = cfg;
    
    // Replace φ-nodes with copies
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        replace_phi_nodes(&destructor, cfg->blocks[i]);
    }
    
    // Insert copy instructions
    insert_copies(&destructor);
    
    // Coalesce copies where possible
    coalesce_copies(&destructor);
    
    free(destructor.copies);
}

static void replace_phi_nodes(SSADestructor *dest, BasicBlock *block) {
    Instruction *inst = block->first;
    while (inst && inst->kind == INST_PHI) {
        Instruction *next = inst->next;
        
        // Schedule copies from predecessors
        for (size_t i = 0; i < inst->data.phi.incoming_count; i++) {
            BasicBlock *pred = inst->data.phi.incoming_blocks[i];
            Value *src = inst->data.phi.incoming_values[i];
            Value *dst = inst->result;
            
            if (src != dst) {  // Avoid self-copies
                add_copy(dest, pred, src, dst);
            }
        }
        
        // Remove φ-node
        remove_instruction(inst);
        
        inst = next;
    }
}

static void add_copy(SSADestructor *dest, BasicBlock *block,
                    Value *src, Value *dest_val) {
    if (dest->copy_count >= dest->copy_capacity) {
        dest->copy_capacity = dest->copy_capacity * 2 + 16;
        dest->copies = realloc(dest->copies,
            dest->copy_capacity * sizeof(dest->copies[0]));
    }
    
    dest->copies[dest->copy_count].block = block;
    dest->copies[dest->copy_count].src = src;
    dest->copies[dest->copy_count].dest = dest_val;
    dest->copy_count++;
}

static void insert_copies(SSADestructor *dest) {
    // Group copies by block
    qsort(dest->copies, dest->copy_count, sizeof(dest->copies[0]),
          compare_copies_by_block);
    
    // Insert parallel copies at end of each predecessor
    size_t i = 0;
    while (i < dest->copy_count) {
        BasicBlock *block = dest->copies[i].block;
        size_t start = i;
        
        // Find all copies for this block
        while (i < dest->copy_count && dest->copies[i].block == block) {
            i++;
        }
        
        // Insert parallel copy
        insert_parallel_copy(block, &dest->copies[start], i - start);
    }
}

static void insert_parallel_copy(BasicBlock *block, 
                               struct { BasicBlock *block; Value *src; Value *dest; } *copies,
                               size_t count) {
    // Handle simple cases
    if (count == 1) {
        emit_copy_before_terminator(block, copies[0].src, copies[0].dest);
        return;
    }
    
    // Detect cycles in parallel assignment
    bool *visited = calloc(count, sizeof(bool));
    bool *in_cycle = calloc(count, sizeof(bool));
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < count; i++) {
        if (!visited[i]) {
            detect_copy_cycle(copies, count, i, visited, in_cycle);
        }
    }
    
    // Insert copies, handling cycles
    Value *temp = NULL;
    for (size_t i = 0; i < count; i++) {
        if (in_cycle[i] && !temp) {
            // Break cycle with temporary
            temp = create_temp_value(copies[i].src->type);
            emit_copy_before_terminator(block, copies[i].src, temp);
            copies[i].src = temp;
        }
    }
    
    // Now insert all copies
    for (size_t i = 0; i < count; i++) {
        emit_copy_before_terminator(block, copies[i].src, copies[i].dest);
    }
    
    free(visited);
    free(in_cycle);
}

5.8 SSA Validation

After construction, we validate the SSA properties:

typedef struct SSAValidator {
    CFG *cfg;
    bool has_errors;
    ErrorList *errors;
} SSAValidator;

bool validate_ssa(CFG *cfg) {
    SSAValidator validator = {0};
    validator.cfg = cfg;
    validator.errors = create_error_list();
    
    // Check each block
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        validate_block_ssa(&validator, cfg->blocks[i]);
    }
    
    // Check dominance properties
    validate_dominance_properties(&validator);
    
    if (validator.has_errors) {
        print_error_list(validator.errors);
    }
    
    free_error_list(validator.errors);
    return !validator.has_errors;
}

static void validate_block_ssa(SSAValidator *val, BasicBlock *block) {
    // Check φ-nodes are at beginning
    bool seen_non_phi = false;
    for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
        if (inst->kind == INST_PHI) {
            if (seen_non_phi) {
                add_error(val, inst, "φ-node not at beginning of block");
            }
            
            // Check φ-node operands
            if (inst->data.phi.incoming_count != block->predecessor_count) {
                add_error(val, inst, "φ-node operand count mismatch");
            }
            
            for (size_t i = 0; i < inst->data.phi.incoming_count; i++) {
                if (!inst->data.phi.incoming_values[i]) {
                    add_error(val, inst, "φ-node missing operand");
                }
            }
        } else {
            seen_non_phi = true;
        }
        
        // Check single definition
        if (inst->result) {
            validate_single_definition(val, inst->result);
        }
        
        // Check uses are dominated by definitions
        for (size_t i = 0; i < inst->operand_count; i++) {
            validate_use_dominance(val, inst, inst->operands[i]);
        }
    }
}

static void validate_single_definition(SSAValidator *val, Value *value) {
    if (value->kind != VALUE_TEMP) return;
    
    // Count definitions
    size_t def_count = 0;
    for (size_t i = 0; i < val->cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = val->cfg->blocks[i];
        for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
            if (inst->result == value) {
                def_count++;
            }
        }
    }
    
    if (def_count != 1) {
        add_error(val, value->def, "Value has %zu definitions", def_count);
    }
}

static void validate_use_dominance(SSAValidator *val, Instruction *use,
                                 Value *value) {
    if (!value->def) return;  // Parameters, constants, etc.
    
    BasicBlock *def_block = value->def->block;
    BasicBlock *use_block = use->block;
    
    // Special case: φ-node uses come from predecessors
    if (use->kind == INST_PHI) {
        // Find which predecessor this value comes from
        for (size_t i = 0; i < use->data.phi.incoming_count; i++) {
            if (use->data.phi.incoming_values[i] == value) {
                use_block = use->data.phi.incoming_blocks[i];
                break;
            }
        }
    }
    
    // Check dominance
    if (!dominates(def_block, use_block)) {
        add_error(val, use, "Use not dominated by definition");
    }
}

5.9 SSA Optimizations

Once in SSA form, several optimizations become straightforward:

void optimize_ssa(CFG *cfg) {
    bool changed;
    do {
        changed = false;
        
        // Dead code elimination
        changed |= eliminate_dead_code(cfg);
        
        // Constant propagation
        changed |= propagate_constants(cfg);
        
        // Copy propagation
        changed |= propagate_copies(cfg);
        
        // Common subexpression elimination
        changed |= eliminate_common_subexpressions(cfg);
        
        // Strength reduction
        changed |= reduce_strength(cfg);
        
    } while (changed);
}

static bool eliminate_dead_code(CFG *cfg) {
    bool changed = false;
    
    // Mark live values
    BitSet *live = bitset_new(cfg->next_value_id);
    mark_live_values(cfg, live);
    
    // Remove dead instructions
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = cfg->blocks[i];
        Instruction *inst = block->first;
        
        while (inst) {
            Instruction *next = inst->next;
            
            if (inst->result && !bitset_test(live, inst->result->id) &&
                !has_side_effects(inst)) {
                remove_instruction(inst);
                changed = true;
            }
            
            inst = next;
        }
    }
    
    bitset_free(live);
    return changed;
}

static bool propagate_constants(CFG *cfg) {
    bool changed = false;
    
    // Build constant map
    ValueMap *constants = valuemap_new();
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = cfg->blocks[i];
        
        for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
            if (is_constant_instruction(inst)) {
                valuemap_put(constants, inst->result, 
                           evaluate_constant(inst));
            }
            
            // Replace uses with constants
            for (size_t j = 0; j < inst->operand_count; j++) {
                Value *const_val = valuemap_get(constants, inst->operands[j]);
                if (const_val) {
                    inst->operands[j] = const_val;
                    changed = true;
                }
            }
            
            // Fold constant expressions
            if (all_operands_constant(inst)) {
                Value *result = fold_constant_expression(inst);
                if (result) {
                    replace_instruction_with_value(inst, result);
                    valuemap_put(constants, inst->result, result);
                    changed = true;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    valuemap_free(constants);
    return changed;
}

5.10 Summary

This chapter detailed Diyrbal's SSA form generation, following the classic Cytron et al. algorithm. The key components are:

  1. Variable Collection: Identifying all variables that need SSA form
  2. φ-Node Insertion: Placing φ-nodes at dominance frontiers
  3. Variable Renaming: Assigning unique names through dominator tree traversal
  4. Memory SSA: Extending SSA to handle memory operations
  5. SSA Destruction: Converting back to conventional form for code generation
  6. Validation: Ensuring SSA properties are maintained
  7. Optimizations: Leveraging SSA form for powerful transformations

The SSA form serves as the foundation for most of Diyrbal's optimizations and analyses. The next chapter will explore the type inference system that operates on this SSA representation.

Chapter 6: Interpretable SSA Design

6.1 Introduction

Traditional SSA form, while excellent for optimization, presents challenges for direct interpretation. φ-nodes lack operational semantics, and the simultaneous assignment assumption doesn't map to sequential execution. This chapter presents Interpretable SSA (ISSA) form, a variant designed for efficient interpretation while maintaining SSA's analytical benefits.

Drawing inspiration from the VM-SSA paper in our references, ISSA makes three key contributions:

  1. Executable φ-nodes with well-defined operational semantics
  2. Memory SSA with directly interpretable array operations
  3. Efficient value representation optimized for interpretation

6.2 Design Principles

ISSA follows several core principles:

// Core ISSA design principles encoded in the IR structure
typedef enum ISSADesignPrinciple {
    ISSA_SELF_CONTAINED,      // Each instruction has complete semantics
    ISSA_NO_SIDE_EFFECTS,     // φ-nodes are pure operations
    ISSA_DIRECT_EXECUTABLE,   // No lowering needed for interpretation
    ISSA_MEMORY_EXPLICIT,     // All memory operations in SSA form
    ISSA_TYPE_SAFE            // Type information preserved at runtime
} ISSADesignPrinciple;

typedef struct ISSAInstruction {
    InstructionKind kind;
    
    // Self-contained execution context
    struct {
        Value **inputs;
        size_t input_count;
        Value *output;
        
        // For φ-nodes: which input to select
        size_t selected_input;
        
        // For memory operations: memory version
        Value *memory_in;
        Value *memory_out;
    } exec;
    
    // Type information for interpretation
    Type *type;
    
    // Direct execution function pointer
    void (*execute)(struct ISSAInstruction *inst, ExecutionContext *ctx);
} ISSAInstruction;

6.3 Executable φ-Nodes

The key innovation is making φ-nodes directly executable:

typedef struct PhiNode {
    ISSAInstruction base;
    
    // Incoming edges and values
    struct {
        BasicBlock *block;
        Value *value;
        size_t block_id;  // For fast lookup during execution
    } *inputs;
    size_t input_count;
    
    // Runtime selector
    size_t (*selector)(struct PhiNode *phi, ExecutionContext *ctx);
} PhiNode;

// φ-node execution is simply selecting the right input
static void execute_phi(ISSAInstruction *inst, ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    PhiNode *phi = (PhiNode*)inst;
    
    // Determine which predecessor we came from
    size_t selected = phi->selector(phi, ctx);
    
    // φ-node execution is just copying the selected value
    copy_value(inst->exec.output, phi->inputs[selected].value);
    
    // Update execution statistics
    ctx->stats.phi_executed++;
}

// Fast predecessor lookup using block IDs
static size_t select_phi_input(PhiNode *phi, ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    size_t last_block_id = ctx->last_block_id;
    
    // Common case: binary search for small φ-nodes
    if (phi->input_count <= 4) {
        for (size_t i = 0; i < phi->input_count; i++) {
            if (phi->inputs[i].block_id == last_block_id) {
                return i;
            }
        }
    } else {
        // Use hash table for large φ-nodes
        return phi_input_table_lookup(phi, last_block_id);
    }
    
    // Should never happen in well-formed SSA
    panic("φ-node input not found for block %zu", last_block_id);
}

6.4 Value Representation

ISSA uses a tagged value representation optimized for interpretation:

// Tagged value representation for efficient interpretation
typedef struct ISSAValue {
    ValueKind kind;
    
    union {
        // Immediate values (no allocation)
        int64_t int_val;
        double float_val;
        bool bool_val;
        
        // Heap-allocated values
        struct {
            void *ptr;
            size_t size;
            TypeInfo *type;
        } heap;
        
        // SSA temporaries
        struct {
            uint32_t version;
            uint32_t var_id;
            ISSAInstruction *def;
        } ssa;
        
        // Memory version
        struct {
            uint64_t version;
            MemoryState *state;
        } memory;
        
        // Array values (for memory SSA)
        struct {
            ISSAValue *elements;
            size_t length;
            size_t capacity;
            Type *elem_type;
        } array;
    } data;
    
    // Reference counting for memory management
    uint32_t ref_count;
    
    // Type tag for runtime type checking
    uint16_t type_tag;
} ISSAValue;

// Efficient value operations
static inline void retain_value(ISSAValue *val) {
    if (val && is_heap_allocated(val)) {
        val->ref_count++;
    }
}

static inline void release_value(ISSAValue *val) {
    if (val && is_heap_allocated(val) && --val->ref_count == 0) {
        free_value(val);
    }
}

static inline bool is_heap_allocated(ISSAValue *val) {
    switch (val->kind) {
        case VALUE_STRING:
        case VALUE_ARRAY:
        case VALUE_STRUCT:
        case VALUE_CLOSURE:
            return true;
        default:
            return false;
    }
}

6.5 Memory SSA in ISSA

ISSA extends SSA to memory operations with directly interpretable semantics:

// Memory SSA instructions
typedef enum MemorySSAOp {
    MEM_PHI,          // Memory φ-node
    MEM_LOAD,         // Load with memory version
    MEM_STORE,        // Store producing new memory version
    MEM_ARRAY_GET,    // Array access in SSA form
    MEM_ARRAY_SET,    // Array update in SSA form
} MemorySSAOp;

typedef struct MemoryPhi {
    ISSAInstruction base;
    
    // Memory versions from predecessors
    ISSAValue **memory_inputs;
    size_t input_count;
    
    // Resulting memory version
    ISSAValue *memory_out;
} MemoryPhi;

typedef struct ArrayOperation {
    ISSAInstruction base;
    
    ISSAValue *array_in;
    ISSAValue *index;
    ISSAValue *value;  // For SET operations
    
    // Result (new array version for SET, element for GET)
    ISSAValue *result;
} ArrayOperation;

// Direct execution of array operations
static void execute_array_get(ISSAInstruction *inst, ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    ArrayOperation *op = (ArrayOperation*)inst;
    
    size_t idx = value_to_size(op->index);
    if (idx >= op->array_in->data.array.length) {
        runtime_error(ctx, "Array index out of bounds");
        return;
    }
    
    // Direct access - no copying needed in SSA form
    op->result = &op->array_in->data.array.elements[idx];
    retain_value(op->result);
}

static void execute_array_set(ISSAInstruction *inst, ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    ArrayOperation *op = (ArrayOperation*)inst;
    
    size_t idx = value_to_size(op->index);
    size_t len = op->array_in->data.array.length;
    
    if (idx >= len) {
        runtime_error(ctx, "Array index out of bounds");
        return;
    }
    
    // Create new array version (functional update)
    ISSAValue *new_array = allocate_array(len, 
                                         op->array_in->data.array.elem_type);
    
    // Copy all elements
    for (size_t i = 0; i < len; i++) {
        if (i == idx) {
            new_array->data.array.elements[i] = *op->value;
            retain_value(op->value);
        } else {
            new_array->data.array.elements[i] = 
                op->array_in->data.array.elements[i];
            retain_value(&op->array_in->data.array.elements[i]);
        }
    }
    
    op->result = new_array;
}

6.6 Instruction Execution Architecture

ISSA uses direct threading for efficient interpretation:

typedef struct ExecutionContext {
    // Current execution state
    BasicBlock *current_block;
    ISSAInstruction *current_inst;
    size_t last_block_id;
    
    // Value storage
    ISSAValue *locals;
    size_t local_count;
    
    // Memory state
    MemoryState *memory;
    
    // Call stack
    struct CallFrame {
        Function *function;
        ISSAValue *return_value;
        BasicBlock *return_block;
        ISSAInstruction *return_inst;
        ISSAValue *saved_locals;
        size_t saved_local_count;
    } *call_stack;
    size_t call_depth;
    size_t max_call_depth;
    
    // Execution statistics
    struct {
        size_t instructions_executed;
        size_t phi_executed;
        size_t memory_ops;
        size_t array_ops;
    } stats;
    
    // Error handling
    jmp_buf error_handler;
    char error_message[256];
} ExecutionContext;

// Main interpreter loop using direct threading
void interpret_issa(Function *entry, ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    ctx->current_block = entry->cfg->entry;
    ctx->current_inst = ctx->current_block->first;
    
    // Set up error handling
    if (setjmp(ctx->error_handler) != 0) {
        // Error occurred
        fprintf(stderr, "Runtime error: %s\n", ctx->error_message);
        return;
    }
    
    // Direct-threaded interpreter loop
    while (ctx->current_inst) {
        ISSAInstruction *inst = ctx->current_inst;
        
        // Execute instruction through function pointer
        inst->execute(inst, ctx);
        
        ctx->stats.instructions_executed++;
        
        // Move to next instruction
        if (inst->kind == INST_BR || inst->kind == INST_BR_COND ||
            inst->kind == INST_RET) {
            // Control flow handled by instruction
        } else {
            ctx->current_inst = inst->base.next;
        }
    }
}

// Optimized instruction dispatch table
static const InstructionExecutor instruction_table[] = {
    [INST_PHI] = execute_phi,
    [INST_ADD] = execute_arithmetic,
    [INST_SUB] = execute_arithmetic,
    [INST_MUL] = execute_arithmetic,
    [INST_DIV] = execute_arithmetic,
    [INST_LOAD] = execute_load,
    [INST_STORE] = execute_store,
    [INST_BR] = execute_branch,
    [INST_BR_COND] = execute_conditional_branch,
    [INST_CALL] = execute_call,
    [INST_RET] = execute_return,
    [MEM_PHI] = execute_memory_phi,
    [MEM_ARRAY_GET] = execute_array_get,
    [MEM_ARRAY_SET] = execute_array_set,
};

6.7 Control Flow Handling

ISSA handles control flow explicitly to support φ-node execution:

static void execute_branch(ISSAInstruction *inst, ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    BranchInst *br = (BranchInst*)inst;
    
    // Record current block for φ-node resolution
    ctx->last_block_id = ctx->current_block->id;
    
    // Jump to target
    ctx->current_block = br->target;
    ctx->current_inst = br->target->first;
}

static void execute_conditional_branch(ISSAInstruction *inst, 
                                     ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    CondBranchInst *br = (CondBranchInst*)inst;
    
    bool condition = value_to_bool(br->condition);
    
    ctx->last_block_id = ctx->current_block->id;
    
    if (condition) {
        ctx->current_block = br->true_target;
        ctx->current_inst = br->true_target->first;
    } else {
        ctx->current_block = br->false_target;
        ctx->current_inst = br->false_target->first;
    }
}

// Special handling for φ-nodes at block entry
static void enter_block(ExecutionContext *ctx, BasicBlock *block) {
    // Execute all φ-nodes at block entry
    for (ISSAInstruction *inst = block->first; 
         inst && inst->kind == INST_PHI; 
         inst = inst->base.next) {
        inst->execute(inst, ctx);
    }
}

6.8 Optimization for Interpretation

ISSA includes several optimizations specifically for interpretation:

// Instruction fusion for common patterns
typedef struct FusedInstruction {
    ISSAInstruction base;
    
    // Fused operation (e.g., LOAD + ADD + STORE)
    ISSAInstruction **fused_ops;
    size_t op_count;
} FusedInstruction;

static void optimize_for_interpretation(Function *func) {
    // Instruction fusion
    fuse_common_patterns(func);
    
    // φ-node specialization
    specialize_phi_nodes(func);
    
    // Memory operation coalescing
    coalesce_memory_ops(func);
    
    // Inline small functions
    inline_small_functions(func);
}

// Specialize φ-nodes for common cases
static void specialize_phi_nodes(Function *func) {
    for (size_t i = 0; i < func->cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = func->cfg->blocks[i];
        
        for (ISSAInstruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
            if (inst->kind == INST_PHI) {
                PhiNode *phi = (PhiNode*)inst;
                
                if (phi->input_count == 2) {
                    // Binary φ-node - use specialized executor
                    inst->execute = execute_binary_phi;
                } else if (all_inputs_same_value(phi)) {
                    // Degenerate φ-node - replace with copy
                    replace_with_copy(inst, phi->inputs[0].value);
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

// Optimized binary φ-node execution
static void execute_binary_phi(ISSAInstruction *inst, ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    PhiNode *phi = (PhiNode*)inst;
    
    // Fast path for binary φ-nodes
    if (ctx->last_block_id == phi->inputs[0].block_id) {
        copy_value(inst->exec.output, phi->inputs[0].value);
    } else {
        copy_value(inst->exec.output, phi->inputs[1].value);
    }
    
    ctx->stats.phi_executed++;
}

6.9 Type Safety in ISSA

ISSA maintains type safety during interpretation:

typedef struct TypeInfo {
    TypeKind kind;
    size_t size;
    size_t alignment;
    
    // For compound types
    union {
        struct {
            TypeInfo *element_type;
            size_t length;
        } array;
        
        struct {
            TypeInfo **field_types;
            char **field_names;
            size_t field_count;
        } struct_type;
        
        struct {
            TypeInfo *return_type;
            TypeInfo **param_types;
            size_t param_count;
        } function;
    } data;
    
    // Runtime type checking
    bool (*check_value)(ISSAValue *val, TypeInfo *expected);
} TypeInfo;

// Type-checked operations
static void execute_typed_operation(ISSAInstruction *inst, 
                                  ExecutionContext *ctx) {
    // Verify input types
    for (size_t i = 0; i < inst->exec.input_count; i++) {
        if (!check_value_type(inst->exec.inputs[i], 
                            inst->type->data.function.param_types[i])) {
            runtime_error(ctx, "Type mismatch in operation %s", 
                         instruction_name(inst->kind));
            return;
        }
    }
    
    // Execute operation
    inst->execute(inst, ctx);
    
    // Verify output type
    if (!check_value_type(inst->exec.output, 
                        inst->type->data.function.return_type)) {
        runtime_error(ctx, "Invalid output type from %s", 
                     instruction_name(inst->kind));
    }
}

6.10 ISSA Construction Algorithm

Converting standard SSA to ISSA:

typedef struct ISSABuilder {
    CFG *input_cfg;
    Function *output_func;
    
    // Mapping from SSA values to ISSA values
    ValueMap *value_map;
    
    // Memory version tracking
    ISSAValue *current_memory;
    
    // Statistics
    size_t instructions_converted;
    size_t phi_nodes_converted;
    size_t memory_phis_inserted;
} ISSABuilder;

Function* build_issa(CFG *cfg) {
    ISSABuilder builder = {0};
    builder.input_cfg = cfg;
    builder.value_map = valuemap_new();
    
    // Create function
    builder.output_func = create_issa_function(cfg->function);
    
    // Convert basic blocks
    for (size_t i = 0; i < cfg->block_count; i++) {
        convert_block(&builder, cfg->blocks[i]);
    }
    
    // Set up φ-node selectors
    setup_phi_selectors(&builder);
    
    // Optimize for interpretation
    optimize_for_interpretation(builder.output_func);
    
    valuemap_free(builder.value_map);
    return builder.output_func;
}

static void convert_block(ISSABuilder *builder, BasicBlock *block) {
    BasicBlock *issa_block = create_issa_block(block);
    
    // Convert φ-nodes first
    for (Instruction *inst = block->first; 
         inst && inst->kind == INST_PHI; 
         inst = inst->next) {
        ISSAInstruction *issa_phi = convert_phi_node(builder, inst);
        append_instruction(issa_block, issa_phi);
    }
    
    // Convert other instructions
    for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
        if (inst->kind == INST_PHI) continue;
        
        ISSAInstruction *issa_inst = convert_instruction(builder, inst);
        append_instruction(issa_block, issa_inst);
    }
}

static ISSAInstruction* convert_phi_node(ISSABuilder *builder, 
                                       Instruction *phi) {
    PhiNode *issa_phi = calloc(1, sizeof(PhiNode));
    issa_phi->base.kind = INST_PHI;
    issa_phi->base.execute = execute_phi;
    issa_phi->selector = select_phi_input;
    
    // Convert inputs
    issa_phi->input_count = phi->data.phi.incoming_count;
    issa_phi->inputs = calloc(issa_phi->input_count, 
                            sizeof(issa_phi->inputs[0]));
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < issa_phi->input_count; i++) {
        issa_phi->inputs[i].block = phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks[i];
        issa_phi->inputs[i].block_id = phi->data.phi.incoming_blocks[i]->id;
        issa_phi->inputs[i].value = convert_value(builder, 
            phi->data.phi.incoming_values[i]);
    }
    
    // Create output value
    issa_phi->base.exec.output = create_issa_value(phi->result->type);
    valuemap_put(builder->value_map, phi->result, issa_phi->base.exec.output);
    
    builder->phi_nodes_converted++;
    return &issa_phi->base;
}

6.11 Performance Characteristics

ISSA's design yields specific performance characteristics:

// Performance monitoring
typedef struct ISSAPerformance {
    // Instruction execution counts
    uint64_t *instruction_counts;
    
    // Hot path detection
    struct HotPath {
        BasicBlock **blocks;
        size_t length;
        uint64_t execution_count;
    } *hot_paths;
    size_t hot_path_count;
    
    // φ-node execution patterns
    struct {
        uint64_t binary_phi;
        uint64_t multi_phi;
        uint64_t memory_phi;
    } phi_stats;
    
    // Cache behavior
    struct {
        uint64_t value_cache_hits;
        uint64_t value_cache_misses;
        uint64_t instruction_cache_hits;
        uint64_t instruction_cache_misses;
    } cache_stats;
} ISSAPerformance;

void profile_issa_execution(ExecutionContext *ctx, ISSAPerformance *perf) {
    // Instrument execution
