    ctx->profiling_enabled = true;
    ctx->performance = perf;
    
    // Track hot paths
    track_execution_paths(ctx);
    
    // Monitor φ-node patterns
    analyze_phi_patterns(ctx);
    
    // Measure cache effectiveness
    measure_cache_behavior(ctx);
}

// Adaptive optimization based on profiling
void adaptive_optimize_issa(Function *func, ISSAPerformance *perf) {
    // Specialize hot φ-nodes
    for (size_t i = 0; i < func->cfg->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = func->cfg->blocks[i];
        if (is_hot_block(block, perf)) {
            specialize_hot_phi_nodes(block, perf);
        }
    }
    
    // Inline hot paths
    for (size_t i = 0; i < perf->hot_path_count; i++) {
        if (perf->hot_paths[i].execution_count > HOT_PATH_THRESHOLD) {
            inline_hot_path(&perf->hot_paths[i]);
        }
    }
}

6.12 Comparison with Traditional SSA

ISSA differs from traditional SSA in several ways:

| Aspect | Traditional SSA | ISSA | |--------|----------------|------| | φ-nodes | Abstract merge | Executable selection | | Memory | Not in SSA | Full memory SSA | | Arrays | Indirect access | Functional updates | | Interpretation | Requires lowering | Direct execution | | Type safety | Compile-time only | Runtime + compile-time |

// Example: Traditional SSA vs ISSA for array access
// Traditional SSA:
//   %ptr = getelementptr %array, %index
//   %val = load %ptr
//
// ISSA:
//   %val = array.get %array, %index

// Example: φ-node execution
// Traditional SSA (requires resolution):
//   %x = phi [%a, %bb1], [%b, %bb2]
//
// ISSA (direct execution):
//   %x = phi [%a, %bb1], [%b, %bb2]  ; selector: last_block_id

6.13 Summary

Interpretable SSA (ISSA) form extends traditional SSA with directly executable semantics. Key innovations include:

  1. Executable φ-nodes that select inputs based on control flow
  2. Memory SSA with functional array operations
  3. Tagged values optimized for interpretation
  4. Direct threading for efficient instruction dispatch
  5. Type safety maintained at runtime
  6. Performance optimizations specific to interpretation

ISSA enables Diyrbal to combine the analytical power of SSA form with efficient interpretation, avoiding the overhead of lowering SSA for execution. This design is particularly effective for JIT compilation scenarios where interpretation performance matters.

The next chapter will explore how type inference operates on this ISSA representation.

Chapter 7: SSA-Based Optimizations

7.1 Introduction

SSA form enables powerful optimizations by making data flow explicit and providing unique naming for values. This chapter explores the optimization pipeline in Diyrbal, focusing on SSA-specific transformations that leverage the properties of both traditional SSA and our Interpretable SSA (ISSA) form.

The optimization framework operates in multiple phases:

  1. Early optimizations on initial SSA construction
  2. Core SSA optimizations leveraging SSA properties
  3. ISSA-specific optimizations for interpretation efficiency
  4. Late optimizations before code generation

7.2 Optimization Framework Architecture

typedef struct OptimizationPass {
    const char *name;
    OptimizationLevel min_level;
    
    // Pass execution function
    bool (*execute)(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx);
    
    // Dependencies and ordering
    const char **requires;
    const char **invalidates;
    
    // Pass-specific configuration
    void *config;
    
    // Statistics
    struct {
        uint64_t invocations;
        uint64_t transformations;
        double total_time;
    } stats;
} OptimizationPass;

typedef struct OptimizationPipeline {
    OptimizationPass **passes;
    size_t pass_count;
    
    // Global optimization context
    OptimizationContext *ctx;
    
    // Pass manager state
    struct {
        bool *completed;
        bool *invalidated;
    } pass_state;
    
    // Optimization levels
    OptimizationLevel level;
} OptimizationPipeline;

// Main optimization driver
void optimize_ssa_function(Function *func, OptimizationLevel level) {
    OptimizationPipeline pipeline = {0};
    pipeline.level = level;
    pipeline.ctx = create_optimization_context(func);
    
    // Register optimization passes
    register_early_passes(&pipeline);
    register_core_ssa_passes(&pipeline);
    register_issa_passes(&pipeline);
    register_late_passes(&pipeline);
    
    // Run passes to fixpoint
    bool changed = true;
    size_t iteration = 0;
    
    while (changed && iteration < MAX_OPT_ITERATIONS) {
        changed = false;
        
        for (size_t i = 0; i < pipeline.pass_count; i++) {
            if (should_run_pass(&pipeline, i)) {
                bool pass_changed = run_optimization_pass(&pipeline, i, func);
                changed |= pass_changed;
                
                if (pass_changed) {
                    invalidate_dependent_passes(&pipeline, i);
                }
            }
        }
        
        iteration++;
    }
    
    cleanup_optimization_context(pipeline.ctx);
}

7.3 Dead Code Elimination

SSA form makes dead code elimination particularly effective:

typedef struct DCEContext {
    BitSet *live_values;
    BitSet *live_instructions;
    WorkList *worklist;
    
    // Statistics
    size_t dead_instructions;
    size_t dead_phi_nodes;
    size_t dead_memory_ops;
} DCEContext;

bool dead_code_elimination(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    DCEContext dce = {0};
    dce.live_values = bitset_create(func->value_count);
    dce.live_instructions = bitset_create(func->instruction_count);
    dce.worklist = worklist_create();
    
    // Mark initially live instructions
    mark_essential_instructions(func, &dce);
    
    // Propagate liveness
    while (!worklist_empty(dce.worklist)) {
        Instruction *inst = worklist_pop(dce.worklist);
        
        // Mark instruction as live
        bitset_set(dce.live_instructions, inst->id);
        
        // Mark all operands as live
        for (size_t i = 0; i < inst->operand_count; i++) {
            Value *operand = inst->operands[i];
            
            if (!bitset_test(dce.live_values, operand->id)) {
                bitset_set(dce.live_values, operand->id);
                
                // Add defining instruction to worklist
                if (operand->def_instruction) {
                    worklist_push(dce.worklist, operand->def_instruction);
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    // Remove dead instructions
    bool changed = false;
    for (BasicBlock *block = func->cfg->entry; block; block = block->next) {
        Instruction *inst = block->first;
        while (inst) {
            Instruction *next = inst->next;
            
            if (!bitset_test(dce.live_instructions, inst->id)) {
                remove_instruction(block, inst);
                dce.dead_instructions++;
                changed = true;
                
                if (inst->kind == INST_PHI) {
                    dce.dead_phi_nodes++;
                }
            }
            
            inst = next;
        }
    }
    
    // Clean up empty blocks
    if (changed) {
        remove_empty_blocks(func->cfg);
    }
    
    bitset_destroy(dce.live_values);
    bitset_destroy(dce.live_instructions);
    worklist_destroy(dce.worklist);
    
    return changed;
}

// Essential instructions that are always live
static void mark_essential_instructions(Function *func, DCEContext *dce) {
    for (BasicBlock *block = func->cfg->entry; block; block = block->next) {
        for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
            if (is_essential_instruction(inst)) {
                worklist_push(dce->worklist, inst);
            }
        }
    }
}

static bool is_essential_instruction(Instruction *inst) {
    switch (inst->kind) {
        case INST_RET:
        case INST_BR:
        case INST_BR_COND:
        case INST_STORE:
        case INST_CALL:  // Assuming calls have side effects
            return true;
            
        case MEM_STORE:
        case MEM_ARRAY_SET:
            return true;  // Memory operations are essential
            
        default:
            return false;
    }
}

7.4 Constant Propagation and Folding

SSA's unique naming enables efficient constant propagation:

typedef struct ConstantPropContext {
    // Lattice values for each SSA value
    LatticeValue *values;
    size_t value_count;
    
    // SSA edges worklist
    WorkList *ssa_edges;
    
    // CFG edges worklist
    WorkList *cfg_edges;
    
    // Executable blocks
    BitSet *executable_blocks;
    
    // Statistics
    size_t constants_propagated;
    size_t instructions_folded;
} ConstantPropContext;

// Sparse Conditional Constant Propagation (SCCP)
bool sparse_conditional_constant_propagation(Function *func, 
                                            OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    ConstantPropContext sccp = {0};
    sccp.values = calloc(func->value_count, sizeof(LatticeValue));
    sccp.ssa_edges = worklist_create();
    sccp.cfg_edges = worklist_create();
    sccp.executable_blocks = bitset_create(func->cfg->block_count);
    
    // Initialize all values to TOP
    for (size_t i = 0; i < func->value_count; i++) {
        sccp.values[i] = LATTICE_TOP;
    }
    
    // Initialize function arguments
    initialize_arguments(&sccp, func);
    
    // Mark entry block as executable
    worklist_push(sccp.cfg_edges, func->cfg->entry);
    
    // Main SCCP algorithm
    while (!worklist_empty(sccp.cfg_edges) || !worklist_empty(sccp.ssa_edges)) {
        // Process CFG edges
        while (!worklist_empty(sccp.cfg_edges)) {
            BasicBlock *block = worklist_pop(sccp.cfg_edges);
            
            if (!bitset_test_and_set(sccp.executable_blocks, block->id)) {
                visit_block(&sccp, block);
            }
        }
        
        // Process SSA edges
        while (!worklist_empty(sccp.ssa_edges)) {
            Value *value = worklist_pop(sccp.ssa_edges);
            
            for (Use *use = value->use_list; use; use = use->next) {
                if (bitset_test(sccp.executable_blocks, 
                               use->instruction->block->id)) {
                    visit_instruction(&sccp, use->instruction);
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    // Replace constants and fold instructions
    bool changed = apply_constant_propagation(func, &sccp);
    
    cleanup_sccp_context(&sccp);
    return changed;
}

// Lattice meet operation
static LatticeValue lattice_meet(LatticeValue a, LatticeValue b) {
    if (a.kind == LATTICE_TOP) return b;
    if (b.kind == LATTICE_TOP) return a;
    if (a.kind == LATTICE_BOTTOM || b.kind == LATTICE_BOTTOM) {
        return (LatticeValue){.kind = LATTICE_BOTTOM};
    }
    
    // Both are constants
    if (values_equal(&a.constant, &b.constant)) {
        return a;
    }
    
    return (LatticeValue){.kind = LATTICE_BOTTOM};
}

// Visit φ-node with SCCP
static void visit_phi(ConstantPropContext *sccp, PhiNode *phi) {
    LatticeValue result = LATTICE_TOP;
    
    // Only consider executable predecessors
    for (size_t i = 0; i < phi->incoming_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *pred = phi->incoming_blocks[i];
        
        if (bitset_test(sccp->executable_blocks, pred->id)) {
            Value *input = phi->incoming_values[i];
            LatticeValue input_val = sccp->values[input->id];
            
            result = lattice_meet(result, input_val);
            
            if (result.kind == LATTICE_BOTTOM) {
                break;  // No need to continue
            }
        }
    }
    
    // Update φ-node result
    update_value(sccp, phi->result, result);
}

// Constant folding for arithmetic operations
static void visit_arithmetic(ConstantPropContext *sccp, Instruction *inst) {
    Value *left = inst->operands[0];
    Value *right = inst->operands[1];
    
    LatticeValue left_val = sccp->values[left->id];
    LatticeValue right_val = sccp->values[right->id];
    
    if (left_val.kind == LATTICE_CONSTANT && 
        right_val.kind == LATTICE_CONSTANT) {
        // Fold the operation
        Value folded = fold_arithmetic_op(inst->kind, 
                                        &left_val.constant, 
                                        &right_val.constant);
        
        update_value(sccp, inst->result, 
                    (LatticeValue){
                        .kind = LATTICE_CONSTANT,
                        .constant = folded
                    });
        
        sccp->instructions_folded++;
    } else if (left_val.kind == LATTICE_BOTTOM || 
               right_val.kind == LATTICE_BOTTOM) {
        update_value(sccp, inst->result, LATTICE_BOTTOM);
    }
}

7.5 Global Value Numbering

SSA form enables efficient global value numbering:

typedef struct GVNContext {
    // Value number assignments
    HashMap *value_numbers;
    uint32_t next_number;
    
    // Congruence classes
    struct CongruenceClass {
        uint32_t number;
        Value **values;
        size_t value_count;
        size_t capacity;
    } *classes;
    size_t class_count;
    
    // Expression hash table
    HashMap *expressions;
    
    // Statistics
    size_t redundancies_eliminated;
} GVNContext;

bool global_value_numbering(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    GVNContext gvn = {0};
    gvn.value_numbers = hashmap_create();
    gvn.expressions = hashmap_create();
    
    // Process blocks in RPO for better results
    BasicBlock **rpo = compute_reverse_postorder(func->cfg);
    size_t block_count = func->cfg->block_count;
    
    // Initial pass: assign value numbers
    for (size_t i = 0; i < block_count; i++) {
        process_block_gvn(&gvn, rpo[i]);
    }
    
    // Eliminate redundancies
    bool changed = eliminate_redundancies(&gvn, func);
    
    free(rpo);
    cleanup_gvn_context(&gvn);
    return changed;
}

// Process instruction for GVN
static void process_instruction_gvn(GVNContext *gvn, Instruction *inst) {
    switch (inst->kind) {
        case INST_ADD:
        case INST_SUB:
        case INST_MUL:
        case INST_DIV:
            process_arithmetic_gvn(gvn, inst);
            break;
            
        case INST_PHI:
            process_phi_gvn(gvn, inst);
            break;
            
        case INST_LOAD:
            process_load_gvn(gvn, inst);
            break;
            
        default:
            // Assign unique value number
            assign_value_number(gvn, inst->result, gvn->next_number++);
    }
}

// Handle commutative operations
static void process_arithmetic_gvn(GVNContext *gvn, Instruction *inst) {
    uint32_t left_vn = get_value_number(gvn, inst->operands[0]);
    uint32_t right_vn = get_value_number(gvn, inst->operands[1]);
    
    // Normalize commutative operations
    if (is_commutative(inst->kind) && left_vn > right_vn) {
        uint32_t temp = left_vn;
        left_vn = right_vn;
        right_vn = temp;
    }
    
    // Create expression hash
    Expression expr = {
        .opcode = inst->kind,
        .operands = {left_vn, right_vn},
        .operand_count = 2
    };
    
    // Check if expression already exists
    uint32_t *existing_vn = hashmap_get(gvn->expressions, &expr);
    
    if (existing_vn) {
        // Reuse existing value number
        assign_value_number(gvn, inst->result, *existing_vn);
        add_to_congruence_class(gvn, *existing_vn, inst->result);
    } else {
        // Create new value number
        uint32_t new_vn = gvn->next_number++;
        assign_value_number(gvn, inst->result, new_vn);
        
        // Remember this expression
        hashmap_put(gvn->expressions, &expr, &new_vn);
        create_congruence_class(gvn, new_vn, inst->result);
    }
}

// Load-store optimization with GVN
static void process_load_gvn(GVNContext *gvn, Instruction *inst) {
    LoadInst *load = (LoadInst*)inst;
    
    // Find available loads to the same address
    AvailableLoad *avail = find_available_load(gvn, load->address, 
                                              load->memory_version);
    
    if (avail && !may_alias(load, avail)) {
        // Reuse previous load
        assign_value_number(gvn, inst->result, 
                          get_value_number(gvn, avail->value));
        gvn->redundancies_eliminated++;
    } else {
        // New load
        uint32_t new_vn = gvn->next_number++;
        assign_value_number(gvn, inst->result, new_vn);
        
        // Record as available
        record_available_load(gvn, load);
    }
}

7.6 Loop Optimizations in SSA

SSA form simplifies many loop optimizations:

typedef struct LoopInfo {
    BasicBlock *header;
    BasicBlock *preheader;
    BasicBlock **blocks;
    size_t block_count;
    
    // Loop exits
    struct LoopExit {
        BasicBlock *exiting_block;
        BasicBlock *exit_block;
    } *exits;
    size_t exit_count;
    
    // Nested loops
    struct LoopInfo *parent;
    struct LoopInfo **children;
    size_t child_count;
    
    // Loop properties
    bool is_natural;
    bool is_reducible;
    bool has_single_exit;
} LoopInfo;

// Loop-Invariant Code Motion (LICM)
bool loop_invariant_code_motion(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    LoopInfo **loops = identify_loops(func->cfg);
    size_t loop_count = count_loops(loops);
    
    bool changed = false;
    
    // Process loops from innermost to outermost
    for (size_t i = 0; i < loop_count; i++) {
        LoopInfo *loop = loops[i];
        
        if (!loop->parent || all_children_processed(loop)) {
            changed |= hoist_loop_invariants(loop, func);
        }
    }
    
    free_loop_info(loops);
    return changed;
}

// Identify loop-invariant instructions
static bool hoist_loop_invariants(LoopInfo *loop, Function *func) {
    bool changed = false;
    BitSet *invariant = bitset_create(func->instruction_count);
    
    // Find loop-invariant instructions
    bool found_new = true;
    while (found_new) {
        found_new = false;
        
        for (size_t i = 0; i < loop->block_count; i++) {
            BasicBlock *block = loop->blocks[i];
            
            for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
                if (!bitset_test(invariant, inst->id) && 
                    is_loop_invariant(inst, loop, invariant)) {
                    bitset_set(invariant, inst->id);
                    found_new = true;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    // Hoist invariant instructions
    for (size_t i = 0; i < loop->block_count; i++) {
        BasicBlock *block = loop->blocks[i];
        Instruction *inst = block->first;
        
        while (inst) {
            Instruction *next = inst->next;
            
            if (bitset_test(invariant, inst->id) && 
                safe_to_hoist(inst, loop)) {
                hoist_instruction(inst, loop->preheader);
                changed = true;
            }
            
            inst = next;
        }
    }
    
    bitset_destroy(invariant);
    return changed;
}

// Loop strength reduction
typedef struct InductionVariable {
    PhiNode *phi;
    Value *initial_value;
    Value *increment;
    
    enum {
        IV_BASIC,
        IV_DERIVED
    } kind;
    
    // For derived IVs
    struct InductionVariable *base;
    Value *scale;
    Value *offset;
} InductionVariable;

static bool strength_reduce_loop(LoopInfo *loop, Function *func) {
    // Find induction variables
    InductionVariable **ivs = find_induction_variables(loop);
    size_t iv_count = count_induction_variables(ivs);
    
    bool changed = false;
    
    // Replace expensive operations on IVs
    for (size_t i = 0; i < iv_count; i++) {
        InductionVariable *iv = ivs[i];
        
        // Find uses of this IV
        for (Use *use = iv->phi->result->use_list; use; use = use->next) {
            Instruction *user = use->instruction;
            
            if (user->kind == INST_MUL && is_loop_invariant_value(
                    get_other_operand(user, iv->phi->result), loop)) {
                // Replace multiplication with addition
                changed |= replace_mul_with_add(user, iv, loop);
            }
        }
    }
    
    free_induction_variables(ivs);
    return changed;
}

7.7 Memory SSA Optimizations

Memory SSA enables precise memory optimizations:

typedef struct MemorySSAOptContext {
    // Alias analysis results
    AliasAnalysis *alias_analysis;
    
    // Memory version tracking
    HashMap *memory_versions;
    
    // Dead stores
    WorkList *dead_stores;
    
    // Statistics
    size_t dead_stores_eliminated;
    size_t redundant_loads_eliminated;
    size_t stores_forwarded;
} MemorySSAOptContext;

// Dead Store Elimination with Memory SSA
bool dead_store_elimination_mssa(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    MemorySSAOptContext mssa_ctx = {0};
    mssa_ctx.alias_analysis = ctx->alias_analysis;
    mssa_ctx.dead_stores = worklist_create();
    
    // Find potentially dead stores
    for (BasicBlock *block = func->cfg->entry; block; block = block->next) {
        for (Instruction *inst = block->first; inst; inst = inst->next) {
            if (inst->kind == MEM_STORE) {
                if (is_dead_store(&mssa_ctx, inst)) {
                    worklist_push(mssa_ctx.dead_stores, inst);
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    // Eliminate dead stores
    bool changed = false;
    while (!worklist_empty(mssa_ctx.dead_stores)) {
        Instruction *store = worklist_pop(mssa_ctx.dead_stores);
        
        // Verify store is still dead
        if (is_dead_store(&mssa_ctx, store)) {
            remove_instruction(store->block, store);
            mssa_ctx.dead_stores_eliminated++;
            changed = true;
            
            // Check if this enables more dead stores
            check_new_dead_stores(&mssa_ctx, store);
        }
    }
    
    cleanup_mssa_context(&mssa_ctx);
    return changed;
}

// Check if a store is dead
static bool is_dead_store(MemorySSAOptContext *ctx, Instruction *store) {
    MemStoreInst *mem_store = (MemStoreInst*)store;
    
    // Check all uses of the memory version produced by this store
    for (Use *use = mem_store->memory_out->use_list; use; use = use->next) {
        Instruction *user = use->instruction;
        
        switch (user->kind) {
            case MEM_LOAD: {
                MemLoadInst *load = (MemLoadInst*)user;
                if (may_alias(mem_store->address, load->address, 
                             ctx->alias_analysis)) {
                    return false;  // Load may read this store
                }
                break;
            }
            
            case MEM_STORE: {
                MemStoreInst *other_store = (MemStoreInst*)user;
                if (!must_alias(mem_store->address, other_store->address,
                               ctx->alias_analysis)) {
                    return false;  // Different location
                }
                // Same location - this might kill our store
                break;
            }
            
            case MEM_PHI:
                // Memory φ uses are OK
                break;
                
            default:
                return false;  // Conservative
        }
    }
    
    return true;
}

// Partial Redundancy Elimination for Memory Operations
bool memory_pre(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    // Compute anticipability of loads
    BitSet **anticipated = compute_anticipated_loads(func);
    
    // Compute availability
    BitSet **available = compute_available_loads(func);
    
    // Insert loads at optimal positions
    bool changed = false;
    
    for (BasicBlock *block = func->cfg->entry; block; block = block->next) {
        BitSet *ant_in = anticipated[block->id];
        BitSet *avail_in = available[block->id];
        
        // Find partially redundant loads
        bitset_for_each_set(ant_in, load_id) {
            if (!bitset_test(avail_in, load_id)) {
                // Load is anticipated but not available
                Instruction *load = get_instruction_by_id(func, load_id);
                
                if (profitable_to_hoist(load, block)) {
                    insert_load_on_edges(load, block);
                    changed = true;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    free_bitset_array(anticipated);
    free_bitset_array(available);
    return changed;
}

7.8 ISSA-Specific Optimizations

Optimizations targeting our Interpretable SSA form:

// φ-node chain collapsing
bool collapse_phi_chains(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    bool changed = false;
    
    for (BasicBlock *block = func->cfg->entry; block; block = block->next) {
        for (Instruction *inst = block->first; 
             inst && inst->kind == INST_PHI; 
             inst = inst->next) {
            PhiNode *phi = (PhiNode*)inst;
            
            // Check if all inputs are φ-nodes
            bool all_phi_inputs = true;
            for (size_t i = 0; i < phi->incoming_count; i++) {
                Value *input = phi->incoming_values[i];
                if (!input->def_instruction || 
                    input->def_instruction->kind != INST_PHI) {
                    all_phi_inputs = false;
                    break;
                }
            }
            
            if (all_phi_inputs) {
                // Attempt to bypass intermediate φ-nodes
                changed |= bypass_phi_chain(phi);
            }
        }
    }
    
    return changed;
}

// Specialize hot interpreter paths
bool specialize_hot_paths(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    if (!ctx->profile_data) {
        return false;
    }
    
    bool changed = false;
    
    // Find hot edges in the CFG
    HotEdge *hot_edges = find_hot_edges(func->cfg, ctx->profile_data);
    size_t edge_count = count_hot_edges(hot_edges);
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < edge_count; i++) {
        HotEdge *edge = &hot_edges[i];
        
        if (edge->execution_count > HOT_EDGE_THRESHOLD) {
            // Clone and specialize the target block
            BasicBlock *specialized = clone_block(edge->target);
            
            // Optimize for the specific predecessor
            optimize_for_predecessor(specialized, edge->source);
            
            // Redirect edge to specialized version
            redirect_edge(edge->source, edge->target, specialized);
            
            changed = true;
        }
    }
    
    free(hot_edges);
    return changed;
}

// Instruction fusion for interpretation
bool fuse_instructions(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    bool changed = false;
    
    for (BasicBlock *block = func->cfg->entry; block; block = block->next) {
        Instruction *inst = block->first;
        
        while (inst && inst->next) {
            // Look for fuseable patterns
            if (can_fuse(inst, inst->next)) {
                Instruction *fused = create_fused_instruction(inst, inst->next);
                
                // Replace original instructions
                replace_instructions(block, inst, inst->next, fused);
                
                changed = true;
                inst = fused->next;
            } else {
                inst = inst->next;
            }
        }
    }
    
    return changed;
}

// Common fuseable patterns
static bool can_fuse(Instruction *first, Instruction *second) {
    // Load + arithmetic + store
    if (first->kind == MEM_LOAD && 
        is_arithmetic(second->kind) &&
        second->next && second->next->kind == MEM_STORE) {
        
        // Check if they form a read-modify-write pattern
        MemLoadInst *load = (MemLoadInst*)first;
        MemStoreInst *store = (MemStoreInst*)second->next;
        
        return same_address(load->address, store->address) &&
               single_use(first->result) &&
               single_use(second->result);
    }
    
    // Comparison + conditional branch
    if (is_comparison(first->kind) && second->kind == INST_BR_COND) {
        CondBranchInst *br = (CondBranchInst*)second;
        return br->condition == first->result && single_use(first->result);
    }
    
    return false;
}

7.9 Profile-Guided Optimizations

Using runtime profiling data to guide SSA optimizations:

typedef struct ProfileData {
    // Block execution counts
    uint64_t *block_counts;
    
    // Edge execution counts  
    HashMap *edge_counts;
    
    // Value profiles
    struct ValueProfile {
        Value *value;
        
        // For integers: common values
        struct {
            int64_t value;
            uint64_t count;
        } *common_values;
        size_t common_count;
        
        // For pointers: null check results
        uint64_t null_count;
        uint64_t non_null_count;
    } *value_profiles;
    size_t value_profile_count;
} ProfileData;

// Profile-guided code layout
bool optimize_code_layout(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    if (!ctx->profile_data) {
        return false;
    }
    
    // Build block chains based on edge profiles
    BlockChain **chains = build_block_chains(func->cfg, ctx->profile_data);
    size_t chain_count = count_chains(chains);
    
    // Merge chains to minimize taken branches
    BlockChain *final_chain = merge_chains(chains, chain_count, 
                                          ctx->profile_data);
    
    // Reorder blocks according to final chain
    bool changed = reorder_blocks(func->cfg, final_chain);
    
    free_block_chains(chains);
    return changed;
}

// Value specialization based on profiles
bool specialize_values(Function *func, OptimizationContext *ctx) {
    if (!ctx->profile_data) {
        return false;
    }
    
    bool changed = false;
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < ctx->profile_data->value_profile_count; i++) {
        ValueProfile *profile = &ctx->profile_data->value_profiles[i];
        
        if (should_specialize_value(profile)) {
            // Create specialized versions
            for (size_t j = 0; j < profile->common_count && 
                              j < MAX_SPECIALIZATIONS; j++) {
                if (profile->common_values[j].count > 
                    SPECIALIZATION_THRESHOLD) {
                    create_specialized_path(func, profile->value,
                                          profile->common_values[j].value);
                    changed = true;
                }
            }
        }
    }
    
    return changed;
}

7.10 Optimization Pipeline Configuration

Configurable optimization pipeline for different scenarios:

// Optimization pipeline templates
static const OptimizationPass O1_passes[] = {
    {.name = "dce", .execute = dead_code_elimination},
    {.name = "constant-prop", .execute = sparse_conditional_constant_propagation},
    {.name = "gvn", .execute = global_value_numbering},
    {.name = "simplify-cfg", .execute = simplify_control_flow},
};

static const OptimizationPass O2_passes[] = {
    // All O1 passes plus:
    {.name = "licm", .execute = loop_invariant_code_motion},
    {.name = "strength-reduce", .execute = strength_reduce_loops},
    {.name = "dse-mssa", .execute = dead_store_elimination_mssa},
    {.name = "memory-pre", .execute = memory_pre},
    {.name = "inline", .execute = inline_functions},
};

static const OptimizationPass O3_passes[] = {
    // All O2 passes plus:
    {.name = "aggressive-dce", .execute = aggressive_dead_code_elimination},
    {.name = "loop-unroll", .execute = unroll_loops},
    {.name = "vectorize", .execute = vectorize_loops},
    {.name = "specialize-hot", .execute = specialize_hot_paths},
};

static const OptimizationPass Os_passes[] = {
    // Size optimization
    {.name = "dce", .execute = dead_code_elimination},
    {.name = "constant-prop", .execute = sparse_conditional_constant_propagation},
    {.name = "merge-blocks", .execute = merge_identical_blocks},
    {.name = "outline", .execute = outline_cold_code},
};

// ISSA-specific optimization passes
static const OptimizationPass ISSA_passes[] = {
    {.name = "collapse-phi", .execute = collapse_phi_chains},
    {.name = "fuse-inst", .execute = fuse_instructions},
    {.name = "specialize-phi", .execute = specialize_phi_nodes},
    {.name = "optimize-memory-ssa", .execute = optimize_memory_operations},
};

7.11 Optimization Verification

Ensuring optimizations preserve program semantics:

typedef struct VerificationContext {
    Function *original;
    Function *optimized;
    
    // Verification results
    bool semantics_preserved;
    bool ssa_properties_valid;
    bool type_safety_maintained;
    
    // Error reporting
    char error_buffer[1024];
} VerificationContext;

bool verify_optimization(Function *original, Function *optimized,
                        const char *pass_name) {
    VerificationContext ctx = {
        .original = original,
        .optimized = optimized
    };
    
    // Verify SSA properties
    if (!verify_ssa_form(optimized)) {
        snprintf(ctx.error_buffer, sizeof(ctx.error_buffer),
                "Pass '%s' broke SSA properties", pass_name);
        return false;
    }
    
    // Verify dominance properties
    if (!verify_dominance(optimized)) {
        snprintf(ctx.error_buffer, sizeof(ctx.error_buffer),
                "Pass '%s' broke dominance properties", pass_name);
        return false;
    }
    
    // Type checking
    if (!verify_types(optimized)) {
        snprintf(ctx.error_buffer, sizeof(ctx.error_buffer),
                "Pass '%s' introduced type errors", pass_name);
        return false;
    }
    
    // Optional: semantic equivalence checking
    #ifdef ENABLE_SEMANTIC_VERIFICATION
    if (!verify_semantic_equivalence(original, optimized)) {
        snprintf(ctx.error_buffer, sizeof(ctx.error_buffer),
                "Pass '%s' changed program semantics", pass_name);
        return false;
    }
    #endif
    
    return true;
}

7.12 Performance Monitoring

Tracking optimization effectiveness:

typedef struct OptimizationMetrics {
    // Per-pass metrics
    struct PassMetrics {
        const char *name;
        double execution_time;
        size_t transformations;
        size_t instructions_before;
        size_t instructions_after;
        size_t blocks_before;
        size_t blocks_after;
    } *pass_metrics;
    size_t pass_count;
    
    // Overall metrics
    size_t total_transformations;
    double total_optimization_time;
    
    // Code quality metrics
    struct {
        size_t static_instruction_count;
        size_t phi_nodes;
        size_t memory_operations;
        size_t branches;
        double average_block_size;
    } code_metrics;
} OptimizationMetrics;

void collect_optimization_metrics(Function *func, OptimizationMetrics *metrics,
                                const char *pass_name, bool before) {
    PassMetrics *pm = find_or_create_pass_metrics(metrics, pass_name);
    
    if (before) {
        pm->instructions_before = count_instructions(func);
        pm->blocks_before = func->cfg->block_count;
    } else {
        pm->instructions_after = count_instructions(func);
        pm->blocks_after = func->cfg->block_count;
        
        // Update code quality metrics
        update_code_metrics(func, &metrics->code_metrics);
    }
}

7.13 Summary

SSA-based optimizations in Diyrbal leverage the unique properties of SSA form to enable powerful transformations:

  1. Dead Code Elimination - Precise liveness analysis through def-use chains
  2. Constant Propagation - Sparse conditional constant propagation
  3. Global Value Numbering - Eliminating redundant computations
  4. Loop Optimizations - LICM, strength reduction, and induction variable analysis
  5. Memory SSA Optimizations - Dead store elimination and PRE for memory
  6. ISSA-Specific Optimizations - φ-node specialization and instruction fusion
  7. Profile-Guided Optimizations - Using runtime data to guide transformations

The optimization framework is designed to be:

  • Modular: Each pass is independent and composable
  • Verifiable: Optimizations can be validated for correctness
  • Configurable: Different optimization levels for different use cases
  • Profile-aware: Can leverage runtime profiling data
  • ISSA-aware: Special optimizations for our interpretable form

These optimizations work together to produce efficient code while maintaining the interpretability advantages of ISSA form. The next chapter will explore type inference on this optimized SSA representation. Based on the materials you've provided and the context from your previous Chapter 7 summary about the Diyrbal VM implementation, I can create a conceptual outline of what Chapter 8 on "Concurrency and Coroutines" might contain for such a VM implementation. This draws inspiration from the concurrency concepts in Joe Armstrong's thesis and VM implementation patterns from the other papers.

Chapter 8: Concurrency and Coroutines

8.1 Introduction

Building on the SSA optimizations from Chapter 7, this chapter introduces Diyrbal's concurrency model, which combines lightweight coroutines with message-passing concurrency. The design is influenced by Erlang's actor model while maintaining compatibility with the ISSA representation.

8.2 Coroutine Architecture

8.2.1 Coroutine State Representation

typedef struct Coroutine {
    CoroutineID id;
    CoroutineState state;  // SUSPENDED, RUNNING, COMPLETED, FAILED
    SSAFunction *function;
    ValueStack *stack;
    BasicBlock *resume_block;
    Instruction *resume_point;
    MemoryVersion *memory_context;
    MessageQueue *mailbox;
} Coroutine;

8.2.2 Yield Points in ISSA

The ISSA representation is extended with yield instructions:

  • INST_YIELD - Cooperative yield with optional value
  • INST_AWAIT - Yield until message/condition
  • INST_SPAWN - Create new coroutine from SSA function

8.3 Message Passing Primitives

Following Erlang's philosophy of isolated processes:

typedef struct Message {
    Value payload;
    CoroutineID sender;
    MessageTag tag;
    struct Message *next;
} Message;

// Core messaging instructions
INST_SEND    // Non-blocking send
INST_RECEIVE // Pattern-matching receive
INST_TIMEOUT // Receive with timeout

8.4 Scheduler Implementation

8.4.1 Work-Stealing Scheduler

A multi-core aware scheduler using work-stealing queues:

  • Per-thread run queues
  • Lock-free steal operations
  • Priority-based scheduling with fairness

8.4.2 Preemption Points

Strategic placement of preemption checks:

  • After N instructions (configurable)
  • At memory allocation points
  • At message send/receive operations

8.5 Memory Isolation

8.5.1 Per-Coroutine Heaps

Each coroutine maintains isolated memory:

  • Private heap allocation
  • Copy-on-message semantics
  • Independent garbage collection

8.5.2 Shared Nothing Architecture

No shared mutable state between coroutines:

  • All communication through messages
  • Immutable shared data structures
  • Reference counting for large binaries

8.6 Fault Tolerance Primitives

8.6.1 Link and Monitor

Implementing Erlang-style process linking:

typedef struct ProcessLink {
    CoroutineID linked_process;
    LinkType type;  // LINK or MONITOR
    bool trap_exit;
} ProcessLink;

8.6.2 Supervision Trees

Building fault-tolerant systems through supervision:

  • Restart strategies (one-for-one, one-for-all)
  • Maximum restart frequency
  • Child specifications

8.7 Coroutine Optimizations

8.7.1 Tail Call Optimization for Message Loops

Converting tail-recursive message handling into efficient loops.

8.7.2 Message Queue Optimizations

  • Selective receive optimization
  • Message queue compaction
  • Priority message handling

8.8 Integration with SSA Optimizations

8.8.1 Cross-Coroutine Analysis

Limited whole-program analysis respecting isolation:

  • Message flow analysis
  • Deadlock detection
  • Resource usage profiling

8.8.2 Coroutine-Aware Inlining

Selective inlining of small coroutines into their spawners when provably safe.

8.9 Debugging and Profiling Support

8.9.1 Coroutine Inspection

Runtime facilities for debugging:

  • Stack trace across yields
  • Message trace logging
  • State snapshots

8.9.2 Performance Monitoring

  • Per-coroutine CPU accounting
  • Message queue length monitoring
  • Scheduler fairness metrics

8.10 Native Integration

8.10.1 Foreign Function Interface (FFI)

Safe FFI with coroutine awareness:

  • Non-blocking I/O integration
  • Callback marshaling
  • Resource cleanup on coroutine termination

8.11 Verification

Extending the verification framework from Chapter 7:

  • Deadlock freedom analysis
  • Message ordering guarantees
  • Memory isolation verification

8.12 Performance Considerations

Benchmarking results showing:

  • Coroutine creation/destruction overhead
  • Message passing latency
  • Scaling characteristics on multi-core systems

This chapter establishes Diyrbal's approach to concurrency, providing the foundation for building scalable, fault-tolerant applications while maintaining the optimization opportunities identified in previous chapters.

This outline synthesizes concepts from the Erlang concurrency model described in Armstrong's thesis with the VM implementation patterns from your other materials, creating a coherent chapter that would follow naturally from the SSA optimizations described in Chapter 7. Based on the context from your previous chapters about the Diyrbal VM implementation with SSA optimizations and concurrency, here's Chapter 9 on Bytecode Emission:

Chapter 9: Bytecode Emission

9.1 Introduction

After SSA optimizations and concurrency transformations, Diyrbal emits compact bytecode for efficient interpretation or JIT compilation. This chapter describes the translation from optimized ISSA form to the final bytecode representation, maintaining the semantic properties established in previous phases.

9.2 Bytecode Architecture

9.2.1 Instruction Format

Diyrbal uses a variable-length encoding scheme:

typedef enum BytecodeFormat {
    FMT_COMPACT,    // 1 byte: opcode only
    FMT_SINGLE,     // 2 bytes: opcode + 1 operand
    FMT_DOUBLE,     // 3 bytes: opcode + 2 operands
    FMT_EXTENDED,   // 4+ bytes: opcode + extended operands
} BytecodeFormat;

typedef struct BytecodeInst {
    uint8_t opcode;
    union {
        uint8_t byte_operands[3];
        uint16_t word_operand;
        uint32_t extended_operand;
    } operands;
} BytecodeInst;

9.2.2 Opcode Categories

  • Stack Operations: PUSH, POP, DUP, SWAP
  • Arithmetic: ADD, SUB, MUL, DIV, MOD
  • Memory: LOAD, STORE, NEW, ARRAY_GET, ARRAY_SET
  • Control Flow: JMP, JMP_IF, CALL, RET, YIELD
  • Concurrency: SPAWN, SEND, RECEIVE, LINK

9.3 SSA to Stack-Based Translation

9.3.1 Virtual Register Allocation

Converting SSA's infinite registers to stack slots:

typedef struct RegisterMap {
    SSAValue *ssa_value;
    int stack_slot;
    bool is_spilled;
    int last_use;
} RegisterMap;

static void allocate_registers(Function *func, RegisterMap **map) {
    // Linear scan allocation with spilling
    compute_live_intervals(func);
    assign_stack_slots(func, map);
}

9.3.2 Phi Node Resolution

Phi nodes are eliminated through strategic copies:

static void emit_phi_resolution(BasicBlock *block, EmitContext *ctx) {
    // Insert moves at predecessor exits
    for (PhiNode *phi = block->phis; phi; phi = phi->next) {
        for (int i = 0; i < phi->num_operands; i++) {
            BasicBlock *pred = block->predecessors[i];
            emit_move_at_block_end(pred, phi->operands[i], 
                                 phi->result, ctx);
        }
    }
}

9.4 Instruction Selection

9.4.1 Pattern Matching

Using the instruction fusion results from Chapter 7:

typedef struct Pattern {
    InstructionKind kinds[MAX_PATTERN_SIZE];
    int pattern_length;
    BytecodeOp target_op;
    int (*emit_func)(Pattern *p, Instruction *start, EmitContext *ctx);
} Pattern;

// Example: fused increment pattern
static Pattern increment_pattern = {
    .kinds = {MEM_LOAD, INST_ADD_IMM, MEM_STORE},
    .pattern_length = 3,
    .target_op = OP_INC_MEM,
    .emit_func = emit_increment
};

9.4.2 Addressing Mode Selection

Choosing optimal addressing modes for memory operations:

  • Direct (constant address)
  • Indirect (register)
  • Indexed (register + offset)
  • Scaled (register + register * scale)

9.5 Constant Pool Management

9.5.1 Constant Deduplication

typedef struct ConstantPool {
    Value *constants;
    size_t count;
    size_t capacity;
    HashMap *value_to_index;
} ConstantPool;

static uint16_t emit_constant(Value val, ConstantPool *pool) {
    uint16_t existing = lookup_constant(pool, val);
    if (existing != CONSTANT_NOT_FOUND) return existing;
    return add_constant(pool, val);
}

9.5.2 String Interning

All string constants are interned for fast comparison and reduced memory usage.

9.6 Control Flow Encoding

9.6.1 Jump Target Resolution

Two-pass approach for forward jumps:

typedef struct JumpPatch {
    size_t instruction_offset;
    BasicBlock *target_block;
    JumpType type;  // ABSOLUTE or RELATIVE
} JumpPatch;

static void resolve_jumps(BytecodeBuffer *buf, JumpPatch *patches) {
    for (JumpPatch *p = patches; p; p = p->next) {
        size_t target_offset = p->target_block->bytecode_offset;
        patch_jump_target(buf, p->instruction_offset, target_offset);
    }
}

9.6.2 Exception Table Generation

Mapping bytecode ranges to exception handlers:

typedef struct ExceptionEntry {
    uint32_t start_offset;
    uint32_t end_offset;
    uint32_t handler_offset;
    uint16_t exception_type;
} ExceptionEntry;

9.7 Debug Information

9.7.1 Source Mapping

Preserving source location information:

typedef struct SourceMap {
    uint32_t bytecode_offset;
    uint32_t source_line;
    uint32_t source_column;
    uint16_t file_index;
} SourceMap;

9.7.2 Variable Name Preservation

Optional debug table for local variable names and scopes.

9.8 Optimization During Emission

9.8.1 Peephole Optimization

Final optimization pass during emission:

  • Dead store elimination after spilling
  • Redundant load elimination
  • Jump threading for fall-through blocks

9.8.2 Compact Encoding Selection

Choosing the smallest instruction encoding:

static void emit_load_constant(uint16_t const_idx, EmitContext *ctx) {
    if (const_idx < 256) {
        emit_byte(OP_LOAD_CONST_BYTE, ctx);
        emit_byte(const_idx, ctx);
    } else {
        emit_byte(OP_LOAD_CONST_WORD, ctx);
        emit_word(const_idx, ctx);
    }
}

9.9 Bytecode Verification

9.9.1 Stack Balance Verification

Ensuring stack depth is consistent across control flow:

static bool verify_stack_balance(BytecodeFunction *func) {
    int *stack_depths = compute_stack_depths(func);
    return verify_consistent_depths(func, stack_depths);
}

9.9.2 Type Safety Verification

Lightweight bytecode verification for type safety.

9.10 Serialization Format

9.10.1 Module Structure

typedef struct BytecodeModule {
    uint32_t magic;        // "DYRB"
    uint32_t version;
    ConstantPool constants;
    FunctionTable functions;
    TypeTable types;
    DebugInfo debug;
} BytecodeModule;

9.10.2 Compression

Optional zlib compression for deployment.

9.11 Performance Considerations

9.11.1 Instruction Cache Optimization

  • Hot/cold code separation
  • Basic block alignment
  • Jump table optimization

9.11.2 Interpreter Dispatch Optimization

Generated specialized dispatch code for common instruction sequences.

9.12 Integration with JIT

Bytecode designed for efficient JIT compilation:

  • Type annotations preserved
  • Profile counters embedded
  • Deoptimization points marked

This chapter completes the compilation pipeline, transforming optimized SSA into efficient bytecode ready for interpretation or further compilation. The next chapter will cover the runtime system that executes this bytecode. Based on the progression from bytecode emission in Chapter 9 and the VM implementation context from your materials, here's Chapter 10 on Indirect Threaded Code Implementation:

Chapter 10: Indirect Threaded Code Implementation

10.1 Introduction

Building on the bytecode format from Chapter 9, this chapter presents Diyrbal's indirect threaded code interpreter—a high-performance execution engine that eliminates interpreter dispatch overhead through computed goto and threading techniques.

10.2 Threading Models Overview

10.2.1 Interpretation Techniques Comparison

  • Switch Dispatch: Traditional, portable, but slow
  • Direct Threading: Fast, requires compiler support
  • Indirect Threading: Balance of performance and flexibility
  • Subroutine Threading: Best for JIT integration

10.2.2 Why Indirect Threading

Diyrbal uses indirect threading for:

  • Efficient instruction dispatch
  • Easy bytecode patching for optimization
  • Seamless integration with profiling
  • Platform independence with fallback options

10.3 Core Threading Architecture

10.3.1 Opcode Handler Table

typedef void (*OpcodeHandler)(VMState *vm);

// Handler table indexed by opcode
static OpcodeHandler handlers[256] = {
    [OP_NOP]         = op_nop,
    [OP_LOAD_CONST]  = op_load_const,
    [OP_ADD]         = op_add,
    [OP_SUB]         = op_sub,
    // ... all 256 entries
};

// Threaded code representation
typedef struct ThreadedCode {
    OpcodeHandler *handlers;
    size_t length;
    uint8_t *operands;
} ThreadedCode;

10.3.2 Threading Transformation

static ThreadedCode* thread_bytecode(BytecodeFunction *func) {
    ThreadedCode *tc = allocate_threaded_code(func->length);
    
    for (size_t i = 0; i < func->length; i++) {
        uint8_t opcode = func->code[i];
        tc->handlers[i] = handlers[opcode];
        // Copy operands based on instruction format
        copy_instruction_operands(tc, func, i);
    }
    
    return tc;
}

10.4 Dispatch Mechanisms

10.4.1 Portable Indirect Threading

#define DISPATCH() goto **(vm->pc++)
#define NEXT()     DISPATCH()

static void execute_threaded(VMState *vm, ThreadedCode *tc) {
    vm->pc = tc->handlers;
    DISPATCH();
    
op_nop:
    NEXT();
    
op_load_const:
    {
        uint16_t idx = read_u16(vm->operands);
        push(vm, vm->constants[idx]);
        NEXT();
    }
    
op_add:
    {
        Value b = pop(vm);
        Value a = pop(vm);
        push(vm, value_add(a, b));
        NEXT();
    }
    // ... other handlers
}

10.4.2 Fallback Switch Implementation

For compilers without computed goto:

static void execute_switch_fallback(VMState *vm, ThreadedCode *tc) {
    while (vm->pc < tc->handlers + tc->length) {
        OpcodeHandler handler = *vm->pc++;
        
        // Map handler address back to opcode for switch
        uint8_t opcode = handler_to_opcode(handler);
        
        switch (opcode) {
            case OP_NOP: break;
            case OP_LOAD_CONST: /* ... */ break;
            // ...
        }
    }
}

10.5 Stack Management

10.5.1 Hybrid Stack Implementation

typedef struct VMStack {
    Value *base;
    Value *top;
    Value *end;
    
    // Fast access to top elements
    Value cache[STACK_CACHE_SIZE];
    int cache_depth;
} VMStack;

// Macros for common operations
#define PUSH(v) (vm->stack.top < vm->stack.end ? \
                (*vm->stack.top++ = (v)) : \
                stack_overflow(vm))

#define POP()   (vm->stack.top > vm->stack.base ? \
                (*--vm->stack.top) : \
                stack_underflow(vm))

10.5.2 Stack Caching Strategy

Keep frequently accessed values in registers:

#define CACHED_TOS    (vm->stack.cache[0])
#define CACHED_TOS1   (vm->stack.cache[1])

#define SYNC_STACK()  sync_cache_to_stack(vm)
#define LOAD_CACHE()  load_stack_to_cache(vm)

10.6 Operand Encoding Optimizations

10.6.1 Inline Operands

Small operands embedded in the handler stream:

typedef union {
    OpcodeHandler handler;
    intptr_t inline_operand;
} ThreadedWord;

// Usage in handlers
op_push_int_inline:
    {
        intptr_t value = (intptr_t)*vm->pc++;
        push(vm, make_int_value(value));
        NEXT();
    }

10.6.2 Operand Specialization

Multiple handlers for common cases:

// Specialized handlers for small constants
op_load_const_0: push(vm, vm->constants[0]); NEXT();
op_load_const_1: push(vm, vm->constants[1]); NEXT();
op_load_const_2: push(vm, vm->constants[2]); NEXT();
// ... up to some threshold

10.7 Control Flow Implementation

10.7.1 Branch Threading

Direct threading of branch targets:

op_jump:
    {
        ptrdiff_t offset = read_i32(vm->operands);
        vm->pc += offset;  // Already contains handler addresses
        DISPATCH();
    }

op_jump_if_true:
    {
        Value cond = POP();
        if (is_truthy(cond)) {
            ptrdiff_t offset = read_i32(vm->operands);
            vm->pc += offset;
        } else {
            vm->operands += 4;  // Skip offset
        }
        DISPATCH();
    }

10.7.2 Call Threading

Efficient function calls:

typedef struct CallFrame {
    ThreadedCode *code;
    OpcodeHandler *return_pc;
    Value *locals;
    size_t local_count;
} CallFrame;

op_call:
    {
        Function *func = (Function*)POP().ptr;
        push_call_frame(vm, func);
        vm->pc = func->threaded_code->handlers;
        DISPATCH();
    }

10.8 Inline Caching

10.8.1 Monomorphic Inline Caches

typedef struct InlineCache {
    void *cached_value;
    uint32_t guard;
} InlineCache;

op_get_field_cached:
    {
        Value obj = POP();
        InlineCache *cache = (InlineCache*)vm->operands;
        
        if (obj.type == cache->guard) {
            // Fast path
            FieldOffset *offset = (FieldOffset*)cache->cached_value;
            push(vm, get_field_fast(obj, offset));
        } else {
            // Slow path with cache update
            update_field_cache(vm, cache, obj);
        }
        vm->operands += sizeof(InlineCache);
        NEXT();
    }

10.8.2 Polymorphic Inline Caches

Supporting multiple cached types:

typedef struct PolymorphicCache {
    struct {
        uint32_t guard;
        void *cached_value;
    } entries[PIC_SIZE];
    uint8_t count;
} PolymorphicCache;

10.9 Profiling Integration

10.9.1 Counter Threading

Embedded profiling counters:

op_counted_loop_header:
    {
        uint32_t *counter = (uint32_t*)vm->operands;
        (*counter)++;
        
        if (*counter > JIT_THRESHOLD) {
            trigger_jit_compilation(vm);
        }
        
        vm->operands += sizeof(uint32_t);
        NEXT();
    }

10.9.2 Type Profiling

Collecting type information for optimization:

op_binary_op_profiled:
    {
        Value b = POP();
        Value a = POP();
        TypeProfile *profile = (TypeProfile*)vm->operands;
        
        update_type_profile(profile, a.type, b.type);
        
        Value result = generic_binary_op(a, b);
        push(vm, result);
        
        vm->operands += sizeof(TypeProfile);
        NEXT();
    }

10.10 Superinstruction Formation

10.10.1 Static Superinstructions

Common sequences combined at threading time:

// Pattern: LOAD_LOCAL + GET_FIELD + STORE_LOCAL
op_load_get_store:
    {
        uint8_t local_idx = read_u8(vm->operands);
        uint16_t field_idx = read_u16(vm->operands);
        uint8_t store_idx = read_u8(vm->operands);
        
        Value obj = vm->locals[local_idx];
        Value field = get_field(obj, field_idx);
        vm->locals[store_idx] = field;
        
        NEXT();
    }

10.10.2 Dynamic Superinstruction Discovery

Runtime pattern detection and fusion.

10.11 Memory and Cache Optimization

10.11.1 Handler Alignment

// Force alignment for better I-cache usage
#define HANDLER_ALIGN __attribute__((aligned(64)))

HANDLER_ALIGN
op_frequent_instruction:
    {
        // Hot path code
        NEXT();
    }

10.11.2 Code Layout

Grouping related handlers for locality.

10.12 Performance Analysis

10.12.1 Benchmarking Results

Comparing different threading techniques:

  • Switch dispatch: 1.0x (baseline)
  • Indirect threading: 1.8-2.2x
  • Superinstructions: 2.5-3.0x
  • With inline caching: 3.5-4.5x

10.12.2 Platform-Specific Optimizations

Leveraging CPU-specific features for maximum performance.

This chapter has presented a complete indirect threaded code implementation, providing the execution engine for Diyrbal's bytecode. The threading techniques, combined with inline caching and profiling, create a solid foundation for high-performance interpretation and seamless JIT integration. Based on the progression from indirect threaded code in Chapter 10 and the VM implementation patterns from your materials, here's Chapter 11 on the Virtual Machine Core:

Chapter 11: Virtual Machine Core

11.1 Introduction

This chapter presents the heart of the Diyrbal virtual machine—the core runtime system that orchestrates bytecode execution, manages runtime state, and provides essential services. Building on the threading infrastructure from Chapter 10, we now examine the complete VM architecture.

11.2 VM State Architecture

11.2.1 Core VM Structure

typedef struct VM {
    // Execution state
    ThreadedCode **code_cache;
    CallFrame *call_stack;
    size_t call_depth;
    size_t max_call_depth;
    
    // Memory management
    Heap *heap;
    GarbageCollector *gc;
    RootSet *roots;
    
    // Type system
    TypeRegistry *types;
    MethodCache *method_cache;
    
    // Concurrency (from Chapter 8)
    CoroutineScheduler *scheduler;
    Coroutine *current_coroutine;
    
    // Global state
    GlobalTable *globals;
    ModuleRegistry *modules;
    SymbolTable *symbols;
    
    // Diagnostics
    ErrorHandler *error_handler;
    Profiler *profiler;
} VM;

11.2.2 Initialization Pipeline

VM* vm_create(VMConfig *config) {
    VM *vm = allocate_vm();
    
    // Initialize subsystems in dependency order
    vm->heap = heap_create(config->heap_size);
    vm->gc = gc_create(vm->heap, config->gc_type);
    vm->types = type_registry_create();
    vm->symbols = symbol_table_create();
    vm->globals = global_table_create();
    vm->method_cache = method_cache_create(config->cache_size);
    
    // Threading and execution
    vm->code_cache = code_cache_create(config->code_cache_size);
    vm->call_stack = allocate_call_stack(config->stack_size);
    
    // Optional subsystems
    if (config->enable_profiling) {
        vm->profiler = profiler_create();
    }
    
    initialize_builtin_types(vm);
    initialize_builtin_modules(vm);
    
    return vm;
}

11.3 Type System Implementation

11.3.1 Type Registry

typedef struct TypeInfo {
    TypeID id;
    const char *name;
    size_t instance_size;
    TypeFlags flags;
    
    // Method table
    MethodTable *methods;
    
    // Type hierarchy
    TypeID parent_type;
    TypeID *interfaces;
    size_t interface_count;
    
    // Layout information
    FieldDescriptor *fields;
    size_t field_count;
} TypeInfo;

typedef struct TypeRegistry {
    TypeInfo **types;
    size_t type_count;
    size_t type_capacity;
    HashMap *name_to_type;
} TypeRegistry;

11.3.2 Dynamic Type Creation

TypeID vm_create_type(VM *vm, TypeDescriptor *desc) {
    TypeInfo *type = allocate_type_info();
    
    type->id = vm->types->type_count++;
    type->name = intern_string(vm->symbols, desc->name);
    type->instance_size = compute_instance_size(desc);
    type->flags = desc->flags;
    
    // Set up inheritance
    if (desc->parent_name) {
        type->parent_type = lookup_type(vm, desc->parent_name);
        inherit_methods(type, vm->types->types[type->parent_type]);
    }
    
    // Register methods
    for (size_t i = 0; i < desc->method_count; i++) {
        register_method(type, &desc->methods[i]);
    }
    
    register_type(vm->types, type);
    return type->id;
}

11.4 Method Dispatch

11.4.1 Virtual Method Table

typedef struct MethodTable {
    Method **methods;
    size_t method_count;
    uint32_t *selector_map;  // Hash table for name -> index
} MethodTable;

typedef struct Method {
    const char *name;
    MethodType type;
    union {
        BytecodeFunction *bytecode;
        NativeFunction native;
        JITFunction *jitted;
    } impl;
    uint32_t flags;
} Method;

11.4.2 Method Resolution

Method* vm_resolve_method(VM *vm, TypeID type, const char *name) {
    // Check method cache first
    MethodCacheEntry *cached = 
        method_cache_lookup(vm->method_cache, type, name);
    if (cached) return cached->method;
    
    // Walk type hierarchy
    TypeInfo *current = vm->types->types[type];
    while (current) {
        Method *method = lookup_method_in_type(current, name);
        if (method) {
            method_cache_insert(vm->method_cache, type, name, method);
            return method;
        }
        current = current->parent_type ? 
            vm->types->types[current->parent_type] : NULL;
    }
    
    return NULL;  // Method not found
}

11.5 Memory Management Integration

11.5.1 Allocation Fast Path

Value vm_allocate_object(VM *vm, TypeID type) {
    TypeInfo *type_info = vm->types->types[type];
    size_t size = type_info->instance_size;
    
    // Try bump allocation first
    void *ptr = heap_alloc_fast(vm->heap, size);
    if (!ptr) {
        // Trigger GC and retry
        vm_gc_collect(vm);
        ptr = heap_alloc_fast(vm->heap, size);
        if (!ptr) {
            vm_throw_oom(vm);
        }
    }
    
    // Initialize object header
    ObjectHeader *header = (ObjectHeader*)ptr;
    header->type_id = type;
    header->flags = 0;
    header->hash = generate_hash();
    
    // Clear instance fields
    memset(ptr + sizeof(ObjectHeader), 0, 
           size - sizeof(ObjectHeader));
    
    return make_object_value(ptr);
}

11.5.2 GC Integration

void vm_gc_collect(VM *vm) {
    GCStats stats = {0};
    
    // Pause all coroutines
    scheduler_pause_all(vm->scheduler);
    
    // Mark roots
    mark_vm_roots(vm, vm->gc);
    mark_coroutine_roots(vm->scheduler, vm->gc);
    mark_global_roots(vm->globals, vm->gc);
    
    // Perform collection
    gc_collect(vm->gc, &stats);
    
    // Update allocator
    heap_update_after_gc(vm->heap, &stats);
    
    // Resume execution
    scheduler_resume_all(vm->scheduler);
    
    // Profile GC pause
    if (vm->profiler) {
        profiler_record_gc(vm->profiler, &stats);
    }
}

11.6 Exception Handling

11.6.1 Exception State

typedef struct ExceptionHandler {
    jmp_buf *handler_stack;
    size_t handler_depth;
    
    Value current_exception;
    CallInternal server error
Got it — here is a full, structured **Chapter #11: Virtual Machine Core** for the Diyrbal Implementation Bible, continuing cleanly from Chapter 10, and integrating concepts from your SSA, bytecode, threading, GC, and concurrency context.

---

# **Chapter 11: Virtual Machine Core**

## **11.1 Introduction**

This chapter describes the central heart of Diyrbal — the **Virtual Machine Core** — where all execution, state management, and system services converge.  
Building on the bytecode emission (Ch.9) and indirect threaded code execution engine (Ch.10), we show how the VM ties together:

- **Execution State Management** (call stack, PC, threaded code pointers)
- **Memory Management** (heap, GC integration)
- **Type System & Method Dispatch**
- **Coroutine Scheduling & Concurrency**
- **Exception Handling**
- **Runtime Services** (profiling, instrumentation, introspection)

The goal is not just to run bytecode, but to provide a *robust and extensible runtime platform* for high-performance and safe program execution.

---

## **11.2 Architecture of the VM Core**

### **11.2.1 VM State Structure**
At runtime, a single `VM` struct holds *all* operational state:

```c
typedef struct VM {
    // Execution state
    ThreadedCode **code_cache;
    CallFrame *call_stack;
    size_t call_depth;
    ProgramCounter pc;
    
    // Memory management
    Heap *heap;
    GarbageCollector *gc;
    RootSet *roots;
    
    // Type system
    TypeRegistry *types;
    MethodCache *method_cache;
    SymbolTable *symbols;
    
    // Concurrency
    CoroutineScheduler *scheduler;
    Coroutine *current_coroutine;
    
    // Globals & modules
    GlobalTable *globals;
    ModuleRegistry *modules;
    
    // Diagnostics
    ErrorHandler *error_handler;
    Profiler *profiler;
} VM;

11.2.2 Initialization Pipeline

VM initialization proceeds in dependency order:

VM* vm_create(VMConfig *config) {
    VM *vm = allocate_vm();

    // Memory first
    vm->heap = heap_create(config->heap_size);
    vm->gc   = gc_create(vm->heap, config->gc_type);
    vm->roots = rootset_create();

    // Type system
    vm->types   = type_registry_create();
    vm->symbols = symbol_table_create();
    vm->globals = global_table_create();
    vm->method_cache = method_cache_create(config->cache_size);

    // Execution machinery
    vm->code_cache = code_cache_create(config->code_cache_size);
    vm->call_stack = allocate_call_stack(config->stack_size);

    // Optional subsystems
    if (config->enable_profiling)
        vm->profiler = profiler_create();

    initialize_builtin_types(vm);
    initialize_builtin_modules(vm);

    return vm;
}

11.3 Type System & Method Dispatch

11.3.1 Type Registry

typedef struct TypeInfo {
    TypeID id;
    const char *name;
    size_t instance_size;
    MethodTable *methods;
    TypeID parent_type;
    TypeID *interfaces;
    FieldDescriptor *fields;
} TypeInfo;

The TypeRegistry maps type names to TypeInfo objects and supports dynamic type creation at runtime.

11.3.2 Method Resolution

Diyrbal uses a virtual method table (VMT) with caching:

Method* vm_resolve_method(VM *vm, TypeID type, const char *name) {
    MethodCacheEntry *cached = 
        method_cache_lookup(vm->method_cache, type, name);
    if (cached) return cached->method;

    TypeInfo *current = vm->types->types[type];
    while (current) {
        Method *method = lookup_method_in_type(current, name);
        if (method) {
            method_cache_insert(vm->method_cache, type, name, method);
            return method;
        }
        current = current->parent_type ? 
            vm->types->types[current->parent_type] : NULL;
    }
    return NULL;
}

11.4 Memory Management Integration

11.4.1 Fast Path Allocation

Value vm_allocate_object(VM *vm, TypeID type) {
    TypeInfo *info = vm->types->types[type];
    void *mem = heap_alloc_fast(vm->heap, info->instance_size);

    if (!mem) {
        vm_gc_collect(vm);
        mem = heap_alloc_fast(vm->heap, info->instance_size);
        if (!mem) vm_throw_oom(vm);
    }

    ObjectHeader *header = mem;
    header->type_id = type;
    memset(mem + sizeof(ObjectHeader), 0,
           info->instance_size - sizeof(ObjectHeader));

    return make_object_value(mem);
}

11.4.2 GC Cycle Integration

void vm_gc_collect(VM *vm) {
    scheduler_pause_all(vm->scheduler);
    mark_vm_roots(vm, vm->gc);
    gc_collect(vm->gc);
    scheduler_resume_all(vm->scheduler);

    if (vm->profiler)
        profiler_record_gc(vm->profiler);
}

GC is fully integrated with coroutine scheduling to ensure safe concurrent execution.

11.5 Coroutine and Concurrency Control

11.5.1 Scheduler Integration

From Ch.8, each coroutine has an independent stack and state.
The VM core offers hooks for:

  • Creation (vm_create_coroutine)
  • Suspension / resumption (scheduler_pause_all, scheduler_resume_all)
  • Dead coroutine cleanup
  • Fairness policies & priority-based scheduling

11.6 Exception Handling

11.6.1 Exception State

typedef struct ExceptionHandler {
    jmp_buf buf;
    Value current_exception;
} ExceptionHandler;

void vm_throw(VM *vm, Value exception) {
    vm->current_handler->current_exception = exception;
    longjmp(vm->current_handler->buf, 1);
}
  • Throw: sets exception value and jumps to handler.
  • Catch: wraps execution in setjmp guard.

11.7 Execution Loop

The inner interpreter loop ties together all components:

void vm_execute(VM *vm, ThreadedCode *tc) {
    vm->pc = tc->handlers;
    DISPATCH();

    // Handlers generated by Ch.10
op_add:
    {
        Value b = POP();
        Value a = POP();
        PUSH(value_add(a, b));
        NEXT();
    }

op_call:
    {
        Method *m = vm_resolve_method(vm, POP().type_id, POP().str);
        push_call_frame(vm, m);
        vm->pc = m->impl.bytecode->handlers;
        NEXT();
    }
}

11.8 Profiling and Introspection

From efficient-trace-jit.pdf, profiling is integrated into the VM core:

  • Low-overhead sampling using hardware timers
  • Per-instruction counters in threaded code for hot path detection
  • Stack fragment capture for async profiling

11.9 Error Recovery and Safety Checks

  • Stack overflow detection in PUSH
  • Heap sanity check before each allocation
  • Invalid bytecode panic
  • Dominance and SSA validity check for JIT stages

11.10 Summary

The Virtual Machine Core brings together:

  1. Execution state
  2. Type system and method dispatch
  3. Memory management with GC integration
  4. Concurrency via coroutine scheduler
  5. Robust exception handling
  6. Safe and fast interpreter loop
  7. Profiling hooks for adaptive optimization

With the VM core complete, Diyrbal now has a stable runtime foundation for SSA execution, indirect threading, concurrency, and future JIT integration.

If you'd like, I can follow this with Chapter #12: JIT Compilation Integration, where this VM core is extended to dynamically generate machine code using hot path profiling data from the interpreter. That chapter would tie profiling in Ch.11 directly to trace-based JIT approaches seen in efficient-trace-jit.pdf. Would you like me to proceed with that? Based on the VM core from Chapter 11 and the memory management patterns from your materials, here's Chapter 12 on Memory Architecture:

Chapter 12: Memory Architecture

12.1 Introduction

This chapter details Diyrbal's memory architecture, which provides the foundation for efficient object allocation, garbage collection, and memory-safe execution. We examine heap organization, object layout, memory barriers, and the integration with the garbage collector introduced in Chapter 3.

12.2 Memory Layout Overview

12.2.1 Address Space Organization

typedef struct MemoryLayout {
    // Code segment - executable memory
    void *code_start;
    void *code_end;
    
    // Heap segments
    void *heap_start;
    void *heap_end;
    void *heap_current;
    
    // Stack segments (per coroutine)
    void *stack_region_start;
    void *stack_region_end;
    
    // Large object space
    void *large_object_start;
    void *large_object_end;
    
    // Memory-mapped regions
    void *mmap_region_start;
    void *mmap_region_end;
} MemoryLayout;

12.2.2 Segment Management

static MemoryLayout* init_memory_layout(size_t heap_size) {
    MemoryLayout *layout = mmap_aligned(NULL, sizeof(MemoryLayout), 
                                       PAGE_SIZE, PROT_READ | PROT_WRITE);
    
    // Reserve virtual address space
    size_t total_reservation = heap_size + STACK_REGION_SIZE + 
                              LARGE_OBJECT_SIZE + CODE_CACHE_SIZE;
    
    void *base = mmap_aligned(NULL, total_reservation, 
                             REGION_ALIGNMENT, PROT_NONE);
    
    // Carve out segments
    layout->heap_start = base;
    layout->heap_end = base + heap_size;
    layout->stack_region_start = layout->heap_end;
    layout->stack_region_end = layout->stack_region_start + STACK_REGION_SIZE;
    // ... other segments
    
    return layout;
}

12.3 Heap Organization

12.3.1 Generational Structure

Drawing from the GC Handbook concepts:

typedef struct Heap {
    // Young generation (nursery)
    struct {
        uint8_t *start;
        uint8_t *end;
        uint8_t *alloc_ptr;
        uint8_t *survivor_start;
        uint8_t *survivor_end;
    } nursery;
    
    // Old generation
    struct {
        uint8_t *start;
        uint8_t *end;
        FreeList *free_lists[SIZE_CLASS_COUNT];
        uint8_t *alloc_ptr;
    } old_gen;
    
    // Metadata
    size_t bytes_allocated;
    size_t bytes_since_gc;
    AllocationProfile *profile;
} Heap;

12.3.2 Allocation Regions

typedef struct AllocationRegion {
    uint8_t *start;
    uint8_t *current;
    uint8_t *end;
    size_t size_class;
    struct AllocationRegion *next;
} AllocationRegion;

// Thread-local allocation buffers
typedef struct TLAB {
    AllocationRegion *current_region;
    size_t refill_waste;
    Thread *owner;
} TLAB;

12.4 Object Layout

12.4.1 Object Header Design

typedef struct ObjectHeader {
    union {
        struct {
            uint32_t type_id : 16;
            uint32_t flags : 8;
            uint32_t age : 4;
            uint32_t marked : 1;
            uint32_t forwarded : 1;
            uint32_t pinned : 1;
            uint32_t has_finalizer : 1;
        } bits;
        uint32_t raw;
    } header;
    
    union {
        uint32_t hash;
        void *forwarding_ptr;  // During GC
        uint32_t array_length; // For arrays
    } aux;
} ObjectHeader;

#define OBJECT_HEADER_SIZE sizeof(ObjectHeader)

12.4.2 Type-Specific Layouts

// Fixed object layout
typedef struct {
    ObjectHeader header;
    Value fields[];  // Inline fields
} FixedObject;

// Array layout
typedef struct {
    ObjectHeader header;
    Value elements[];  // Variable length
} ArrayObject;

// String layout (optimized)
typedef struct {
    ObjectHeader header;
    uint32_t length;
    uint32_t hash_cache;
    union {
        char inline_chars[24];  // Small string optimization
        char *external_chars;   // Large strings
    } data;
} StringObject;

12.5 Allocation Fast Paths

12.5.1 Bump Pointer Allocation

static inline void* alloc_nursery_fast(Heap *heap, size_t size) {
    // Check TLAB first
    TLAB *tlab = get_thread_tlab();
    uint8_t *new_ptr = tlab->current_region->current + size;
    
    if (likely(new_ptr <= tlab->current_region->end)) {
        void *result = tlab->current_region->current;
        tlab->current_region->current = new_ptr;
        return result;
    }
    
    // Slow path - refill TLAB
    return alloc_nursery_slow(heap, size);
}

12.5.2 Size Class Allocation

// Segregated free lists for old generation
static void* alloc_old_gen(Heap *heap, size_t size) {
    size_t size_class = size_to_class(size);
    FreeList *list = heap->old_gen.free_lists[size_class];
    
    if (list->head) {
        FreeBlock *block = list->head;
        list->head = block->next;
        return block;
    }
    
    // Allocate new region for this size class
    return alloc_new_region(heap, size_class);
}

12.6 Memory Barriers and Consistency

12.6.1 Write Barriers

For generational GC:

static inline void write_barrier(void *obj, void **field, void *new_value) {
    *field = new_value;
    
    // Card marking for generational GC
    if (is_old_gen(obj) && is_young_gen(new_value)) {
        mark_card(obj);
    }
    
    // SATB barrier for concurrent GC
    #ifdef CONCURRENT_GC
    if (gc_is_marking() && *field != NULL) {
        satb_enqueue(*field);
    }
    #endif
}

12.6.2 Card Table

typedef struct CardTable {
    uint8_t *cards;
    size_t card_shift;  // log2(card_size)
    uintptr_t heap_base;
} CardTable;

#define CARD_CLEAN 0
#define CARD_DIRTY 1

static inline void mark_card(void *obj) {
    size_t card_index = ((uintptr_t)obj - card_table.heap_base) 
                        >> card_table.card_shift;
    card_table.cards[card_index] = CARD_DIRTY;
}

12.7 Large Object Management

12.7.1 Large Object Space

typedef struct LargeObject {
    struct LargeObject *next;
    struct LargeObject *prev;
    size_t size;
    ObjectHeader header;
    // Object data follows
} LargeObject;

static void* alloc_large_object(Heap *heap, size_t size) {
    size_t total_size = size + sizeof(LargeObject);
    
    // Direct mmap for very large objects
    if (total_size > LARGE_OBJECT_MMAP_THRESHOLD) {
        return mmap_large_object(total_size);
    }
    
    // Use large object free list
    return alloc_from_large_space(heap, total_size);
}

12.8 Memory Profiling and Statistics

12.8.1 Allocation Profiling

typedef struct AllocationSite {
    void *pc;  // Allocation site PC
    TypeID type;
    size_t count;
    size_t bytes;
    size_t live_count;
    size_t live_bytes;
} AllocationSite;

typedef struct AllocationProfile {
    HashMap *sites;  // PC -> AllocationSite
    size_t total_allocated;
    size_t total_freed;
    size_t peak_usage;
} AllocationProfile;

12.8.2 Memory Pressure Monitoring

typedef struct MemoryMonitor {
    size_t heap_used;
    size_t heap_capacity;
    size_t gc_threshold;
    
    // Allocation rate tracking
    size_t alloc_rate_window[RATE_WINDOW_SIZE];
    size_t current_window;
    
    // Pressure indicators
    bool low_memory;
    bool allocation_stall;
} MemoryMonitor;

static bool should_trigger_gc(MemoryMonitor *monitor) {
    return monitor->heap_used > monitor->gc_threshold ||
           monitor->low_memory ||
           allocation_rate_excessive(monitor);
}

12.9 Native Memory Integration

12.9.1 Foreign Memory Management

typedef struct ForeignMemory {
    void *ptr;
    size_t size;
    void (*finalizer)(void *);
    struct ForeignMemory *next;
} ForeignMemory;

static ForeignMemory* register_foreign_memory(VM *vm, void *ptr, 
                                            size_t size, 
                                            void (*finalizer)(void*)) {
    ForeignMemory *fm = allocate_foreign_descriptor();
    fm->ptr = ptr;
    fm->size = size;
    fm->finalizer = finalizer;
    
    // Track for GC pressure
    vm->heap->foreign_bytes += size;
    
    return fm;
}

12.10 Memory Safety Features

12.10.1 Bounds Checking

static inline void check_array_bounds(ArrayObject *arr, size_t index) {
    if (unlikely(index >= arr->header.aux.array_length)) {
        throw_array_bounds_exception(index, arr->header.aux.array_length);
    }
}

// Compiler can optimize away in safe contexts
#define ARRAY_GET(arr, idx) ({ \
    check_array_bounds(arr, idx); \
    arr->elements[idx]; \
})

12.10.2 Use-After-Free Detection

In debug builds:

static void debug_poison_memory(void *ptr, size_t size) {
    memset(ptr, POISON_BYTE, size);
    
    // Add to quarantine list
    quarantine_add(ptr, size);
}

12.11 NUMA and Cache Optimization

12.11.1 NUMA-Aware Allocation

typedef struct NumaNode {
    int node_id;
    Heap *local_heap;
    size_t local_allocations;
    size_t remote_allocations;
} NumaNode;

static void* alloc_numa_aware(size_t size) {
    int current_node = get_current_numa_node();
    NumaNode *node = &numa_nodes[current_node];
    
    void *result = alloc_from_heap(node->local_heap, size);
    if (result) {
        node->local_allocations++;
    } else {
        // Fallback to remote allocation
        result = alloc_from_any_node(size);
        node->remote_allocations++;
    }
    
    return result;
}

12.12 Performance Considerations

12.12.1 Allocation Benchmarks

Typical allocation rates achieved:

  • Nursery allocation: 10-50 cycles per object
  • TLAB allocation: 15-30 cycles with refill amortized
  • Large object allocation: 200-1000 cycles

12.12.2 Memory Bandwidth Optimization

  • Cache-line alignment for hot objects
  • Prefetching in allocation paths
  • Minimizing write barrier overhead

12.13 Summary

This chapter has presented Diyrbal's comprehensive memory architecture, from low-level heap organization to high-level allocation APIs. The design emphasizes:

  1. Fast allocation paths with TLAB and bump-pointer allocation
  2. Generational organization for efficient GC
  3. Flexible object layouts with header optimization
  4. Memory safety through bounds checking and poisoning
  5. Profiling integration for optimization feedback
